PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 12.30 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received, through the Governor‐General, from the Governor of Western Australia, a facsimile copy of the certificate of the choice of the houses of the Western Australian parliament of Philip Ross Lightfoot to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Senator John Panizza. I table the document.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Senator Philip Ross Lightfoot made and subscribed the oath of allegiance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received, through the Governor‐General, from the Governor of Victoria the certificate received by the Governor‐General of the choice of the houses of the Victorian parliament of Senator Karen Margaret Synon to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator the Hon. Jim Short. I table the certificate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 March, on motion by Senator Hill:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The AIDC Sale Bill 1997 was introduced into the House of Representatives on 22 February and makes the legislative amendments to enable the sale of the Australian Industry Development Corporation, known as the AIDC. Labor will not oppose the bill, despite having concerns with the legislation as it relates to the AIDC shareholding in the Australian Submarine Corporation and with the employment terms and conditions of the staff—although our concerns in this area have, to some extent, been alleviated.

SPEECH.PARA: The AIDC was established in 1970 as an investment bank to finance Australian industry. Its role, when established, was essentially to fill a gap that was not then adequately covered by the banking sector and other financial lenders. It, essentially, was established to cover cases where the development would not otherwise have taken place or would have been possible only in circumstances—unless local finance was available—that involved ownership of control going to foreign investors.

Over the years, the AIDC has pioneered infrastructure financing and it has a unique capability to turn public policy into reality through reacting as a policy lever for national development. It developed widely recognised project resource and infrastructure financing expertise. Two of the many significant examples of developments which occurred with AIDC financing include the Woodside North West Shelf gas project, which involved $US1.6 billion of financing, and the Argyle Diamond project, where the AIDC was the only Australian financier. There would have been no Australian equity in it but for the AIDC. The Eraring Power Station project was also financed through the AIDC, as was the nucleus telectronics pacemaker, which AIDC underwrote the initial financing of. In addition to all of those very worthwhile and significant infrastructure investments, the AIDC has contributed some $130 million in dividend payments to the Commonwealth since 1983.

Overall, the AIDC has performed well. It did make a loss in 1991, but most banks reported major losses in that period. But it did not, through its difficult period, need to draw on the government guarantee. The loss occurred largely because in the mid‐ to late 1980s the AIDC had moved away from its core business of infrastructure and resources. We, as a Labor Party, believe that there is still a need for activity in this area.

The AIDC currently employs some 200 people. The Labor Party does not want to see overly generous golden handshakes or, in the case of some, golden handshakes going to the AIDC's senior management. Apart from that group, we are concerned that the ordinary workers in the organisation not be disadvantaged by the sale. I note that concerns were expressed about this during the Senate committee hearings. Labor is pleased that assurances have now been given that the existing terms and conditions of employment for these workers will be maintained.

The AIDC is one of two Australian controlled and independent investment houses. There is a real chance that, through this sale, it could be purchased by overseas interests, particularly as there are no special provisions in the bill to deal with foreign ownership. Labor notes the assurances of the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp, that, if the buyer is overseas owned, the AIDC's 48½ per cent holding in the Australian Submarine Corporation could be excluded from the sale. We welcome that assurance but believe we need to legislate to ensure that assurance is maintained. That is the purpose of the amendment I will be moving when we consider the detail of this bill. We will essentially be moving that the Australian Submarine Corporation component be removed from AIDC Ltd and located within the corporation, which is to stay in place under this legislative arrangement to manage the borrowings and loan portfolio and to manage such national interest assets as the Commonwealth's Australian Submarine Corporation shareholding.

Essentially, the AIDC will remain in existence. It needs to manage certain activities. We are saying that this is where the Australian Submarine Corporation shareholding should be parked to ensure the guarantee, the assurance, that was given by Senator Kemp. It will also ensure that the AIDC as well as the Australian Submarine Corporation do not become foreign controlled.

Labor recognises that, to some extent, the AIDC has moved from its original charter and that the need for capital private sector investment in major infrastructure projects, while just as significant, now needs to be addressed in different ways. The AIDC itself has confirmed that there is no function that it now performs which cannot be carried out equally as well by the private sector.

BREAK.PARA: But there still remains a significant gap in the market; the AIDC is no longer specifically focused towards filling that gap. The government is doing nothing to fill this gap because it does not believe that it has a role in the area. Worse, it is cutting away all of the existing support mechanisms: the DIFF scheme, the R&D tax concessions, the bounties, Austrade and AusIndustry to name a few, with a total of $3.9 billion cut out of the last budget. The export market development grant scheme is another.

This year the axe looks set to fall further on the Australian motor vehicle industry. We could see its demise if the government adopts the majority recommendations of the Productivity Commission. Pharmaceuticals, information technology, textiles, clothing and footwear and, once again, research and development concessions have all been under the microscope. Labor strongly opposes the huge cost cutting exercise that Treasury and this government have been involved in in wanting to zap industry and literally wipe out many of these industry sectors. We see a real need for government involvement and a real role for government involvement in these areas.

I certainly hope—although I am not terribly sure this hope will be realised—that some on the back bench opposite understand the destruction that the Treasurer, Mr Peter Costello, is creating in terms of our manufacturing base. It is about time they backed the manufacturing industry in this country.

On Monday 17 March, Labor sought examination of the issue through the Senate Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee. It was a process which yielded some useful information, including the fact that legislation had been drafted without reference to the AIDC board. This is a great government for consultation. It said, `We are going to wipe you out, board members, but we will not tell you about it. We will keep it secret and we will drop it on you in the parliament. You can read about it in the newspapers.' It was only through the hearings we had in the Senate that the board was able to flag three problems that they had with the legislation. This is a hallmark of this government: it announces particular legislation, it consults afterwards and then it does not listen as a consequence of that consultation. We have seen many examples of that in the Senate over the past year.

Unless Labor had actually gone through the accountability exercise in the Senate committee we would not have known about this. The government would not have sought to ask them about these difficulties. These difficulties should have been sorted out well before the legislation was tabled. It does reflect the undue haste with which the government seems to continually introduce legislation, as well as its inability to manage the process of government.
Labor has a second reading amendment with regard to this legislation. I move:
At the end of the motion, add:
"whilst recognising that there were difficulties associated with the way the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC) had moved from its original charter, the Senate nevertheless:
(a) reaffirms its commitment to the principles underpinning the AIDC's creation;

(b) condemns the Government for not putting a structure in place which addresses the failure of Australia's capital markets to provide sufficient long-term, patient funds for industry development; and
(c) calls on the Government to establish an effective means of supporting patient capital investment and to determine remedial strategies appropriate to today's environment".

I would indicate to the Senate that, in addition to that second reading amendment, in the consideration in detail stage of committee we will seek to move amendments to require that the Submarine Corporation's shares be parked in the AIDC. The purpose is to ensure that the Submarine Corporation and the activities that spin off from it, which have seen enormous leverage given to the defence systems and heavy engineering capacity of this country and the critical mass that it established and which would have not been backed by the Australian financiers but for the AIDC, are kept. They are to be kept properly through the corporation's structure and ensure that it is does not come under foreign control. I will seek the opportunity to address those details in the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —The AIDC was established by the Gorton Liberal government in 1970, nearly 30 years ago. It was a marvellous initiative, established by a great Australian nationalist who believed that the resources and ingenuity of Australians should result in an increase in the national income of Australians rather than that of foreign investors. Hence the AIDC was set up to help finance the development of new Australian industries and businesses. It was a great initiative in 1970 and, as the government's proposition of a venture capital fund shows, it still serves a great need.

SPEECH.PARA: Since financial deregulation in 1983 a whole range of merchant banks have been established and have thrived to the extent that it seems that any corporate raider can now obtain finance if they want it. The AIDC was acquired by the previous Labor government to compete with them and in recent years has operated basically as a merchant bank rather than as a tool of national economic development policy. Many of its current problems must be laid at the door of the previous government. Yet the original argument for setting up the AIDC is even stronger now than it ever was. In 1996, Australia's net foreign liabilities, that is debt and equity, constituted 60 per cent of gross domestic product, up from 42 per cent of GDP a decade ago and 20 per cent a decade before that.

In the last decade, net foreign equity investment in Australia has more than doubled, from 9.5 to 20 per cent of GDP. Income payable on those investments, on debt and equity, constitutes virtually all of our $20 billion annual current account deficit. No other OECD country has a current account deficit problem comparable to Australia's, stemming from the failure to finance our own investments domestically. Indeed, it is quite clear that there is a continuing need for a national investment bank with the objective of raising our national income and our economic independence. An AIDC committed to the national interest would fulfil this role. But the AIDC as it is presently structured cannot. It is just a merchant bank, a merchant bank trading off its government guarantee to borrow cheap and lend dear. That is hardly the sort of business that a government instrumentality should be in, and we would like to see it return to its original charter.

For a while the AIDC seemed to become a law unto itself. The accountability regime established by the previous government simply did not work. Former AIDC executives awarded themselves huge wage rises. In 1995, four AIDC executives had packages of over $1 million. Another six were paid over $700,000, well above the market rate even for moderately successful merchant bankers. All of this was done, often with the government appointed member of the board excluded from board meetings or prevented from reporting back to government what was going on, even though such payments seriously affected the AIDC dividend to government. I note with approval that AIDC salaries have since been substantially reduced.

The Democrats believe that the Australian Industry Development Corporation should remain in public ownership. But we believe that its subsidiary, the AIDC Ltd, the corporate subsidiary, should be sold or wound up and its assets transferred back to AIDC the corporation, or there should be a combination of both sale of AIDC Ltd and assets transfer. The corporation should be then given a clear national interest agenda, with a particular focus on small business development, industry development and regional development and then set out to fill the holes in our financial sector and the provision of cheap and accessible finance.

This bill does not achieve that. It does not attempt to achieve that. It merely allows AIDC Ltd to be sold. As a trade sale it is likely to be to another merchant bank or a foreign bank. That will hardly deepen or broaden our financial sector. It will not address the problems that I have outlined and which were also outlined by Labor earlier. It will certainly do nothing to improve our economic independence.

Despite the fact that many of the problems that the AIDC experiences can be laid at Labor's door, we will be supporting Labor's second reading amendment. But we do intend to let the government bill go through with our support, subject to an amendment which we will be putting to clear up some of the areas where there are problems. Those I will address during the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The sale of the AIDC has been on the cards for some time. We will not oppose this measure, in spite of our general view that the public sector representing the public interest has a place in direct market activity and indeed to retain control through public monopoly critical sectors of the economy. The reason we do not oppose the sale is that AIDC has not, in our opinion, done much of anything to actually stimulate industry. Various specific sectoral industry policies have been much more important. In fact, the AIDC has been used to stimulate some quite dubious sectors of the economy, for example the defence industries and defence trade, in what amounts to subsidies for those industries.

SPEECH.PARA: The AIDC is, as honourable senators probably know, the minority shareholder in Australian Submarine Corporation. About one‐eighth of AIDC's capital is tied to the Australian Submarine Corporation, giving it 49 per cent shareholding, enough to give Kockums, the Swedish submarine company, which is the other direct partner in AIDC, controlling interest without expending a cent more than is required. So AIDC is doing great things in terms of benefiting submarine manufacturing here and corporate profits in Sweden.

Of the $100 million invested in companies not wholly owned, about $26 million or one quarter is with Australian Submarine Corporation and $20 million each with Textile Industries Australia and Venture Stores Ltd, respectively a textile manufacturer and a chain of retail stores. About $10 million is with appliance manufacturer Kambrook and other minor amounts are with other manufacturers.

I personally do not see how we are greatly benefiting industry development in Australia with this sort of investment profile. We are benefiting indefensible defence policy for subsidising defence industries. We are benefiting Kambrook a little and the manchester industry, which would potentially help electrical goods manufacturing and textile production, but I am not sure who we are meant to be benefiting in investing in Venture Stores, a retail chain. It does not seem to me that there is a shortage of retail stores or that industry will grow as a result of such investment.

I note that AIDC divested its investment in Berrivale Orchards a few years ago. I think it was at about the same time fruit juice manufacturers were complaining about the impact of the World Trade Organisation bills on the Australian fruit juice industry generally and the citrus industry specifically. Perhaps that was a bit embarrassing. At least some of the investments in wholly owned companies, about $200 million worth, have also been of questionable benefit in terms of industry policy. Investment includes items like International Parking (Liverpool) Pty Ltd and the China Water Company (Hacaing) Ltd. Also, a lot of investments are in bonds and other speculative areas.

As a business, AIDC has not done badly. It has returned profit to the Commonwealth. Our objection previously was based on an objection of the AIDC itself that the mechanism for sale would devalue the company and the problems associated with the repurchase of stock issued on the basis that AIDC would not be sold. At this point, however, AIDC seems to feel content with the sale plan. So there is no real objection to its going ahead.

In the absence of any clear national interest agenda, I would like to point out, though, where in our opinion AIDC has, through government policy changes, missed the mark. AIDC was established as a vehicle for investment in the pursuit of industry policy. I believe the pursuit of industry policy is still a valid goal. I would love to see this government make a commitment to industry development—particularly the development of a manufacturing sector in Australia. We badly need value added industry, and it is clear that the corporate boardrooms globally do not currently see Australia as a source of manufactured goods. The global corporate map has Australia pencilled in as a provider of cheap minerals, wheat, wool and woodchip, and a consumer of manufactured products of all sorts, including, ironically, various kinds of foodstuffs.

A lot of noise has been made in this parliament and academia about the wonders of the Asian economies. It is time we took a real look at what they did. They did not grow by lowering all barriers to imports and foreign investment. They did not grow by severing government involvement in the market and `allowing the market the freedom to develop and thrive'. They kept shelters whilst stimulating their own development through strong, directed investment policies and through direct support for what they considered key industries. They did not simply accept the wisdom of corporate heads and major Western economies. They did not allow themselves to be producers of cheap labour products and primary produce, and consumers of their ex-imperial masters' manufactured goods.

Asian governments actively promoted and developed manufacturing, secondary industry, particularly in the areas of import replacement and value adding. They adopted the highest technological means of production available, produced at the highest technological level that their infrastructure could support and actively sought to increase the level of their infrastructure. This is why China is now producing televisions, electronic goods and, increasingly, computer hardware and software. This is why countries like Taiwan have virtually turned away from low labour cost goods. They do not want their position to be dependent on the poverty of their people. They have aspirations for more than that and as a nation they have been willing to act, through government, to pursue such goals.

Here in Australia we seem to have the opposite aspiration. Government seems to be determined to impoverish people and ensure that a low wage regime will come into play. That is why they do nothing about employment, why there is no investment policy, why there is no industry policy and why they are dismantling industrial relations law as a mechanism to protect workers and turning it into a mechanism to ensure their exploitation. This is why they are dismantling the social support structure under the guise of economic necessity. This is why we see a work for the dole scheme and a move to user‐pays and lower taxes.

This government is here for the corporations and the rich. It is involved in major redistribution of wealth—upwards, from the mouths of workers and those struggling outside the work force. And make no mistake: if there is any area of waste, it lies in the corporate excesses for the upper management. It lies in the lives of the wealthy in Australia.

No, this government is selling Australia down the river. Its idea of development is to mine uranium in a world heritage area. Its idea of development is to give a green light to loggers to decimate the few remaining pockets of old‐growth forest to turn it into woodchips. It would not even rate for being turned into disposable chopsticks; it will be ground into little pieces. This government is determined to turn wealth into dross.

The government's only excuse is the so-called international free market. Attitude is not policy, despite what they say on soft drink commercials. What we need for effective development is a commitment to doing what we need to do to create a world we all wish to live in—a radical concept—one where no-one is in great economic hardship and one that supports community and supports life with a capital `L', the beauty of our natural heritage and the integrity of an ecosystem that makes all our lives possible.

We need positive industry and investment policy, but we need more than that. We need policies of vision, policies that include the future, where development gives more than incidental thought to the long-term state of the earth and our local environment. We need policies for the development of technologies that have positive physical and social effects, policies that take an integrated approach to the future, policies that include at all levels the need to address issues like the greenhouse effect—remember that?—and the ultimate well-being of our water and land.

We also need socially oriented development. We need development that will create a more equitable and diverse society; policies that create full employment under benign conditions—not policies that encourage overwork, insecurity, and breakdown of familial and social relationships. We absolutely do not need divisive policies that pit parts of our community against others, against Aboriginals or migrants—yet that seems to be the direction this government has chosen.

The term `sustainable development', almost since its coining, has been raised whenever people call for protection of nature. It is time to call for the protection of nature and for social welfare to be considered whenever we talk about development. I believe the funds from this sale should be used in this fashion. I will not be holding my breath. Nevertheless, we will be supporting this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran, Sen Julian

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the AIDC Sale Bill is to privatise the Australian Industry Development Corporation Ltd, the AIDC, in line with other government announcements with regard to asset sales—namely, the airports and ANL, the Australian National Line—which will reap billions of dollars for budget repair. I know the other speakers in essence are supporting this bill, but they were giving false sentiment to the AIDC as it is about to be auctioned off. It is always a sentiment you can give and have the luxury of when in opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have to say that particularly the Australian Democrat speaker gave the best case of exactly why it should be sold, and that is that it is no longer acting in its original role. Its lending is now no longer at favourable rates—they are indeed at market rates—and therefore its profits are very slim indeed. Without the government guarantee, it can be said that it would be making massive losses. So the government guaran tee is all that is holding up this particular organisation.

Added to that was the great credibility loss of this organisation when it increased executive salaries to the tune of a million dollars. This is just a relatively small merchant bank and the executives—they were given this pay rise under the previous government, of course—were paying themselves an amount equivalent to that earned by Don Argus or Don Mercer from the National Australia Bank and the ANZ Bank. So I feel that the organisation lost a great deal of credibility and the right to any sentiment that it may get from the opposition.

But it is worth looking at the organisation's history from whence it began because it is in fact entrenched in National Party history, Senator Sherry, which you fail to give due credit to. The library digest gives us the source. The AIDC was established in 1970 and it was mainly the initiative of the Rt Hon. John `Black Jack' McEwen, who was then minister for trade and industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is the current Black Jack?

—Senator Sherry, you interject in relation to `Black Jack' McEwen. The trade portfolio has been held by the National Party since time immemorial and it is still held in this coalition government by the Leader of the National Party and Deputy Prime Minister, Tim Fischer, who is overseas at this very moment progressing Australia's position. The then minister for trade, Jack McEwen, saw the need to counter Australia's growing dependence on foreign capital to support its enterprises and industries. At a time of its creation in 1970, the AIDC was the only merchant bank in the country. It was set up as a state owned merchant bank to provide capital in mining, manufacturing, processing and resource development sectors.

SPEECH.PARA: McEwen was not opposed to foreign investment per se and in fact he acknowledged the importance of the availability of such capital to Australia, as it is today. The AIDC was created to fill a gap then not adequately covered by the banking sector and other financial lenders. It assisted Australian residents to match the share capital required to create or maintain large enterprises so as to avoid too often becoming the minor party in an enterprise which was the target of foreign investment or a takeover.

Since its origins, the Australian financial sector has grown to an extent where there is a multitude of merchant banks and financial institutions accommodating particularly the sectors that the AIDC was particularly interested in or targeted, and they were the mining and manufacturing sectors. I doubt whether the Rt Hon. Black Jack McEwen would have imagined the deregulated economy that we have today, the deregulated financial sector and all the options now open to Australian business. I think he would have understood, would have accepted and would have wanted the sale of the AIDC. The fact is that it has run its course. It no longer the relevancy or usefulness that it did have—and it certainly did have—at its establishment.

Its sale now very much fits this coalition government's privatisation program and debt reduction strategy. The sale is generally supported by the opposition. However, the Senate Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee reports that there was some discussion with regard to the disposal of the AIDC interest in the Australian Submarine Corporation Pty Ltd, of which the AIDC holds some 48.5 per cent. That is a genuine concern and not inappropriate, but it is one that has been understood by this government and has been dealt with. I quote the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp):
. . . it is not the government's intention and, clearly, if there was a potential problem in that area, (the Commonwealth's shareholding in ASC) would be pulled out of the sale.

Just to restate that: there is a proper concern that, when the AIDC is sold, inappropriate foreign investors may take up the AIDC's 48 per cent share of the submarine corporation. But, as that quote says, the government is aware of this and would not allow inappropriate foreign ownership of that particular corporation. Therefore, this bill enables the Minister for Finance to remove any asset from AIDC Ltd and invest it elsewhere. So we have that open option, Senator Margetts. It is important to note that, with the sale of the AIDC, any government asset and funds received will go towards government debt reduction. This is in stark contrast to the privatisation program of the previous Labor government, which wasted billions of dollars of asset sales in recurrent expenditure.

TALK.START.PARA: —What have you done with Telstra?

—Senator Sherry, I honestly do not know why half the time you bother to interject. You are way over there and I am way over here. Just let me progress through this speech. It is really not worth interjecting, given that I am so far over here on the back bench and you are way over there on the front bench. Why don't you just hold your tongue? Save your energies for question time or something a little more appropriate for one of the heavyweights over there. Just let me get on with my speech in the backblocks here of cocky's corner.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I was trying to make was the stark difference between this government's asset reduction program and the previous government's. The previous government just frittered away on spurious causes the billions of dollars that were raised through asset sales. This was a negligent approach to this country's valuable assets. Look at their record. Not only was the sale of the AIDC botched when it was first announced in about 1990 and is only now coming to fruition in 1997, but what of the sale of Qantas?

On four different occasions the Qantas sale appeared in the previous government's budget as a deficit reduction item which never eventuated. Not only was this very disruptive to Qantas operations and a dishonest approach to budget reporting but its eventual sale in 1994, which reaped billions of dollars, was spent to no long‐term advantage of finances. In fact, we know in the Keating government's term that government debt jumped from $30 billion to $100 billion.

Then there was the dishonest sale of the Commonwealth Bank. Time does not permit me to go too deeply into that sale except to say that a commitment was made by the then Treasurer that the then government would hold its 51.3 per cent holdings in the Commonwealth Bank. By the way, he wrote to every shareholder saying that, and every mum and dad bought shares on that basis. He wrote to every shareholder and then, with a flick of a pen, dishonestly sold the rest of the Commonwealth Bank.

Then, of course, there was the debacle of the ANL sale. Again, time does not permit me to go into the history of that sale except that we know one thing: the stop‐start sale of that incompetent and loss‐making shipping line was only stopped for one reason, that is, the Maritime Workers Union weighed in heavily on the previous government. So politics prevented the sale in the national interest on that occasion.

The point to be made here is that this government has a clear, transparent and determined policy towards privatisation. It is based on the criteria of producing competitive benefits for the economy—for example, the Telstra sale, which will produce an efficient company and has allowed new entrants into the telecommunications field—and, of course, the government will use its sales to reduce the long‐term debts which we now face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —In summing up the second reading debate, firstly I thank honourable senators who contributed. It is important that the government put its view in relation to the pious second reading amendment moved by the Australian Labor Party. The government will be opposing the amendment, you will not be surprised to learn. We believe that it is vaguely hypocritical coming from the Australian Labor Party who, indeed, sought unsuccessfully to sell the AIDC over a period of time. I have taken an interest in privatisation issues since I arrived in this place. When the Australian Labor Party finally decided that `privatisation' was not a dirty word, they did seek to sell the AIDC.

SPEECH.PARA: In many of the budgets over the past four or five years of the Labor Party's final period in government, the proceeds of the sale of AIDC were included in budget figures. It was one of those items that was announced for sale virtually every time Mr Keating, Mr Willis or Mr Kerin brought down a budget, but it never quite got done. There were good reasons for that or, indeed, bad reasons—there were problems getting the sale together. It is somewhat hypocritical that the Labor Party should come to this debate and start condemning the process which we are putting into place and it looks as though, with the endorsement of the Senate, it could be successful.

Let me turn to the principles underpinning the wording of the opposition's pious amendment. Paragraph (1) talks about a reaffirmation of the principles underpinning the AIDC's creation. Senator McGauran, in his excellent contribution to the second reading debate, said that Mr McEwen, if he were with us today, would probably have supported the sale for the reason that the AIDC was established in the way it was to promote industry and development in Australia because there was a paucity of, particularly, merchant banking skills within Australia at that time.

Anyone who could possibly say that there is a lack of merchant bankers out there trying to fund anything that moves would basically not know what they are talking about. The application and implementation of the recommendations of the Campbell committee of inquiry—as established by the then Treasurer, John Howard, and implemented, to the great credit of the man, by Paul Keating when he was elected Treasurer in 1983—have ensured that the banking system in Australia is far more vigorous and competitive than it was in 1970.

Some of my colleagues have argued that it needs to be more competitive and, as we see the implementation of the Wallis committee—the daughter of the Campbell committee—report recommendations, we hope that that will be achieved. The principles underpinning AIDC's creation may well be, in broad terms, good principles but to argue that the principles from 27 years ago are applicable now in 1997 is more a reflection of the Labor Party's approach to policy at the moment. What this is really saying is that what they did over the last 13 years was a failure, that they want to go back to the 1950s policies of the Labor Party, the 1950s policies generally—that they want to stop any tariff reduction, they want to stop reform of the tax system and they really want to call a halt to any sort of reform at all. They are saying that everything was hunky‐dory in the 1950s and that we should go back to then. That seems to be Labor's new policy approach and it seems to be reflected again in this amendment.

The government, of course, cannot support the proposition that we have not put a structure in place. Paragraph (2) of the pious amendment addresses the failure of Australia's capital markets to provide sufficient long‐term patient funds for industry development. Paragraph (3) relates to the government needing to establish an effective means for supporting capital investment. This government, through a whole serious of policies, is, indeed, addressing those issues. Clearly the Labor Party did much to destroy investment in Australia, particularly investment in manufacturing—in fact, investment in anything. They went so far as to engineer a recession that wiped out tens of thousands of businesses; a recession that knocked 500,000 people out of jobs.

The centrepoint of Labor's economic and industry policies seemed to be to engineer a recession so that so many of those people got wiped out. Australia is only just beginning to recover from those industry and economic policies. This government—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are doing your best to make it worse.

—Senator Bishop interjects that they had to make it worse so that they could make it better. Dee Margetts would understand: it was the clear‐felling approach to economic and industry policy—just wipe out thousands of hectares. Senator Mark Bishop needs to be on the record: this was the Keating economic and industry policy—we needed to restructure, so we clear‐felled the Australian economy and hoped that something would emerge. Wipe out 500,000 people's jobs and tens of thousands of businesses and see what you are left with.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not take that view. We are implementing a range of policies. I will run through them as quickly as I can. To enable banks to invest five per cent of their core capital in small business without prior consultation with the Reserve Bank, we have changed the prudential requirements. We have changed the tax treatment of equity investment by financial intermediaries in small and medium enterprises, so that such investments will be liable for capital gains rather than income tax. Through the business equity information service, we have sponsored several private finance matching services. We have initiated a review of the pooled development funds program, in an effort to find ways of encouraging greater capital raising and attracting greater participation from superannuation funds in equity provision. We have initiated a significant study to look at the feasibility of an alternative equity market. In the area of corporations law, we have initiated a program called the corporate law economic reform program, which will look at easing prospectus provisions to make the raising of equity capital a lot easier for small and medium enterprises and at changing the exemptions within the corporations law to ensure that small and medium enterprises can access equity capital.

So this government is doing a whole range of things that the previous government ignored for 13 years which will make it easier to access investment capital, for small and medium enterprises particularly. They are things that, I am sure, John McEwen—and even Senator McGauran—would support. Ours is a 1990s approach to raising investment in Australia and not the 1950s approach of the Beazley‐led opposition. They would have Australians believe that some sort of back to the future policy manifesto development program is appropriate.

We will be opposing this second reading amendment for those reasons. I urge all honourable senators to be very careful in supporting what is clearly a very pious amendment coming from the political party which did so much to destroy industrial investment in Australia and which itself proposed the sale of AIDC but failed to sell it. This is clearly a very pious amendment. I urge all senators to oppose this amendment and support the second reading of the bill.
Amendment (Senator Sherry's) agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, page 15 (after line 10), before section 33J, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 33HA Minister for Finance to direct AIDC Ltd to transfer asset

SPEECH.PARA: (1) The Minister for Finance must, by written notice given to AIDC Ltd. direct that body to transfer all of its holdings in the Australian Submarine Corporation to the Corporation.
(2) The direction may impose on AIDC Ltd requirements that are ancillary or incidental to the transfer, including, but not limited to, any of the following requirements:

PARA.TAB: (a) a requirement that the transfer must be completed no later than 30 June 1997;
(b) a requirement that the transfer must be undertaken as a specified manner.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) AIDC Ltd must comply with a direction given under subsection (2).
(4) To avoid doubt, nothing in this or any other Act authorises the Minister to transfer from the Corporation its holding in the Australian Submarine Corporation.
(2) Schedule 1, item 39, page 15 (line 13), omit "The Minister for Finance", substitute "Subject to section 33HA, the Minister for Finance".
(3) Schedule 1, item 39, page 16 (line 5), omit "The Minister for Finance", substitute "Subject to section 33HA, the Minister for Finance".
I also point out that amendment 4 would have to be carried if this issue was to be dealt with correctly and legally. It deals with the same issue.

The effect of the amendments we have circulated, as I foreshadowed in my speech in the second reading debate, is to separate out the sale of the Australian Submarine Corporation and to ensure that it is not sold without parliamentary approval—certainly at this stage. I have outlined in my speech in the second reading debate the reasons we believe that is important.

We have amendments from the Australian Democrats which deal with the same issue but in a very different way. As I am advised, the Democrat amendments separate out the Submarine Corporation. However, it can be left to a minister at a future date, without reference to parliament, to sell the Submarine Corporation. That is the first area of difference. Secondly, the Democrat amendments give preference to the buyer of the AIDC if that is a foreign corporation. If the purchaser of the AIDC—excluding the Submarine Corporation—is a foreign corporation, it has first preference. Then, if a foreign buyer declines that first preference, the AIDC is to be put on the market in Australia. As I under stand it, those are the Australian Democrat amendments.

We think they are very wishy‐washy amendments, for the reasons I have outlined. Above all else, if we are going to separate out the sale of one of the assets of the AIDC and it is not to be sold, it should come back to parliament for sale. That is a very important principle, which I would have thought that the Democrats would agree to. I am surprised they have effectively agreed to the minister—in this case, the Minister for Finance—selling it off. This is at best a holding operation for the Submarine Corporation until the government goes through the process of selling the rest of the AIDC. I do not want to talk too long on this issue. I know that time is pressing and we have a heavy commitment legislatively. Could Senator Campbell let us know when he anticipates the conclusion of the sale of the AIDC?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will seek to achieve the transfer of the 100 per cent ownership to the corporation before September of this year and we would hope to achieve a sale by the end of this calendar year.

—There is no doubt amongst honourable senators that I have had concerns for quite some time in relation to Australia's push for Collins class submarines and whether or not that was a wise way to spend our defence dollar let alone a wise way to spend budget money, considering the other commitments that are before us. What will be the impact in relation to employment? Does it make any difference to employment whether or not the AIDC, along with the Australian Submarine Corporation, is sold?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The effect of the amendment that Senator Murray will be moving will be that the Submarine Corporation is transferred to the Australian Industry Development Corporation, and it also contains restrictions about who can buy the Submarine Corporation. It ensures that a foreigner—and Senator Murray can correct this when he moves his amendment—under the definition in the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act cannot buy it. The long‐term outcome of what happens to the Submarine Corporation is something that we can only guess at.

SPEECH.PARA: It would be in Australia's interests if that corporation was able to move into other industrial areas and to create other businesses than building submarines. That is something that is being speculated upon. Clearly, this government would like to see a major industry like that move into other areas of industrial enterprise, servicing the South‐East Asian and Asia‐Pacific region, but that is something that we as politicians and bureaucrats in the federal government cannot tend to second guess.

As far as AIDC goes, one would hope that—ensuring that as a merchant banking operation it is moving out of the restrictions of being a Commonwealth owned enterprise—it may well be able to grow and expand and create opportunities. I would hope that what we are doing has got more upside for employment than downside, and that would be my own guess.

TALK.START.PARA: —From what the minister has said, I think he is indicating that he will not be supporting Labor's amendment but will be supporting the Democrats' amendment. This brings me to the question: if the multilateral agreement on investment comes to pass and Australia signs up to that, won't the Democrats' amendment be worth nothing, because we won't be able to make laws—we will have to change our laws, won't we—that actually impact on the level of Australian ownership, even if it is perceived by Australia to be in the public interest?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a bridge that we will have to be concerned about if that all comes to pass. I might use this opportunity, rather than having to jump up again, to say that the reason we will support Senator Murray's amendment is that it does put in place a number of sensible restrictions in relation to the transfer of what we regard as a strategic asset for Australia, and it creates a sound legislative framework to do that. It ensures that it cannot be sold.

SPEECH.PARA: What Senator Sherry said about the first right of Kockums to buy the shares out I am advised is correct but we could not legislate to override that because you would be traversing an agreement that is already in place and you would have to pay compensation. I do not even think the Australian Labor Party would want the Senate to override a contractual obligation that was negotiated when they were in power. What we are saying is that, once Kockums's right was at an end—whether or not they had exercised it—under the proposed amendment to be moved by Senator Murray, the sale could not take place to a foreigner under the definition used in the foreign takeovers act.

It is not using the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act to create that power under this bill. All it is doing—I think I am correctly advised—is to use the definition used under that act, so it is giving the minister quite a specific amount of power. To go to the hypothetical situation that Senator Margetts has moved—

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't think hypothetical.

—It is hypothetical at the moment because what you have said has not happened. It may happen and a lot of people think it would be a good thing if it did happen. I am not up with negotiations in relation to deregulating foreign investment, but I would imagine that national governments would retain some significant powers in relation to the ownership of defence manufacturing and things like that. I do not know but it would be an interesting debate for another time. I will certainly research it. It is not germane to this specific bill.

SPEECH.PARA: We have some significant misgivings about the effect of the Australian Labor Party's amendments, which were moved in the House of Representatives as well. They are technically flawed. I will say for the record why they are technically flawed and why Senator Murray's amendment achieves a similar result but in a better structured way.

There is a timing problem. Proposed amendment No. 1 requires the transfer to be the first act taken before the transfer of minorities makes AIDC Ltd a wholly owned AIDC body, which is how other transfer provisions in the bill are drafted. Yet subsection 2(a) requires transfer by 30 June 1997.

Technical problems arise from the creation of a separate, independent power of direction and a lack of proper cross‐referencing within the legislation. So, under the amendments, any transfer would not be exempt from stamp duty under section 33X, and proceeds of the asset transfers, if any, may be extracted from AIDC Ltd under section 33U only if they are transfers under 33J. More significantly, proposed amendment No. 4 would prevent the corporation from subsequently disposing of the holding without further legislation. It would defeat the government's policy objective of ultimately abolishing the corporation and repealing the act.

Opposition amendment No. 4, which would prevent the repeal of the Australian Industry Development Corporation act, is not necessary in any case. The corporation cannot be abolished so long as it has any assets under the commencement provision in clause 2 of the AIDC Sale Bill. I am advised that that is not likely to occur for some 10 years at least because of the existing assets and commitments of the corporation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be speaking to Senator Sherry's criticisms in respect of the AIDC Sale Bill when I come to deal with my own amendment. I will signify, for the purposes of the committee, that we will not be supporting Labor's amendment because we think ours is superior to their intention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —It does not surprise me that you think it is superior, but it is inferior in our view. There are some issues that I want to raise in respect of the Democrats' amendment. I know that we have crossed over somewhat in this debate. Senator Campbell, if you do not think that amendment 4 is necessary, we would be very happy if you would accept amendments 1, 2 and 3. I reiterate that we believe the Submarine Corporation should be separated out. It is a strategic asset. Senator Campbell, who are the owners of Kockums?
—I am advised that it is partially the Swedish government and partially Swedish private interests. We are just trying to find out whether Abba have shares. But I am advised they do not.
—Mamma Mia! We jest, but I think it is a serious issue. Our intention is to park the Submarine Corporation separately—
—Moor it.

—Sorry, we are mooring it. Goodness knows where—maybe out in the Pacific somewhere. Seriously, we are proposing to park it. This is a strategic asset. We face the prospect, as I understand the Democrats' amendment, that Kockums, which has a substantial foreign shareholding of Swedish interests, will have first preference. We are not attempting to override the contractual agreement that the government has. We are saying that it should not be sold—full stop. If Kockums chooses to purchase—as I understand the Democrats' amendment—we could face the potential of the ownership of the Australian Submarine Corporation passing into the hands of a Swedish company.

SPEECH.PARA: I would contend that that is not in the best strategic interests for Australia. I am not just talking from a military point of view; I am talking from an industry policy point of view. Longer term, where the Swedish submarine interests come into conflict with the Australian operations, if that ownership change should occur, I cannot imagine the Australian national interests being put before Swedish national interests. That is what concerns me about the Democrats' approach.

Time is pressing on. I understand the situation with the numbers. The Democrats, in the longer term, are going to sell out Australian strategic interests with their amendment. That is a great pity. I know the way the votes are going to fall, and I think it would be futile to waste the time of the chamber in a long and lengthy debate on this issue. I think it is very regrettable that the Democrats' action does not meet rhetoric once again. But that is the way they intend to vote on this occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The rhetoric of Senator Sherry does not match the rhetoric of the Labor government and particularly of Senator Ray, when he was defence minister, who actually negotiated this pre‐emptive right for Kockums.
—Yes, but we didn't sell it to them, did we?

—No, but you have negotiated the arrangement whereby Kockums have a right. This government has not done anything about that arrangement whatsoever. This bill does not change that amendment. This bill, as amended by Senator Murray's amendment—if it is passed in this place, and I put money on the fact that it will at this stage; I join you on that—ensures that, if the shareholding in the Australian Submarine Corporation is to be sold, it cannot be sold to a foreign person as described by the FAT—the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the exercise of Kockums's pre-emptive rights, I am advised, would require Foreign Investment Review Board approval under the FAT Act. So there still is a requirement there, but it is quite unbelievable that a Labor Party senator should come in here and criticise the fact that a Swedish owned company should not have a right to purchase the balance of the company when it was actually the Australian Labor Party minister and government who negotiated that right. For the Senate to then seek to overturn that would be a government breach in that contract. It could quite clearly give rise to issues of compensation if the Australian government was forced to do that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —But we are not seeking to override the contractual agreement that has been entered into, as you point out, by a Labor minister. We are saying that here, now, today, given the circumstances of Australian industry, given what you have been doing to industry policy in this country, the Submarine Corpo ration should remain in public ownership. That is the way we see it—full stop.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Sherry's ) be agreed to.
Noes 42

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, item 39, page 16 (after line 23), at the end of section 33K, add:

PARA.TAB: (6) If a share in a company vests in a person under this section, the company must register the person as the holder of the share.
(7) Subsection (6) has effect despite anything in the Corporations Law.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Schedule 1, item 39, page 16 (after line 23), after section 33K, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 33KA Special provisions relating to shares in the Australian Submarine Corporation

SPEECH.PARA: (1) If an AIDC body is the holder of legal or beneficial interests in shares in the Australian Submarine Corporation, the Minister for Finance must:

PARA.TAB: (a) make such a declaration under section 33K as will result in the Australian Industry Development Corporation becoming the holder of those interests before 1 September 1997; or

(b) make such a series of successive declarations under section 33K as will result in the Australian Industry Development Corporation ultimately becoming the holder of those interests before 1 September 1997 as a consequence of one or more interposed transfers to other AIDC bodies.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) If the Australian Industry Development Corporation becomes the holder of those interests as a result of the declaration or any of those declarations, this Act does not prevent those interests from being subsequently sold or transferred.

(3) If the Australian Industry Development Corporation becomes the holder of those interests as a result of the declaration or any of those declarations, the Australian Industry Development Corporation must not subsequently sell or transfer those interests to a foreign person (within the meaning of the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act 1975 ) unless:

PARA.TAB: (a) immediately before the commencement of this section, the foreign person had an entitlement to acquit those interests; and
(b) immediately before the commencement of this section, the foreign person was a registered shareholder in the Australian Submarine Corporation; and
(c) that entitlement:

TAB.TAB: (i) arises out of a shareholders' agreement; or
(ii) relates, directly or indirectly, to the foreign person's capacity as a registered shareholder in the Australian Submarine Corporation; and

PARA.TAB: (d) the sale or transfer:

TAB.TAB: (i) gives effect to that entitlement; or
(ii) would have given effect to that entitlement if it were assumed that AIDC bodies and the Australian Industry Development Corporation were the same entity.

SPEECH.PARA: (4) For the purposes of this section, a person is entitled to acquire any thing if the person is absolutely or contingently entitled to acquire it, whether because of any constituent document of a company, the exercise of any right or option or for any other reason.
(5) In this section:

TAB.TAB: Australian Submarine Corporation means Australian Submarine Corporation Pty Limited.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Campbell was quite right in his remarks, because no government—I am referring to the previous government—negotiates a pre-emptive right with a commercial institution without having a potential sale in its mind. Quite clearly, the previous government kept that option open. The fact is that the Swedish consortium, Kockums, was given that right by Labor, has that right and has the entitlement to exercise it if it so wishes.

I want to say something in reaction to Senator Sherry's remarks. Labor has a long history of the sale of public assets. It has a committed history of economic rationalism. I stood in this chamber and heard the best possible speech I have ever heard against the sale of airports from Senator Bob Collins. Then Labor trooped over to the other side and flogged off yet another set of our assets. When I hear you—again, to use Senator Campbell's words—coming the pious on us, I look forward to the days when Labor finally gives up its old record of economic rationalism.

Let us look at my amendments and where we agree with and differ from Labor. Labor quite rightly referred the bill to the Senate Finance and Public Administration Commit tee. That committee, again quite rightly, raised serious issues which were pursued further by Labor and by us. When we had a look into it, we established that AIDC Ltd's principal asset at the moment is the Australian Submarine Corporation. So far that corporation has produced one out of five submarines. When that contract has finished, the effect will be that unless the ASC continues with other work or in some other form, that will be the end of it. It will have a residue of depreciated assets, some intellectual property and the overhang of government investment in it over the years.

Labor and the Democrats were both concerned to see that the ASC was not immediately sold off with AIDC Ltd, and that it be transferred into the AIDC. We both achieved that result. We were both concerned that it was not sold to foreign interests, except with regard to the pre-emptive right that Kockums has. Once again, we have both achieved that result. However, we have taken the view that the only way in which government can deal with this issue is by having its hands relatively untied. For us the most important thing is that the jobs and the investment and the contracts which matter so much to South Australia are preserved and do continue. We have the government's assurance that they are going to make sure that that happens. In fact, they are contractually bound to make sure that that happens.

Our amendments followed a briefing discussion with the Minister for Finance. We thank you for the courtesy accorded us. Therefore, we put together our amendment to the AIDC Sale Bill, which would achieve a number of objectives. These were: firstly, to oblige the minister to transfer their ASC shareholding to the Australian Industry Development Corporation, which is a statutory authority and is not subject to sale; secondly, to require AIDC Ltd to follow the minister's direction to transfer shares, which was vital from a legal point of view; thirdly, to preclude the transfer of the shareholding in any subsequent sale of the shares to a foreign person; and, fourthly, to use the Foreign Acquisition and Takeovers Act 1975 to establish the meaning of a foreign person.

BREAK.PARA: When the bill was considered by the Senate Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee, of which I am a member, the ALP members issued a minority report proposing an amendment which required the transfer of the shares to the corporation. This also prevented those shares being sold in the future. That proposed amendment was drafted as a stand‐alone section of the bill.

The amendment responding to the Democrats' concerns has been prepared to be consistent with and take advantage of the powers provided by other sections of the bill. It is to be inserted immediately after section 33K to take advantage of the power provided by 33K which enables the minister to vest the shares without the need for conveyance and this minimises the risk of triggering any pre‐emptive rights held by the shareholders in the Australian Submarine Corporation.

The drafting uses the term `AIDC body', defined elsewhere in the bill as `the corporation or a wholly owned subsidiary of the corporation'. This is important, as the minister is only obliged to move the shares following the acquisition of AIDC Ltd shares from the two minority shareholders in that company, which again were a hangover from previous re‐acquisitions. Transfer of the ASC shares prior to that action could give rise to problems in relation to minority shareholders' rights.

The utilisation of 33K powers by the minister ensure that the powers provided elsewhere in the bill oblige AIDC Ltd to follow the minister's direction. Division 11 of the bill provides a series of injunctive powers. A date has been inserted to provide comfort that the move of the shares will take place in a reasonable time and that provides sufficient flexibility to ensure that the Office of Asset Sales and its advisers have had the opportunity to ensure that related issues concerning rights and obligations associated with the shareholding are properly addressed at the time the move takes place.

AIDC Ltd holding the shares in a subsidiary company and intercompany arrangements associated with the shareholding will need to be addressed. AIDC Ltd has certain rights as a principal shareholder which will need to be transferred to the corporation when their shares are moved, possibly involving negotiation with the other principal shareholder, the 48½ per cent shareholder, Kockums. The ASC shares are held through a series of subsidiary companies, AIDC Defence Holdings, which is 100 per cent owned by AIDC Investments, which in turn is 100 per cent owned by AIDC Limited. Section 33KA(l)(b) allows the shares to be moved through the companies if that fits with the intercompany relationships.

The Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act 1975 provides for a range of circumstances in determining a foreign person covering direct shareholdings, substantial interests, associations, trust arrangements and residency issues. Subsections 33KA(3)(a) to (d) are included to ensure that the amendment does not constitute an appropriation of existing shareholders' rights that the other parties may have. Without this, it would be necessary to provide for compensation to the other existing shareholders or the legality of the move of the ASC shareholding could be in question. The shareholder rights that would be protected would only be those that existed at the commencement of the bill. Any other regulatory requirements that would apply to those shareholder rights, such as satisfying the normal provisions of the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act, would not be removed. Subsections 33KA(4) and (5) are included for the purpose of clarifying the meaning of certain references in the section.

We think that our amendment meets the needs of the Senate. It meets the needs of the FPA committee, as expressed in their report. It meets many of the concerns of Labor. It certainly meets most of the concerns of the Democrats and therefore we commend the amendment to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated earlier, one of my concerns is that the multilateral agreement on investment, which is being negotiated internationally at the moment, will in fact, if and when it is signed—and it may not be too long from now—have the effect of requiring Australia to change its laws in relation to access to investments. There could be a whole range of laws, including media laws or laws involving investment in defence industry.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not know what the wording of this agreement currently is or what it will be in its final form. I think our negotiators probably have a better idea than we do. Obviously, it would be a very good idea if we do know what this will be, because in the end it may well mean that our laws will have to change to conform with the multilateral agreement on investment.

Many things have changed as a result of the World Trade Organisation, including issues of quarantine, customs standards and so on, to the detriment and concern of many people in the community. These were not mentioned by either the government or the opposition at the time these were signed on to. I do think it is time now that we started looking at what it is we are signing on to. I do not think from the sound of it that it would make much difference whether or not the Greens support it, because the numbers are obviously there. If we are going to get a warm fuzzy feeling, we should remember that that warm fuzzy feeling may not be around for very long. We may not necessarily be protecting this industry.

If there are exemptions within the multilateral agreement on investment, there are not many exemptions in the way of the World Trade Organisation agreement through the Uruguay Round of GATT that specifically say that Australia can operate in its own interest in relation to whom we trade with and defence issues. It is only if there is a specific security risk to Australia and that would be hard to justify if it was a middle eastern country or somewhere in Europe.

If we make an ethical decision that is not currently already part of the World Trade Organisation agenda, one would wonder exactly what exemptions there would be and why it would be limited to trade and defence and not a whole lot of other issues. We still have to know these things, but I would not necessarily hold my breath and assume that this amendment—which is likely to be going through—will in the long run mean that we will not have Australian Defence Industries owned and operated almost totally, if not totally, by overseas concerns.

BREAK.PARA: Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Campbell) read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Minister, was the Prime Minister correctly reported in the Sydney Morning Herald as describing the Melbourne Age as appalling, the Sydney Morning Herald as too liberal and the Australian Financial Review reporters as being out of control? Having made these comments in private to the cabinet and to at least one media proprietor is the Prime Minister now willing to make them public? To what extent will these views drive government policy in the area of media ownership?

—I suspect there would be a range of views around this chamber in assessment of various journalists within those publications. Senator, if you want me to ask the Prime Minister whether he was reported correctly I will do so but the important thing is that when the government is ready it will make a decision on the cross‐media matters and it will do so against a background of encouraging diversity whilst at the same time looking to the least amount of regulation that is necessary to achieve that objective.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, will government policy be sensitive to Minister Moore's stated concerns that `any movement towards lack of diversity would not be in the national interest'? Has Mr Moore spoken to the Prime Minister on his concerns?

—I think I have answered the question. You can expect from us objective and sound policy in contrast with Labor's record in relation to media control, a record which has a long and dark history, unfortu nately. We are approaching this matter with care. That is not surprising. Senator Alston has conducted an inquiry and is well informed in the matter. Advice has been given to the cabinet and, at an appropriate time, a decision will be made as to whether there should be change.

—My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Last week marked the fourth reduction in interest rates since the coalition came to office; a further vindication of the government's economic strategy, I might add. How will the environment of low interest rates, low inflation and strong business investment assist Australian families and small business?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —More good news as a result of coalition government policy; a further dividend to the Australian people resulting from good, sound economic management. It was interesting that practically everyone within our country applauded it, except the Australian Labor Party—perhaps because of the contrast with their record in relation to interest rates. Yes, it is good news for Australian families and it is good news for small business as well. It vindicates what was a sound budget, a budget of consolidation to build on the difficulties of the previous year when we had to address the inherited deficit of $10.3 billion. I am very pleased that we have been able to rein in that deficit, reduce expenditure—and, therefore, keep pressure off interest rates—continue an even lower inflationary environment and encourage expanded economic growth.
—Did you see Roy and HG on Saturday night?

—That is something that you should applaud, Senator Sherry. It is good news for all Australians, particularly for those seeking jobs. It is, as Senator Knowles said, the fourth reduction in interest rates since the coalition was elected just over a year ago and already we have been able to see four reductions in interest rates with a sum total of two per cent. Interest rates are now at their lowest level in 24 years: 7.2 per cent on variable home loans. Under the coalition government we have the lowest interest rates in 24 years. Small business, as I said, is also the winner, with business variable loan rates falling to 9.25 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: The reduction in interest rates is consistent with the government's strategy which is to produce a growth, low inflation and low interest rate environment. It indicates the benefits that can flow from the decisions that this government has been prepared to take. It is a reward for the battlers—never let that be forgotten. It is a reward for those who have been prepared to practice wage restraint despite what they are encouraged to do by the Australian Labor Party. It would be even better if the Australian banks would pass on the full benefit. I take the opportunity to welcome Aussie Home Loans' example, which has dropped its home loan variable interest rate to 6.99 per cent by passing on the interest rate reduction in full.

Let us briefly compare the coalition record with that of Labor. Home loan interest rates under Labor were 17 per cent in 1989‐90 and under the coalition they are 7.2 per cent. For small business they were over 20 per cent in 1989‐90 and under the coalition they are just over nine per cent. Credit card rates under Labor were over 25 per cent and under the coalition they are 16 per cent. This continues the environment of low interest rates, low inflation and strong business investment. Profits are rising—and that is more good news.

It was interesting to see organisations such as the Housing Industry Association and the Real Estate Institute applauding the government's decision. What did they say? They said that this creates the environment for more jobs. That is good news for Australia and adds to the other benefits that have flowed from coalition decisions: the $1 billion family tax initiative, $600 million being put back into private health insurance, the savings rebate and the decision to reduce the provisional tax uplift factor. That is sound economic management, with benefits for all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the Leader of the Government in the Senate tell the Senate whether this environment of low interest rates, low inflation and strong business investment will be assisted by any other reforms the government has in place?

—I could talk about the industrial relations reforms, for example. Really what we did in the first year was to tackle all the big decisions: cut back expenditure, IR reform, reduce red tape for small business, give business a chance to grow and to improve. I do welcome the supplementary question because it reminds me that economic growth is now accelerating: 3.25 was the projected figure, now it is 3.75. There is improved housing affordability—the best figures for years and years—and a strong outlook for investment growth with 16 per cent in 1996‐97, up from eight per cent. Retail sales are rising. There is lots of good news as a result of sound coalition policy.

—My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Has the minister's attention been drawn to comments by a member of the Wallis inquiry into the Australian financial system, Mr Bill Beerworth—you appointed him—in London recently? Is Mr Beerworth correct in asserting that the government is unlikely to implement the Wallis reforms because of the tough decisions facing it on Wik? Is he right when he says that the government has adopted Wallis's `weasel words' on foreign ownership? Is Mr Beerworth correct in asserting that the ACCC is only interested in highly photogenic cases and is not interested in being a retail protection agency?

—One thing you cannot say about this government is that it is not reformist. I am amazed to hear this question. The complaint of Labor until now has been that there was too much reform in the first year. What we will do now is try and build on those changes. It is a period of consolidation to give business the chance to grow and to expand and to employ more Australians—and all you do is come back and knock us again. That reform package is still on the table. It is being considered by government and appropriate decisions will be made in due course. When we are ready to make them, we will make them.

—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. I refer to last Friday's cut in official interest rates by the Reserve Bank, which means that interest rates have now fallen a full two percentage points in 14 months since the coalition have been in government. We have heard Senator Hill espouse its benefits but, from the Assistant Treasurer's perspective, how did the government's responsible and prudent economic management help create the conditions for an interest rate cut? What is the government's view on the failure, thus far, of the big four banks to pass on the full cut in official rates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for your question, Senator. It is clear that, once again, you are focusing on the main game—issues of concern to families and to business. These are the sorts of questions that we never get from the opposition.

ANSWER.PARA: The government's budget received a resounding endorsement on Friday, with a further cut in official interest rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did the banks do?

—I am coming to that, Senator; just contain yourself. As was mentioned by my colleague, Senator Hill, the Reserve Bank announced on Friday, for the fourth time since the election, a fall of two percentage points. Of course, the government welcomes the cut in official interest rates which, I assume, the Labor Party welcomes.
—We do.
—Good to hear. It does promise help to long‐suffering families who struggled under the very high interest rates burden that the Labor Party imposed on them.

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order, which relates to repetition. This is exactly the same as Senator Hill's answer. He should be sat down. It is exactly the same answer: same wording but with a much poorer delivery, I might say.
—Order! There is no point of order. He is answering a different question.

—It is quite clear, as one of my colleagues said, that the Labor Party really do not like good news. This budget strategy is conducive to low interest rates. In just three years the government is turning around Labor's $10.3 billion deficit, which they left the government, into a $1.6 billion surplus. This is a turnaround of some $12 billion—a major achievement of this government. While other factors do help determine interest rates, including wages, the fact remains that the budget strategy is very important in this regard.

ANSWER.PARA: The big four banks are now offering home loan rates of 8.2 per cent, which represents an interest saving on a loan of $100,000 of some $275 a month compared to when we came into office. This represents a benefit of around $70 a week. The government is concerned that the big banks have not passed on the official interest rate cut fully to lower home loan rates. Official interest rates are done for the benefit, we hope, of consumers—not for the benefit of banks. The government believes that the battlers deserve to have their reward quickly and fully.

The ACCC has written to the banks asking them to explain their actions in only passing on 0.35 per cent of the rate cut. It is, of course, up to the ACCC to determine if any breaches of the Trade Practices Act have occurred.

The government is putting in place a low inflationary, low interest rate, strong growth environment which delivers sustained reductions in unemployment. In contrast, what is the Labor Party offering? The Labor Party has consistently opposed the government's policies to eliminate the huge deficit that was left to us by the Labor Party.
