The Labor Party has a strong record of big deficits, big taxes and high interest rates. That is not the government's policy; that is the policy of the Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. Minister, can you confirm that the changes to the treatment of income stream products under the social security income and assets test will be retrospective? Can you confirm that pensioners who invested in these products on the advice of their financial advisers some years ago will now be disadvantaged by your changes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the question shows a lack of understanding about the measure that is being proposed. I would suggest to the honourable senator that perhaps he might go back and have a look at the fine print.

ANSWER.PARA: This is a measure which has been welcomed around Australia by retirees as well as by the retirement income industry. This is a measure which will make sure that financial planners are not able to advertise that you can be a millionaire and still get a social security pension. If the Labor Party is suggesting that they want to see a continuation of that, which flourished under their years in government, well they should make it very clear. On this side of the parliament we believe that people who have the means to support themselves should be expected to do so to the extent that they are capable of before they ask their neighbour or the taxpayer for assistance. That is the first part of this answer.

In addition, the reform to the income and assets testing of income streams is designed to give retired people more choice in how they invest their money, to be fairer to them and to encourage them to go for long-term income streams. A habit of recent times has been for the financial industry to recommend that prospective retirees should put their money into short-term measures. The way our tests are determined in the Department of Social Security means that notionally those assets are seen to disappear from the assessment. Those are the sorts of short-term products of something like five years maximum. People have the opportunity to change those by the time the proposal becomes law. They have plenty of time ahead of them now over the next year to change the way they have invested.

I believe that the nation will endorse, as I have found in this past week going around a number of states in Australia, this measure as a fair and beneficial measure. The only people who will be affected are those people who are being persuaded to hide their assets from the Department of Social Security. That is not fair to Australians generally.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Minister, can you confirm that it is your department's assessment that pensioners will need more help from financial information services officers as a result of the changes, not less?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I will confirm that. And yes, we have made provision for extra financial information services officers to deal with that item that we are introducing in the budget in addition to the deferred pension bonus plan. So we have recognised the need people will have for that information. They will need to make sure that the advice they are getting from the commercial sector is not self-interested on the part of the private sector but geared at trying to maximise a retiree's total retirement income. That is what we are about—making sure that older people have maximum retirement income, not allowing people to run a horse and cart through the social security system, as you allowed to happen for all those years.

—My question is to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Minister, do you think that acknowledging the past honestly is a fundamental prerequisite for reconciliation? Does honest acknowledgment of the past allow you as, Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, on behalf of Australian governments past and present, to apologise for the mistaken policy of forced separation of Aboriginal children from their families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Kernot for the question. The answer to the first part of the question is yes. The answer to the second part is that a formal response to the tabling of the report into the separa tion of children will be given at an appropriate time and it will be tabled this afternoon.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that that is so close, Minister, can I ask you to put this on the record: given that the Prime Minister this morning expressed deep personal sorrow for the impact of the policy, are you able as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to extend that deep personal sorrow to an apology at the government level, or do you have some advice which tells you that the minute you say sorry or apologise you open the floodgates for some kind of compensation? Is it not true that people can pursue their rights to compensation irrespective of what this government decides to do?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, people can pursue them and are pursuing them. As you know, there are two cases before the courts at the moment. I do not think any prejudging of that is appropriate. As I said previously, I will make a statement on behalf of the government at the appropriate time after the report has been tabled.
—You are hopeless. You are a disgrace. You create embarrassment for Australia.

—I am pleased that my staff are in the gallery. You will understand what I am referring to if you heard Senator Bolkus's statement. An appropriate response to the report will be given at the appropriate time.
—No-one else does, you can be certain of that. They might but no-one else will.
—I was referring to the sledging that goes on from the other side. I just thought that I would draw it to their attention while they were in the gallery.

—My question is to Senator Alston, as minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service. Minister, has your attention been drawn to recent comments by the Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Mr Max Moore-Wilton, that higher pay was required to overcome a vacuum at the senior levels of the Public Service? Is there a vacuum at the senior levels of the Public Service and how does Mr Moore-Wilton's call for higher pay fit with the government's views on enterprise bargaining?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see some remarks attributed to Mr Moore-Wilton. I have not canvassed them with him or sought any official response so I can only go about as far as Senator Hogg is able to go, I think, in terms of interpreting what was being said. But, as I understand it, Mr Moore‐Wilton was simply making the point that it is important to have sufficient incentives and sufficient wage levels in place to attract the best people. There can be no doubt that the fundamental direction and impetus and enthusiasm of government departments is overwhelmingly—
—How much extra are you going to give the ABC so they can employ Jana Wendt?
—Pardon?
—Order! Senator Alston, you should be answering Senator Hogg's question.

—The ABC has done very nicely, I would have thought. The ABC has basically managed to adapt very nicely to what we gave them in the last budget. So I do not think the complaint comes from that corner.

ANSWER.PARA: The point that is more important is that the secretary to a department, the person who has the ultimate responsibility, overwhelmingly sets the direction for the pace of reform, the way in which that department accommodates it and the way in which those who are responsible for reporting carry out their duties. I think Mr Moore‐Wilton was simply trying to make the point that it is very important indeed that we have wage structures that enable those people to be attracted to the service and indeed to remain in the service.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the government share Mr Moore-Wilton's view that departmental secretaries should have access to a BMW in the same way that the Reserve Bank Governor, Mr Ian Macfarlane, has?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, I am not sure of the precise context in which those reported remarks might have been made, but I think what Mr Moore-Wilton was presumably intending to point to—rather than it simply being interpreted as it was: as a sort of straight‐line ambit claim for everyone to get a BMW—was that we do need to ensure that there are attractions to the package. You blokes were masters at this idea of dressing things up, offering all sorts of untaxed returns, to the point where the tax system started creaking at the edges because of salary sacrifice and other arrangements.

ANSWER.PARA: Clearly, I think what he was pointing to was the fact that we cannot simply assume that a particular sum of money is sufficient; that there are other add‐ons that need to be looked at, in examining the total attractiveness of a package. I do not think he should have been taken as suggesting that somehow there was a straight‐line transfer that whatever the Governor of the Reserve Bank gets is appropriate for any particular public servant.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Trade. I refer to the current negotiations within the OECD for a multilateral agreement on investment, and I ask: what assessment has the government done on the impacts of this agreement on areas such as the Foreign Investment Review Board; Australian laws limiting overseas investment or cross‐ownership, such as media cross‐ownership laws; laws regulating investments themselves, such the regulations requiring a certain level of Australian content in television; and any manufacturing regime requiring a minimum Australian content or requiring re‐investment of profits in this country? When would any government assessment of these effects be made available, and would this be made available to the parliament for debate before any agreement is signed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously we take into account in these negotiations our domestic situation and our practices in relation to manufacturing industry, international flows of capital and the like. With respect, I think Senator Margetts is approaching the issue a touch negatively. Really the issue is what benefits Australia and other communities can gain from the multilateral agreement on investments.

ANSWER.PARA: If we come back to what it is all about, we believe that if a regime is in place that enforces non‐discrimination and greater transparency in investment rules, then that will help contribute to economic expansion in much the same way as we have been able to do through the regime on multilateral trading. So we think that it is not conceptually possible to separate the two. Expanding the international community, with the benefits that flow in terms of higher living standards and jobs, requires an expansion in the movement of international finance as it does an expansion in international trade.

These negotiations, as the honourable senator will know, have been going on for some time under the auspices of the OECD. I understand it has not been an easy negotiation. In fact, the deadline for completion has had to be extended. That is quite a good sign in some ways because it indicates the international community is looking for a high quality agreement and it is not going to compromise with a lower quality outcome simply to comply with the earlier time restraints that had been applied.

So the concept I think is sound and in the national interest. Australia will continue constructively negotiating towards a good outcome. As I understand it, when we reach a conclusion, it will have to go through the treaty process that we have in relation to other such agreements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. The minister still has not answered the question about whether an assessment has been done or when it will be made available.
—Senator Hill, do you wish to make any further comments?

—I said that we obviously negotiate against the background of our domestic economic environment, and that includes the regulatory regime that we have in place. But we do not negotiate negatively—we negotiate positively—because we see that a more transparent flow of international capital can actually benefit Australia and help create more jobs.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The way I read that is there will not be an assessment and it certainly will not be available to the Senate or to the public before any agreement is signed. By way of a supplementary question: the Prime Minister has acknowledged the high levels of community disillusionment and uncertainty as a result of international agreements signed already. Given the assurances that government gave us about our sovereignty in relation to such things as quarantine barriers under the World Trade Organisation agreement, and given the subsequent debacle as a result of our lack of control in such agreements, why should we imagine that after signing this agreement any parliament in Australia will retain the ability to discriminate between overseas and Australian investment or to regulate terms at variance with the multilateral agreement on investment under which investment may occur?

—Again, it is a very negative approach from Senator Margetts. What she does not appreciate is that we are negotiating this agreement for Australia's advantage, not Australia's disadvantage, otherwise we would not be negotiating it at all. We can see the benefits that flow from capital. We have built Australia in part on foreign capital, and if we have in place a more transparent, non‐discriminatory capital flow regime that will be of benefit to Australia. I simply urge her not to approach all these things quite as negatively as she is, but to actually look at the advantages that can come from them. The advantages in this instance include economic growth and jobs.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Minister, has your attention been drawn to a recent Federal Court decision upholding an earlier ruling by the Public Service and Merit Protection Commission that a public servant who authorised and signed for his own receipt of a meal allowance should be demoted and forced to repay the money? Minister, are you aware that in this case the commission found that the public servant `had the sole approving and accounting function at the post and was required to satisfy himself as to the correctness and legality of the payment in terms of his authority'? Minister, are you also aware that the disciplinary appeals committee found that the conduct constituted a breach of the standard of behaviour expected of an officer? Minister, what is the difference between these circumstances and the case involving Mr Max Moore-Wilton?

—I have answered before, and we had some discussion on this in the estimates committee, that the practice adopted by Mr Max Moore-Wilton in relation to that matter was consistent with previous practices. We talked about the range of departmental officials who were involved in that process. We talked about the fact that the benefits that flowed to Mr Max Moore-Wilton were in fact less than what could have been possible through other alternatives. I understand that even since then there has been some third party assessment of the process, I think again through the merit authority, which has confirmed that the practices adopted in that case were all in order.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, how did Mr Max Moore-Wilton get away with his self‐approval of temporary accommodation arrangements when the public servant was treated in the way that I outlined in my question? Why hasn't Mr Max Moore-Wilton been asked to repay his forgone officer contribution towards the weekly cost of his Canberra accommodation?

—I have answered the question. The practice that was adopted in that case was consistent with previous practice and in actual fact was cheaper than some other alternatives that were available. That is not a point that Senator Faulkner has been prepared to recognise. So there is really, I do not think, much more that can be added to that matter. It was all in order. There is a difficulty, when you get to the top of the departmental line, as to who has the final approval when they are matters that concern you. That has been addressed and found to be in order in this instance.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. The Howard government has brought down its second budget, which will greatly assist the economy and provide substantial benefits to ordinary Australians. Will the minister inform the Senate of what measures announced today will provide increased assistance to young people facing real barriers to participating in employment, education and training?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Synon for that question. If any Australian who wants a job cannot get a job, that is a matter of concern to the government. With the high unemployment that we have at the moment, there are far too many people in that position. But it is of particular concern I think to all Australians when a young Australian who wants to get a job cannot get one. We all seem to have a softer spot for unemployed youth than for other Australians who perhaps have already had their first go.

ANSWER.PARA: Youth unemployment is one of the very real and enduring legacies of the Keating government. I do not deny for one minute that youth unemployment rates are higher because of the structural changes in the economy—such that the pool of jobs for low skilled and unskilled young people who unwisely, I think, chose to leave school as soon as they could is diminishing all the time. Consequently, we have an increased youth unemployment rate.

Nonetheless, I am pleased to inform the Senate that today we had the national launch of the job placement, employment and training program, which will fund over 90 agencies nationally to assist young people across Australia. This government is committed to working with young people. While we recognise the diverse achievements of young people in many of their endeavours and congratulate them for that, we also acknowledge the need to provide for young people that have not enjoyed anything like the same level of opportunity.

BREAK.PARA: There is still a section of young Australians within our community that needs special assistance from the government. This government is aware of the circumstances that confront those young people and today has announced $11 million of direct assistance. We are absolutely committed in this task to working with community organisations that can provide services to young people that need assistance in our community. We are determined that each member of the community has a real chance to contribute to society and to reach their own full potential.

The service is funded under the JPET scheme. As I say, over 90 agencies will provide that sort of assistance to over 8,000 young Australians. The JPET program provides services to ensure that young Australians with special needs overcome the barriers to their participation in employment, education or training. The young people who will be helped by this sort of service around Australia are or have been wards of the state and some have been involved with the law. They might be students, young refugees or ex-offenders. So JPET will offer ongoing support and referral services to those under 21 and especially for those 15‐ to 19‐year‐olds who have significant problems.

Once those underlying problems are managed effectively, participants in the program will then be assisted in their efforts to gain access to education, entry level training or employment and in particular will be supported to maintain their participation in those activities. Funding of $11 million per annum for the next two years is available to assist young Australians who are homeless or at risk of becoming so. I am very pleased that over 8,000 young people will receive support from JPET in the next year and will help these young people realise their full potential.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. I refer the minister to recent reports that a former staffer of Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Mr Tony Abbott, was in regular contact with the member for Oxley prior to his defection to her staff and throughout the period that he was employed by Mr Abbott. Given that the Liberal Party has investigated his mobile phone use during this period, and that the Liberal Party has acknowledged that moves are afoot to investigate his use of a departmental laptop computer, do you intend to conduct any investigations of Mr Oldfield's activities whilst he was employed by Mr Abbott? Minister, are you concerned that Mr Oldfield may have obtained confidential information in his capacity as a staffer that could now be misused in his new job? Are you concerned that Mr Oldfield may have misused departmental resources whilst he was employed by Mr Abbott?

—Thank you, Senator Bishop, for the question. I have some advice here from the Minister for Administrative Services concerning the investigation into allegations of improper use of office facilities and staff entitlements by David Oldfield. The minister advises that the department will provide any assistance to the Hon. Tony Abbott in respect of records held by it. Should the Department of Administrative Services identify any non‐official use of equipment or services, appropriate action will be taken to seek reimbursement. I do not think there is anything more I can add.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the government broaden its inquiry to see whether any other ministerial staffers have been involved in contact with the One Nation Party? Has the government issued instructions to its staff about such contact and what is the nature of such instructions?

—I do not think you listened carefully to my answer, Senator Bishop. I think what you did was, you had something prepared which did not relate to the answer I gave, and you hopped to your feet. What I said—and it was not what you inferred—was that `the department will provide any assistance to the Hon. Tony Abbott in respect of records held by it.'
—Yes, we heard.
—That is what I said. Then I went on to say:

BREAK.PARA: Should the Department . . . identify any non‐official use of equipment or services, appropriate action will be taken to seek reimbursement.

That is what I said, Senator. The views of this side of the parliament towards the One Nation Party are extremely well known and Mr Howard, the Prime Minister, has made some very strong comments on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's Gallery of a delegation from the Diet of Japan. I trust that your visit to this country will be both informative and enjoyable.
—Hear, hear!

—My question is addressed to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, for many years the coalition, out of deference to its big business backers, has turned a deaf ear to the pleas from small business for protection in the Trade Practices Act against unfair trading practices. Was it not the case that the best you would do for small business was to promise an inquiry after the 1996 election in this matter? Is it not the case that the inquiry's report tabled today, a report of your own backbenchers, amongst others, has concluded that `concerns about unfair business conduct towards small business are justified and should be addressed urgently'? What urgent action will you be taking to provide small business with protection against unfair business conduct by big business, protection which should have been delivered years ago; or will you need another round of open‐ended consultations with your big business backers first, denying small business action on their most pressing concern?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you again, Senator Murray, for your question. Senator Murray, you do take an interest in the issues of small business, which my colleague Senator Parer has noted from time to time. I have to say, the implications in your question are unnecessary and unwarranted. I notice you mention that a report has been brought down. Obvi ously, the government will closely consider the recommendations in the report and, at an appropriate time, the government will make its views known on that. Senator, you mentioned your concern for small business. I wonder whether, in your supplementary question, you will be able to indicate to us whether you will be supporting the government in relation to its recent announcement on unfair dismissals in small business.
—That would be out of order Minister; you can't do that; you can't make a speech.

—No; the question involved help for small business and, in the spirit of proper debate and with Senator Murray's alleged concern for small business, I would be very interested in his response to that issue. There is a whole range of things this government has done for small business. There is the range of measures which were announced in our response to the Bell report. We have done various things like reduce the provisional tax uplift factor; provide special exemptions for CGT rollovers; and improve the FBT reporting arrangements which were very complex. So there is a whole range of measures which we have brought down to assist small business.

ANSWER.PARA: This government is the party of small business, Senator. Rather than being lectured by you about small business, what we want is your assistance on some real help to assist small business. That is the assurance that we are looking for from the Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question but, by the way, Minister, I would appreciate it if you did not refer to `deaf ears'. I am sure you did not mean anything by it, but there are people who are offended by it. Is it not the case that this government is only interested in small business reforms that do not upset big business? That was my question earlier. You are quite prepared to strip 1.3 million workers of legal protection against unfair dismissal law to fix a non‐existent problem with your own unfair dismissal laws to appear to be helping small business, but when it comes to taking on the banks, Coles Myer, shopping centre owners and the oil companies, where are you? Is it the case that you will go to water? Will indefinite delay be the order of the day? In other words, be precise: within what time frame will we see the amendments to the Trade Practices Act recommended by your committee today—amendments the committee and small business say are urgently needed—and brought forward as legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, Senator, you range far and wide, and you make a whole host of allegations. I think small business will be absolutely fascinated to hear that you do not believe that the unfair dismissal laws are a particular problem in relation to small business. I would be fascinated to hear you wipe that, Senator. It rather suggests your concern for small business is highly selective.

ANSWER.PARA: This government has instituted a vast range of measures—tax measures, record‐keeping measures—to assist small business. You mentioned the banks. In response to an earlier question from this side, I thought there were some rather strong words put forward in relation to the problems we are having with the banks in making sure that the full cut in interest rates is passed on. We play it straight, Senator, and I hope that the Australian Democrats will too.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. I refer you to the Treasurer's press release of 14 February, in which Mr Costello stated in regard to the infrastructure borrowings tax concession that, in an examination of existing applications, `schemes being proposed are exploiting the concession for tax minimisation purposes'. Are you aware that, according to Mr Roy Alper, the director of National Power, if the government had not terminated the infrastructure borrowing scheme on 14 February, the Redbank power project would have commenced today, leading to an estimated 1,000 jobs in the Hunter region? How does this application, which will create 1,000 jobs, constitute a tax minimisation scheme?

—There was an inquiry this morning, which you referred to, and I am sorry that you were not up here to hear the responses which were given. There were, in relation to infrastructure schemes, some very real problems that emerged which led to the Treasurer making the press statement on 14 February. The test for the Labor Party will be just how it will come down and support the government in relation to its moves there.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, given that your government and your industry minister have done nothing to protect the jobs of steelworkers in the Hunter region, why will you not show a bit of leadership and intervene to ensure that this important project, with all its benefits for the Hunter Valley, can proceed as planned?

—I have to say that I have now heard absolutely everything: the Labor Party complaining about employment! It was under your government, Senator, that unemployment—not only amongst people formerly in the steelworks but across the whole economy—reached record levels. You are the high unemployment party, and don't you get up there and lecture to this government, which has to deal with the mess that you left.

—My question is to Senator Alston, the minister for communications. Minister, I refer to the Mansfield report on the future role and functions of the ABC. To what extent has the development of the federal government's response to such critical issues as the ABC's relevance in the 21st century been influenced by the submissions—particularly that of the ALP—to the Mansfield review?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very good question indeed, because what we announced in the budget was a precise delivery of the promise we made back in July last year. We have given the ABC half a billion dollars—just over $500 million dollars—and we have made a number of other very important refinements, for which the ABC will, I am sure, be very grateful.

ANSWER.PARA: But the people of Australia are entitled to an explanation not just about the outcome but about the inputs, because it is very significant that at the next election they will have to make a choice between the competing parties and the views that they express.

TALK.START.PARA: —We won't be destroying the ABC like you are.

—Madam President, you might recall that back in August last year Senator Schacht was very keen to tell us that he had put in a submission on behalf of the ALP. In order to get hold of that submission—which of course was nine months ago—Senator Coonan had to put in three separate letters pleading with Senator Schacht to let that document see the light of day. What he finally did on 30 April was to say that he was prepared to hand it over—to come clean. He said that he had had wide‐ranging discussions with Mr Mansfield, and he had been told—presumably he had asked—to simply outline the Labor Party's broad policy position.

ANSWER.PARA: What we then got was a letter. The first thing was a letter dated 30 August. This is what Senator Schacht said:

I understand the official closing date for submissions is today. As you will be aware, I have been very busy with some Senate references committees. My submission will be sent to you within a fortnight. If you want any more information, give my office a call.
Seven weeks later, what did we get? We got a document which can charitably be described as a submission, outlining the ALP's broad policy position.

Firstly, it starts off by saying, `The opposition opposes the inquiry's terms of reference and, therefore, we do not believe it is necessary to make a detailed submission.' So what was the point of all that? Why did you go on about seeking special leave to put in a document six or seven weeks down the track? Then you say it would be very difficult for the opposition to support recommendations produced by the inquiry, unless you turn a blind eye to the terms of reference. That is all very helpful to Mr Mansfield. Quite clearly you were not prepared to await the outcome, to make a judgment on the merits of what he recommended. You are simply saying, `In advance, we cannot support anything.'

I have to say, in passing, the strangulation of the English language is absolutely excruci ating. To say it is `dubious' as to whether the inquiry can make any reasonable recommendations, to say that some of the programs are `quintessential' in their reflection of Australian culture, and then to end up saying, `I accept without prejudice your invitation to have further discussions'—what on earth does that mean? Clearly, mindless regurgitation of legalities.

What it really means is, `I can't tell you. I don't want you to tell anyone either, because I really don't have any views on the ABC.' I would have thought we should all be very grateful indeed that none of this saw the light of day before the recent shadow cabinet massacre, because, clearly, Senator Schacht was much more interested in going off to Japan—trotting out his industry policy to shore up his preselection—than addressing any of the real issues.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Well if you are being rolled by the Bolkus left faction, all I can say is there will be no‐one left in South Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that there is nothing in this document that tells you anything about not only the ALP's view on the ABC, but no‐one's view. There are a few mindless inanities, a bit of trite rhetoric about believing that the ABC should continue to play a role as a public broadcaster. We get a bit of scare campaigning about regional stations—`We don't want to see them closing down; we want to see the importance of independent news and current affairs.' There is nothing about whether you support changes to the charter. I presume you will in due course. It is an absolute disgrace—2½ pages of mindless rhetoric, not in any shape or form addressing the policy issues, and it will be judged accordingly. (Time expired)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Transport and Regional Development

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. Did the minister for Transport and Regional Development, travelling as a passenger, directly access air traffic control at Sydney airport by a mobile telephone from on‐board the aircraft in an attempt to jump a 14‐plane landing queue at Sydney airport—a slot system which the minister himself is responsible for administering? Did the minister, during that telephone conversation with the controller, identify himself by name and ask on three separate occasions whether something could be done to prioritise the landing slot that had been allocated to his aircraft at Sydney airport?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —The general answer to most of that question is no.
—No?

—But it probably deserves a more detailed explanation than Senator Collins has clearly been able to get his mind around from a newspaper report. I can confirm that Mr Sharp was a passenger on a chartered light aircraft—not a jet as reported in today's Sydney Morning Herald —on a flight between Goulburn and Sydney on 17 May last. After take‐off from Goulburn, they were advised by air traffic control of a delay to the intended arrival time. Mr Sharp did make use of an 1‐800 free call telephone number published by Airservices Australia, which allows people with particular concerns about landing times to make inquiries about traffic conditions and traffic sequences.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not aware of that? Is that right? Okay. Well, the fact is that this is a right that is available to every other pilot or person nominated by the pilot of an aircraft. Mr Sharp simply determined whether to persevere with the delay in getting into Mascot or whether it made more sense to divert to Bankstown. He made inquiries which, I recall reading in this morning's paper, were not categorised in any shape or form as an attempt to apply pressure. They were simply inquiries that any other reasonable person who had some concern about whether the planes fly on time and arrive on time would have made.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand why you cannot be bothered finding out whether a plane is going to arrive on time, because you know that basically you are responsible for the mess in the first place. You simply folded your hands for years on end and were not prepared to do anything about it. All that Mr Sharp is doing is taking advantage of about all that is left to those who suffer the ongoing frustrations of regular air users. Mr Sharp is perfectly entitled, as he did on this occasion, to make inquiries. He did no more than any other pilot does when facing delays in getting into Sydney. I know and Mr Sharp knows that Senator Collins and his ilk do not want in any shape or form to know the true facts of the matter, but I have outlined them and I think they speak for themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question in response to that fascinating answer that the minister gave. Minister, are you aware that the 1‐800 number that you just talked about that can in fact be accessed by any person in Australia, when it is accessed by any person in Australia other than a pilot, puts you through to the switchboard at CASA here in Canberra? Are you aware that, if a pilot wishes to access air traffic control to talk to the controller, he has to prefix that 1‐800 number with a PIN number provided to pilots only? Did the minister use a pilot's prefix in front of the 1‐800 call?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —It is extraordinary, isn't it? We now all know why Senator Collins got comprehensively dumped from the front bench. If ever a bloke had no interest at all in his nominal portfolio responsibilities—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —He is a local member now.
—Order! Senators on my left should notice that their leader is on his feet.

—Thank you, Madam President. My point of order is one of relevance. It is a very direct supplementary question that Senator Collins has asked. Interesting though the other matters may be that Senator Alston has been canvassing, I ask you, Madam President, given that it is a supplementary question, to direct the minister to answer the question that Senator Collins asked.
—The minister clearly was giving a little more information than was asked in the question, but I am sure you should have in mind the actual question asked, Minister.

—The short answer is that I do not know whether there were PIN numbers involved or any other of those mindless technical details that you seem to be absorbed with, to the detriment of the interests of your constituents—to those sitting behind you who expect you to reflect on issues that you have been given responsibility for. This is another example of an obsession. The bottom line in this is whether or not Mr Sharp acted in any improper manner and the short answer is that he did not. He simply took action that is available to any other person. He was quite properly anxious to know just how much longer he would have wait as a result of your policies.(Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Minister, I understand that the Queensland cabinet has agreed with South Australia to sign a heads of agreement on joint arrangements for the future management of the Lake Eyre Basin. Can the Minister please inform the Senate of what arrangements are being made to conserve the natural heritage of this major region in Australia, and what role the Commonwealth is playing in these arrangements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Ferguson for that important question. Yes, the Queensland and the South Australian governments have signed this historic heads of agreement, and the Commonwealth government will be signing in support of both state governments. This approach to land management contrasts starkly with the previous approach of Labor, and it demonstrates what can be achieved through a cooperative approach.

ANSWER.PARA: What is important is that the Lake Eyre Basin—which is one of the great unregulated catchments of the world really, which has priceless assets of international ecological significance and also vitally important economic assets—is now to be managed in a cooperative way by these two states, with the support of the Commonwealth, to ensure the sustainability of both the economic and environmental assets. That is vitally important, and it shows that finally in this country we are learning from the mistakes of the past.

We now recognise, for example, what we did wrong with the Murray-Darling Basin. We now recognise that it is important to get the science right, to get in place a cooperative arrangement between all relevant parties and then to implement such arrangements to preserve these assets before it is too late. We recognise that, to maintain the economic advantages of a basin such as this, it is important to protect the natural systems as well.

In this instance, it is important to protect the continued health of river systems such as the Thomson, the Barcoo, the Cooper, the Georgina and the Diamantina, which encompass the states of Queensland and South Australia. That is why a cooperative mechanism, in which particularly the upstream state is prepared to cooperate with the downstream state, is vitally important. Senator Ferguson, this will be good news for our constituents in South Australia.

What the state governments have agreed to is that they will enter into a cooperative agreement for the purposes of establishing arrangements for the integrated catchment management and water resources management of the Lake Eyre Basin, something that is long overdue. In doing so, they will adopt management plans or policies for flow management regimes that reflect current near natural variable flows of the river systems. That is great news, Senator Ferguson. In other words, a regime that will protect near natural flows of the river system really does show that we are learning from past experiences.

The agreement will put in place policies for objectives for land and water management in the basin, including water quality objectives and river flow objectives. We are talking about both the quality and the quantity of the water flow into South Australia. It will put in place policies that will provide for catchment management strategies to ensure that, as far as practicable, those objectives are met—including the promotion of community action to achieve the objectives for land and water management identified under the agreement or management plan or policy—and processes for dealing with current usage of water for domestic and stock watering requirements and processes for dealing with significant water related development proposals for the basin.

It is a first. Before the damage is done, in this instance two states—Queensland and South Australia—have got together and said, `Let's put into place cooperative policies which will ensure both the quality and quantity of flows within the river system and therefore ensure, in the long term, the sustainability of the great Lake Eyre Basin, sustainability both for its economic assets and for its environmental assets.

I say on behalf of the Commonwealth government that we are pleased to be a part of this initiative. We are pleased to sign it. We look forward to supporting those two states as the plan is implemented in the months ahead.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the minister further explain the circumstances that gave rise to this significant agreement when the most recent history of environmental issues in the Lake Eyre Basin has been marked by controversy and distrust?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —It is simply a different approach of government. Our approach is to work cooperatively with stakeholders.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—In this instance it is to work cooperatively with the state governments, with the pastoralists and with other users within Queensland.

ANSWER.PARA: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The level of noise is far too high.

—I understand the embarrassment on the side of Labor because their approach was a regulatory approach—try to enforce an outcome. They wonder why it got so many stakeholders offside, and they did not get the outcome they wanted in the end in any event. This is a different approach. It is demonstrated through the Natural Heritage Trust philosophy—an approach through cooperation to achieve a better outcome. (Time expired)
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—Pursuant to standing order 74(5), I ask the Minister representing the Attorney-General for an explanation as to why an answer has not been provided to question on notice No. 482, which I asked on 7 March 1997 and for which I advised you I needed an answer to in the last sitting week.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I do not have an answer for you, but I will get one this afternoon.
—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the explanation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Minister for Transport and Regional Development

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston), to a question without notice asked by Senator Bob Collins today, relating to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) and air traffic control at Sydney Airport.

I must say that the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston), surprised me with his answer today. The story that I based the question on was carried in today's Sydney Morning Herald . Therefore, I assumed that the minister would have a brief on it and that he would be prepared for it. I was therefore somewhat surprised to hear him suggest that the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) had done nothing more than what was available—to quote the minister in here today—to anyone else in Australia.

Does the minister representing the minister for transport seriously suggest, as he told the Senate today, that if anyone in Australia—I invite him to be one of them—rings the 1800 free call number, which he just referred to, that person would be connected with air traffic control at Sydney airport, which is what he told the Senate today would happen—because Mr Sharp had done nothing else than do what was available to any other person in Australia?

Is the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development in the Senate seriously suggesting that CASA would run a system enabling anyone inquiring about the arrival time of an aircraft at an airport to be connected to a senior controller at Sydney airport who in fact was responsible for allocating the slots at Sydney airport for the arrival of all the aircraft? The answer that the minister gave the Senate today was utter nonsense. I have to say I would be astonished if that information was given in the brief that surely would have been provided to the minister as a result of the publicity given to these allegations, but the minister did confirm that the call indeed was made.

You do not have to be too clever to work out just precisely what happened. It was in real terms the arrogance of office. It was this minister big‐noting himself in a way that I do not think does him any credit. Certainly, it does not do the government any credit—it is only 14 short months since the election—for the minister to get this big headed about being a federal minister in this government. The minister was flying into Sydney from Goulburn, which I think is his home airport. I understand that he was in fact flying on a chartered aircraft from a company that operates here in Canberra at Fyshwick, not on a jet, as reported in the story, but Senator Alston confirmed today the call was made from the aircraft on a mobile phone.
Senator Calvert interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not complaining about that, Senator, at all and I am not suggesting you cannot. I have done it myself on light aircraft, not on jets. But, as you would know, Senator, it is not possible on a commercial aircraft nor is it possible in the VIP fleet either. They observe the rule for safety reasons as stringently as commercial aircraft do because mobile phones, being unshielded as they are, have a potential to affect the navigational instruments on board modern‐day aircraft.

BREAK.PARA: That is not the thing I am complaining about at all. It is the absolute effrontery of the minister, who is responsible for administering the slot system at Sydney airport, a system which everyone else in Australia is expected to comply with, to try to get himself shoved up the line by big‐noting himself to a controller at Sydney airport and thereby abusing the position that he holds as a minister. That in fact is a substantive matter to raise here in the parliament, and I did not expect the nonsense we heard today.

Of course, the answer—and the reason this intrigues me—is that we know the minister did this, and Senator Alston has confirmed that. But the answers Senator Alston gave raise a whole lot of questions; they do not provide any answers. Did in fact the pilot of the aircraft attempt to get an upgrade of the slot into Sydney? Why was it a passenger on board his rcraft, no matter how self-important the passenger was, who tried to get this upgrade?

We know that transcripts of these conversations are available because they are taped, as honourable senators on the appropriate committees in here know full well. We know that a transcript would be available to us to prove whether the minister did in fact use the words attributed to him in the Sydney Morning Herald today, as I have no doubt he did. I challenge the minister, particularly this minister who gave such a silly answer today, to table the transcripts of the tapes that I know are held by air traffic control in Sydney so we will know beyond any doubt whatsoever what the minister said to the controller at Sydney airport. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —This demonstration of arrogance by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp), of course, is typical of a ministry that seems to think that when they get on a plane they can get preferential treatment. This is not the first occasion that we have had a situation like this.

SPEECH.PARA: Senators will recall in the early days of the new government the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan) arranging for an army helicopter to pick up his wife from a golf course to take her to a show. Senators will recall The Hon. Mrs Bishop being involved in an incident on an aircraft where the stewards of the plane complained about the pressure that was applied to them because the plane was going to be late getting into an airport.

Now what do we have? We have the minister who is in charge of transport, John Sharp, the minister who has actually implemented the system at Mascot airport that he and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) said was going to solve the problem of congestion at Sydney airport, trying to queue jump and, furthermore, doing it in a most extraordinary and, I would suggest, very improper way.

As Senator Bob Collins has pointed out, the minister has utilised a service which is designed to be there for pilots of aircraft to use, those who have a legitimate right to contact air traffic control with respect to landing times at any airport. But, no, we have a minister on a chartered aircraft, as it would appear, getting on the phone and, in effect, trying to take over the role of the pilot and putting pressure on air traffic control at Sydney to get in earlier.

This minister, I have to say, has been probably one of the most arrogant ministers in an arrogant ministry. For instance, you will recall this is the minister who wanted his own way so much with respect to appointments on the board of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority that he ran a public campaign denigrating the reputations of certain members of that authority and, at the same time, publicly supporting a particular candidate who now happens to have been appointed to CASA and who, many would argue, at least bears some responsibility for some of the pre-existing problems with respect to air safety in this country.

This is a minister who treats the protests of concerned citizens in my area of Sydney with absolute disdain. A month or two ago a deputation came to this parliament, comprising 10 local council shire mayors of Sydney, representing well over one million people. They came to this parliament to meet with the minister and other members of the government and the opposition to talk about the issue of the siting of Sydney's second airport. The minister refused to see them. The minister has consistently refused to see deputations from residents groups, shire council representatives and others on this issue of Sydney's second airport.

I want to point out to the Senate while I have the opportunity that again today and for the next two days in this parliament there are representatives of various citizens groups who are campaigning against the choice of Holsworthy airport. They will be in this parliament today, tomorrow and Wednesday. There is an open invitation to the minister and other members of the government to go and talk to those representatives and hear their concerns about the problems of Sydney's second airport and air traffic congestion and aircraft noise in Sydney. The minister should do that rather than ignoring their legitimate concerns. But when he happens to get himself caught in a position where he is a little bit inconvenienced by getting into Sydney late, what does he do? He quickly gets on the phone and tries to stand over air traffic control. I say to the minister that it is about time he changed this arrogant attitude that he has adopted and he should go and talk to those people who are now in Senate committee room 1S2.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Just a couple of weeks ago in this Senate a question was raised about 78 flights landing on the east-west runway when the cross‐winds were in excess of 15 kilometres an hour. The question of safety was raised. So, when Senator Alston in his answer today accuses everyone else of problems at Sydney airport, he had better look very closely at the problems generated by this government in a politically motivated decision to spread noise over Sydney. I would not be at all surprised that Mr Sharp's difficulty of getting into Sydney on this particular day was caused by the runway pattern that he himself has put out, mostly at the behest of Mr Howard, to stop planes flying over the Bennelong electorate and to spread and ease the noise around Sydney, irrespective of whether it hits safety.

SPEECH.PARA: As I think Senator Collins has pointed out, there is nothing wrong with Mr Sharp taking a charter flight from Goulburn to Sydney, although I will say that the degree to which National Party ministers are using charter flights out of Canberra to go home on Friday nights when the rest of us trudge out to the airport is quite startling. That particular provision was never intended for National Party ministers to whip out to the airport after a parliamentary session. I do not know whether your brother takes you; oh, there is no airport at South Yarra, is there, Senator McGauran?

Ministers pick up a plane as a taxi out of Canberra airport to go down to Gippsland and up to Mr Anderson's electorate and those of Mr Sharp and Mr Fischer. They all do it. That was not really the intention of charter aircraft. They were to get you from spot A to spot B on ministerial duty, not home quickly at night. However, if it can be shown over time that this is a cheaper method than, for example, Mr McGauran flying to Melbourne and getting a Comcar down to Traralgon or wherever he lives—I do not want to identify where he lives but I think he lives down that way—that might be fine too.

What we have in this situation is Mr Sharp getting on his charter aircraft and he is so self‐important that he does not want to be held up going into Sydney airport. The battlers can though. They can sit up there and fly round and round in circles, as long as this bloke gets priority and gets in. I know he is a busy minister. He is so busy restructuring the Airservices board and assassinating its members in public that he probably had to get to Sydney in a hurry. But no-one in Australia likes queue jumpers. Trying to jump 14 slots ahead is not a particularly politic thing to do.

Senator Collins is absolutely right. Not all Australians have the right to ring the air traffic controllers in Sydney. What we do not know is that if he did access the 008 number, how come he got put through to the air traffic controllers? If he did, did he have to use a special pin number that the pilot gave him? If it was only a moderate friendly little inquiry from the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, who pays their salary, maybe it is only an impolitic thing to have done. We will be able to find out because the transcripts will be there.

If Mr Sharp wants to hold his ground and say he did absolutely nothing wrong at all, let us release the transcripts. There will certainly not be any commercial-in-confidence aspects or any legal matters to do with it. There cannot be. Let the transcripts come out, let them be put down and we will make a judgment on whether this was a concerned citizen innocently ringing to find out when he was getting into Sydney or whether it was a self‐important minister trying to queue jump 14 slots to get in, based on an airport design that had political connotations in its very existence.

I am also concerned, even though the instrumentation on light aircraft is different, that he was using a mobile phone. There are two things here: there is a safety aspect, which we would not like to highlight because it is less likely to occur in a light plane than a jet; but also all the telecommunications companies have objections to mobile phones being used in the air. I think the reason for that—I am not a technical person—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are just preserving their bailiwick.

—As you would acknowledge, Senator MacGibbon, it is just the case that they jump over the cells so quick, you cannot be charged. So it is probably not a safety issue; it is a telecommunications issue. I want to know whether Mr Sharp was actually billed for the call or whether the plane was going quick enough so that he got a real free call. But then it was an 008 number, so we are getting into very complex territory here. What it comes back to is simply a very arrogant minister on all appearances. The only way you will be able to disprove that in my view is by publishing the transcripts so we can all have a read. And if it is not Mr Modest Sharp, we will drop the issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert, Sen Paul

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it unusual with all the questions that were asked today that we have to come in here and listen to a series of allegations.
—About ministers abusing their office.

—That is all they are—allegations. Given the record of your government about these sorts of things, about which you would know—using charter aircraft to go and open dog shows and when you got there the dog show had finished—
—You were making it a relevant thing three years ago.

—I do not condone any of that at all. But the fact of the matter is that you are saying things here today about Sydney airport. I know it is a favourite subject of Senator Forshaw, but Senator Ferguson and I just happen to have had two days up there last week.
—Up where?

—At Sydney airport. We were listening to evidence from the Lane Cove action group, from people from Leichhardt, Barry Cotter from Marrickville—who gave us a very good dissertation on what is going on—and the No Aircraft Noise Party. In fact, we asked questions about what has happened. I observed at first hand that after about 11 o'clock the whole operation switched to the east-west runway and continued that way until about 3 o'clock in the afternoon. I asked some of the people who were giving evidence, and who were obviously biased against aircraft noise, if this sharing of the noise had made any difference and they said, yes, it had.

SPEECH.PARA: But, for the information of honourable senators who are very concerned about aircraft noise at Sydney airport, the thing that interested me was that the noise remediation program that was instigated by the former government and continued by this government seems to be working quite well. In fact, we met one particular person who chose to buy a house in the flight path at Sydenham about four years ago, and he has done very nicely. By his own admission, he has had a capital gain of $60,000 on his home.

I was going to raise the particular matter, which people here today have been talking about, of so-called slot times. I might be wrong but, in evidence given to us at the aircraft noise hearing the other day, we were told that one of the things that Sydney airport and the FAC were looking at and going to use to reduce the noise were slot times; they were going to introduce slot times so that aircraft can do as they do at Heathrow airport from—

TALK.START.PARA: —I bet you've never jumped a queue. I bet you never have.
—No.
—No! Absolutely, you wouldn't.
—I would not know how to use a mobile phone, for a start.
—That'd be right. And they made you whip!
—I've heard that Tasmanian senators don't know how to use mobile phones.
—Order on my left! Senator Calvert, would you direct your response through the chair.

—I just thought that those honourable senators opposite might be interested to know that there were moves afoot to introduce slot times at Sydney airport in an attempt to reduce the noise, as happens at Heathrow airport with a parallel runway system. One of the Qantas pilots told me once why it happens in Sydney the way it does. A lot of the noise is caused by the fact that they do not get a glide path far enough out and they cannot glide in.
—When were you at Heathrow?
—This particular aircraft pilot was telling me that when you fly into Heathrow airport you can come in from 15 miles out.
—Is this in defence of the minister?
—I am just trying to give you some information on how this government is trying to alleviate noise at Sydney airport. As Senator Collins would know—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Bob Collins interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, don't I get any protection from the chair at all?
—No!
—Order! Senator Carr!

—Here I am trying to give some very important information to the opposition, who do not seem to know anything about aircraft or airports. Senator Collins should know that in a charter aircraft you can use a mobile phone. Obviously Mr Sharp was doing that. The rest of what we have heard today are only allegations. Surely to goodness, until we have further proof, it was a waste of half an hour of government business time today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran, Sen Julian

TALK.START.PARA: —I also have been provoked to join this debate. I will be brief, because I want to hand over to my—
—Tell us about South Yarra.

—parliamentary leader, Senator Boswell, to defend Mr Sharp, the good minister for transport, and a National Party colleague. It is not for me as a Victorian to venture into the great debate of the Sydney airport and all the debacles that have followed it over the last 10 years. But Senator Ray got up in here and talked about political bias because this government opened the third runway. Well, I would have thought that is why you built three runways—to open it up and maximise your ability to land.

SPEECH.PARA: But for him to talk about this minister opening up the third runway to gain some sort of political advantage for the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in his seat of Bennelong is absolute nonsense when we all know that it was the previous minister, Laurie Brereton, whose absolute motivation was to shut down one complete runway so that it would not go over his particular electorate. Coming from Victoria, I know that much: you built a third runway and then shut one down.

I will offer some advice to the minister. Given the queues at Sydney airport and the debacle that has followed over the past 10 years because of previous policies, it is probably timely for me to mention that that sort of delay would not happen in Victoria, currently. If he were to land at the Essendon airport, he would get an instant result. There are no queues at the Essendon airport, being as efficient as it is. It is Melbourne's second airport and it should remain so and remain open. I just offer that timely advice to the minister: these sorts of delays and frustrations just do not occur in Victoria, because of our good airport system and the two that are in the inner city.

In a week when we have had good economic news, namely the lowering of interest rates, in today's question time there was not one single question from the opposition on the economy—not one single question. What we have had are all these lightweight issues today, such as the minister chartering into Sydney airport. We have had a question on a political adviser to Tony Abbott, for heaven's sake, and what he could take out of the office, and also several questions from the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Faulkner) on the position of the Prime Minister's senior Public Service adviser, Mr Max Moore-Wilton—none of them relevant. None of them are relevant to the everyday lives of Australians. I accept that they are probably trying to build up some sort of political perception, some sort of flawed political perception.

But the fact of the matter is that, in a week that we have had good economic news in this economy, the opposition is attempting to distract the government and the Australian people—and the media no doubt—to focus on these shallow pathetic issues that do not go to the heart of government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a contribution on this matter because I think that what the opposition are trying to do is build a mountain out of a molehill over this; and that is their role—to attack. They have to exploit every opportunity they have, but this one is fairly hollow because Mr Don Brown, chief of the air controllers, said that there was no impropriety at all in the matter. What Mr Sharp has obviously done is rung up because he has been late for an appointment; but there has been no pressure put on the air controllers in any way. He rang up and made a request—and that was for a better slot. That was rejected by the air controller and there was no pressure at all put on that air controller. Mr Sharp accepted that he would have to get in the queue like everyone else.

SPEECH.PARA: To put paid to that matter, the chief of the air controllers, Mr Don Brown, said, `There is absolutely no impropriety; there is nothing to investigate.' But, of course, the opposition, after a week of interest rates going down and small business getting on top, has got to go in and exploit an opportunity. Everyone knows that is what an opposition is expected to do—and you have done it. But do not try to go over the top—you are going right over the top on these issues. It is clear that the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, Mr Sharp, has committed no impropriety. If there were anything there, Mr Brown would have made some note or certainly would not have come out and given him a clean bill of health. Not a bad try—three out of 10—and just wait—

TALK.START.PARA: —And nothing out of 10 for the response.
—Three out of 10 for you guys—and you certainly have not kicked a goal on this one.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to join this important debate. Senator Boswell talks about mountains out of molehills. The only molehill that Senator Boswell is interested in is, of course, the failing leadership of Mr Tim Fischer. The reason that Senator Boswell comes into the chamber behind Senator Calvert and behind Senator McGauran is to support his candidate for the leadership of the National Party—Mr Sharp. Mr Sharp is Senator Boswell's boy. It is Mr Sharp whom Senator Boswell wants to make Leader of the National Party in Australia.

BREAK.PARA: We have these sorts of parliamentary contributions from the government whip, a government whip who says he does not know how to use a mobile phone—and I understand, on very good authority from the opposition whip, he cannot count either. We also have a contribution from poor old Senator McGauran, whose brother is over there in the House of Representatives. His brother is also trying to angle in on Tim Fischer's leadership; he is also in the hunt, but he has not got Senator Boswell's support, Senator McGauran. He may have your support, but he certainly has not got Senator Boswell's support. Poor old Senator McGauran comes in and makes a contribution to the debate, talking about Mr Sharp landing at Essendon Airport—but that is in a different state. You need a geography lesson, Senator McGauran —you really do.

What this issue is about is Mr Sharp, the putative leader of the National Party and Deputy Prime Minister of Australia, misusing and abusing his ministerial responsibility. That is what it is about: misusing his office and trying to queue jump; getting in a light plane and finding out that there are 14 other planes in front in—

TALK.START.PARA: —Probably a jet aircraft.

—Maybe jet aircraft, maybe international flights, maybe domestic flights; but 14 aircraft in front of him and all, according to Mr Sharp, having to stand back and let him and his light aircraft go into Sydney first.
—Sharp practice.
—Probably. Probably the pilot of Mr Sharp's plane objected—
—You'd hope so.
—You would hope so. Probably the pilot said, `Oh, well, mate, handle it yourself,' which is what Mr Sharp did. Mr Sharp got on the mobile phone and—
—This is only a Cessna.

—Mr Sharp probably thought he was in some sort of fighter plane at the time. Really and truly! Mr Sharp gets on the mobile phone at the back of the plane and rings 1800. It may have gone through to the CASA switch because, if you are not a pilot, that is where you are supposed to go through; or he may have even used the pilot's pin number. We will find that out, too, when we get the transcript, I hope.

BREAK.PARA: This is about abuse of office—and no attempt on your part, Senator Boswell, or on the part of any of your other cronies in the National Party will be able to sweep that under the carpet. This is a minister who wants one rule for him flying into Sydney airport while all other Australians—everyone else who uses the place—has to wait in line, wait in the queue and take his turn. There is one rule for a minister in the Howard government and another rule for all other Australians. It is not on; you stand exposed, and Mr Sharp has an awful lot of explaining to do to get out of this one.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate, on behalf of the President, of the death on Wednesday, 21 May 1997 of the Hon. Sir William John Aston KCMG, member of the House of Representatives for the division of Phillip, New South Wales, from 1955 to 1961 and from 1963 to 1972, and Speaker of the House of Representatives from 1967 to 1972.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on Wednesday, 21 May 1997, of the Honourable Sir William John Aston KCMG, Member of the House of Representatives for the Division of Phillip, New South Wales, from 1955 to 1961 and from 1963 to 1972, Deputy Government Whip from 1959 to 1961 and 1963 to 1964, Government Whip from 1964 to 1967 and Speaker of the House of Representatives from 1967 to 1972, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service, and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

Sir William was born on 19 September 1916 in Sydney. His service to the nation began during World War II when he enlisted in the Citizen Military Forces and soon transferred to the 2nd Australian Imperial Force. He served in New Guinea and rose from gunner to the rank of lieutenant with the 82nd Australian Mobile Searchlight Battery. Even before entering federal parliament, he had given active and successful service in local politics. He was an alderman of the Waverley Municipal Council from 1949 to 1953 and served as mayor from 1952 to 1953.

He became a member of the House of Representatives in 1955, winning the seat of Phillip for the Liberal Party. He held the seat until 1961 and then again from 1963 to 1972. His maiden speech characterised his concern for the issues facing Australia in the Cold War era and the difficulties confronting the wheat and wool industries. He also spoke of the need for the government of the day to communicate and explain its policies to the people and the need for streamlining the country's industrial relations system: issues which are, perhaps not surprisingly, equally pertinent and important today.

During his 15 years in the parliament Sir William contributed extensively to the work of a range of parliamentary committees. He was, as I said, elected as Speaker of the House of Representatives in February 1967. The six years that he occupied the Speaker's chair saw some colourful episodes and turbulent debates in the House which tested his mettle and his impressive parliamentary and political skills.

His public service was recognised both overseas and at home. In 1969 he was awarded the Korea Order of Distinguished Service Merit 1st Class for his contribution to the promotion of friendly relations between the Republic of Korea and the Commonwealth of Australia. In 1970 he was appointed a Knight Commander of the Most Distinguished Order of St Michael and St George.

Sir William's passing will be mourned by all those who knew him. On behalf of the government I extend to his wife, Lady Betty Aston, and his daughters Margaret and Anne, son‐in‐law Edward, and grandchildren William, Elizabeth and Catherine, our most sincere sympathy in their bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the opposition, I support the condolence motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate on the death of the Hon. Sir William Aston who, of course, had distinguished service in this parliament, most particularly as Speaker of the House of Representatives. Labor senators join with senators from all sides of the chamber in expressing regret at his death and offering our sincere condolences to his family.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is proper to say that Bill Aston served his country well, both in peace and war. He fought in World War II, enlisting firstly in the CMF in March 1942 and transferring to the 2nd AIF in July of that same year. During the course of the war he rose from the rank of gunner to the rank of lieutenant.

He had a long and, I think it is fair to say, turbulent parliamentary career, being first elected to the House of Representatives in 1955. He won the seat of Phillip from Joe Fitzgerald, a great Labor stalwart who had won the seat of Phillip when it was created in the 1949 redistribution. Bill Aston won Phillip again in 1958 but in the election of 1961, where Labor clawed back many seats, he was defeated along with 15 other Liberal members.

New South Wales electoral folklore has always been characterised by really tough, knock‐down, drag‐out, hard fought contests in the seat of Phillip. Having been defeated in 1961, Bill Aston was successful in the 1963 election until he was defeated in 1972 by Joe Riordan, who went on to become a minister in the Whitlam government. The 1969 result was a classic example. Bill Aston won the seat in 1969 by 221 votes. Of course, there was much muttering from the Labor Party afterwards about possible Court of Disputed Returns appeals and the like. But that really did characterise what occurred in Phillip right through until the seat was recently abolished.

During his time in the parliament, Bill Aston was a member of many committees, including the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs. He also served as Deputy Government Whip from 1959 to 1961 and 1963 to 1964, and then as Government Whip from 1964 to 1967. But it was as Speaker of the House of Representatives that Bill Aston's service to this parliament was most notable. He held that position of Speaker from 1967 until the defeat of the McMahon government in 1972. It was a long parliamentary career for Bill Aston in a tough inner metropolitan electorate in Sydney that was famous for its close fought struggles.

Bill Aston was noted also for the nature of many of his parliamentary contributions. He was noteworthy, I think, for many of the rulings he made as Speaker of the House of Representatives. Not all times were these rulings accepted with good grace by the then opposition, the Labor Party, but I think on both sides of the parliament and certainly in the Labor Party we acknowledge the significance of the parliamentary contribution that Bill Aston made. On behalf of the opposition, we offer our sincere sympathy to his family and his friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)
