. . . the intent of the changes should be to achieve the dual objectives of facilitating an expanding, competitive minerals sector while containing the expenditure growth flowing from widening eligibility beyond the intent of the Scheme.

The changes were announced on 31 October and both Senator Parer and Mr Prosser made much about the extensive consultations that had taken place. Yet, even following that, the Minerals Council of Australia still have some concerns. Mr Ellis, on behalf of the Minerals Council, stated:

. . . the legislation and the comments made by the minister in his Second Reading Speech appear to go beyond that agreement. They do not provide the certainty integral to our agreement. Following a detailed analysis of the legislation, the Council will be seeking the Government's cooperation to rectify the apparent unintended consequences . . .

It still comes back to the point that there is no clear definition of what is intended to be achieved from the diesel fuel rebate scheme. There is a broad recognition that it is there to assist industries and create a level playing field. Even when you look at some other countries where diesel fuel, as an input into producing goods, is significantly cheaper than it is here in Australia, there is still this problem.

Of course, we have not heard the government dispel the speculation that there may well be a cap placed on the diesel fuel rebate scheme, which would create total uncertainty. It is a ridiculous situation. I do not know how you would work it; maybe you can explain that, Minister. If you have a cap and you get all of the claims in, what percentage of the claim will be paid, to whom and on what basis? There is nothing worse, in so far as our mining industry and our agricultural industry are concerned, than having those sorts of uncertainties hanging over them.

What is of particular concern to me is the issue that relates to the cement industry. I guess I am referring to the cement industry in my own state because it has a significant investment in Tasmania, both in terms of infrastructure and employment. In 1993 Australian Cement Holdings, which is Goliath Portland Cement at Railton, completed the bulk of its site upgrade—a capital expenditure on site which is ongoing. At the completion, in excess of $100 million will have been spent. In addition, a $50 million ship was purchased in the same year for the specific purpose of transporting cement products to mainland markets.

A major investment is also taking place in the form of a new limestone mine. This development involves some 100 trucks operating at any one time and, consequently, their diesel fuel usage is quite significant. Some 200 people are employed directly at Goliath and the flow‐on employment effect is substantial. Shaw Contracting, a Tasmanian based company which is employed by the company, has as many as 100 vehicles on site at any one time. In Tasmania, Australian Cement Holdings owns Besser and Cornwall. In all they employ somewhere in the vicinity of 350 people.

Since June 1995, Goliath Portland Cement has not received the diesel fuel rebate, despite the fact that one company within the Australian cement group is receiving the rebate. This government has been claiming that the very reason they are not receiving the rebate is because, in 1995, we removed it.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's true.

—Senator Parer says that is true but it is not so. It is true that we did tighten up the eligibility but it was always the intention that the amended legislation would continue to provide a rebate for diesel fuel used for the purpose of mining calcite, or calcium, from limestone for the production of cement. That is even supported in a letter from Mr Prosser, the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs. Firstly, just to dispel this myth that you people keep trying to push about, I refer to a letter dated 9 August 1995 from the then Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, Senator Schacht, in which, in part, he says:

BREAK.PARA: However, the law continues to allow rebate to be paid where an activity can be said to be `mining for minerals' and does not simply constitute the extraction of the now excluded materials.

Therefore, the legal test is whether the activities of a claimant are carried out with a view to recovering from the limestone ore, a mineral or minerals such as calcium carbonate (or calcite). If this is the case, then the rebate is payable.
In a further letter from the now minister, Mr Prosser, dated 16 October 1996, the minister, in part, says:

Most quarrying materials previously eligible for diesel fuel rebate became ineligible on 1 July 1995. The only materials presently eligible are limestone for use in de‐acidification of soil in agriculture and materials from which the mineral content is extracted, such as rutile.
Minister, that somewhat makes a bit of an untruth what you have been saying and what you told me in estimates.

The cement industry, in its submission to the Economics Legislation Committee inquiry into the Customs and Excise Legislation Bill (No. 2) 1996, highlighted the inequity of the situation. I would like to refer to that submission because they also acknowledge the fact that the then minister, Senator Schacht, had written to them. It was their view that what he had said was correct. In their submission—and I will read part of it—they said:

The Cement Industry mines limestone for the sole purpose of recovering the mineral calcite or calcium from what is a naturally occurring raw material. Under the `mining for minerals' test we believe we are eligible for the diesel fuel rebate.

The Cement Industry enjoyed the benefit of the diesel fuel rebate prior to the legislation passed in July 1995. With the introduction of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Act 1995 (Act No. 87 of 1995), which came into effect on July 1, 1995, some confusion arose as to the continuing eligibility of the Cement Industry in respect of its mining activities directed to the recovery of calcite or calcium. This legislation introduced a clause which excluded—
and this is the important point—
sand, sandstone, soil, slate, clay (other than bentonite or kaolin) basalt, granite, gravel or water, or limestone (other than agricultural use limestone).

The insertion of limestone in the 1995 amendment, was intended to exclude limestone which was quarried but not to exclude limestone which was mined, where mining was undertaken in the pursuit of mineral recovery (calcite or calcium). The blanket exclusion of `limestone' has created unintentional and undue confusion. The intent was to clarify the quarrying issue.

I will come to this a little bit later. The situation with regard to the cement industry is that Customs has always contended—and indeed may well now, as a result of these amendments, contend—that they are quarrying.

If it is the case that, although Customs have been fighting a losing battle in the courts with regard to this matter, and it seems to be getting more confused by the day—I think they are fighting a losing battle; I notice the minister nodded with regard to that—and they are now changing the course of their attack on the basis that if this legislation goes through they will say: `You might have won the battle with regard to the minerals mining test, but we are going to knock you over on the basis of the quarrying test, which we think you will not meet,' that provides a somewhat interesting set of circumstances. One would have to wonder about coalmining in so far as it relates to open-cut. The mining industry would be rather interested in such an interpretation of quarrying.

If a company is mining limestone and then going for a process to extract a mineral which to all intents and purposes, as I understand it—and I will be very interested to hear whether my opinion is wrong—is not excluded by the list of other things that are described as not being minerals for the purposes of the legislation, it will be very interesting to see what sort of position the Minerals Council will adopt. I raised this question with them.

Minister, when I asked some questions of you in the estimates you indicated that, should Customs lose their court processes, they would be paying. The information that is being conveyed to the cement industry appears to be: `We are still not going to pay you even if you win in the Federal Court because we will have this legislation up and we will knock you over on the basis of quarry.' I will be very interested to hear the minister's explanation of that when the times comes. I also ask you, Minister: even if at some point in time you win the argument about quarrying, will it also be the case that you will not be paying the cement industry retrospectively for those claims they had before this legislation became law?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —In the second reading speech on the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996 the government proposes savings of $160 million. The bill does this by narrowing eligibility and excluding formerly claimable activities. It tightens administration and acts to close off claims allowed as a result of appeals to the AAT and the Federal Court. These changes will impact directly on the bottom line of most claimants.

SPEECH.PARA: The government has not provided any analysis of the consequences of last year's budget cut in terms of industry viability, jobs, investment or exports. Nor am I aware of any government cost-benefit analysis of the diesel fuel rebate and its effect on the mining industry, regional economies and the broader economy.

During the federal election campaign in February 1996 Senator Cheryl Kernot, leader of the Australian Democrats, said that if faced with a choice of cuts to essential services and budgets, particularly the environment, it would be wise to consider a package of cuts including to—and I quote—`reduce the energy inefficient diesel subsidies to the mining industry, subsidies which are worth over $800 million a year and which are not available to industries such as tourism, services and manufacturing, all of which raise more export revenue than mining'.

The Australian Democrats recommended reducing the DFR for the mining industry during that election campaign. We recommended that it be reduced by 50 per cent, so achieving revenue savings of $400 million. This bill, by cutting the DFR by $160 million, meets 40 per cent of the target we set. Obviously we will therefore be supporting the bill for that reason.

The Australian Democrats have three prime motivations for our policy. Firstly, we believe the mining industry has the capacity to substantially improve fuel efficiency by reducing its reliance on diesel, a move that would assist in reducing Australia's greenhouse emissions. Removing the rebate would make diesel less attractive on cost grounds. Secondly, we accept that there are limits to the budget capacity of government and in a climate of strong budget cuts and strong community demands the Australian Democrats believe it is appropriate for the mining industry to make this contribution to budget outlays. Thirdly, we believe that the DFR is an inefficient and inappropriate industry and export motivator. With regard to the first item, we recognise that, in trying to induce fuel efficiencies, there should be a carrot as well as a stick. Incentives could be considered to encourage a speedy switch for the mining industry out of diesel usage into energy usage, which delivers a better environmental outcome.

With regard to the second item, budget needs are immediate and continue to be immediate. The coalition government and many business and economic commentators have advocated cuts to the DFR for budget reasons. The Australian Democrats recognise that investment in the mining industry often has a long lead time before the returns kick in. Investors in the mining industry frequently need to take a long-term view and for some current projects the DFR may be an important contributor to viability and the bottom line.

For that reason, despite the fact that we support a reduction in DFR, we believe that it would be profoundly unfair to suddenly and significantly change the financial climate in which the industry operates. Accordingly, a graduated phased reduction would be preferable for industry financial planning. I am aware from the running sheet that the Greens (WA) will be putting up an amendment for a fast‐phase reduction but, in view of the comments I have just made, we will not be able to support that view.

The third item in our policy consideration relates to the inefficiency of the DFR as an export or industry motivational device. The ANAO picked up problems with the DFR scheme in the 1996 performance audit and recommended that the purpose and objective of the scheme be clarified. The government says that the primary purpose of the DFR is to maintain competitiveness in these key export industries. In this statement it did not say that the primary purpose is for government to refund or rebate moneys to which it is not entitled, and that is the argument of the mining industry.

We are well aware that the mining industry strongly asserts that the DFR is not industry assistance but is a refund of diesel fuel excise which is not applicable in specified circumstances. However, the rail industry, manufacturers and many exporters do not get the rebate and could mount similar arguments for it. They are paying a higher price for diesel which they, too, may use as a business input. Equitable principles would require the DFR to be provided across the board on a common basis to those with an equivalent export or industry case. Instead, the DFR is applied on a discriminatory basis. This discrimination in favour of the mining, fishing and farming industries clearly identifies the DFR as an assistance measure extended to select groups.

The Australian Democrats, consequently, do consider the DFR to be an industry assistance measure. On that basis, its efficacy must be evaluated. Australian Democrat support for appropriate industry assistance is well doc umented—including for assistance the coalition government has cut, such as DIFF, the 150 per cent R&D tax allowance, the EMDG scheme and so on. The Australian Democrats believe that the DFR as applied is arbitrary, discriminatory, administratively complex and poorly targeted. We believe that export motivation and industry assistance for the mining industry needs to be re-examined. That will require a re‐look at taxes, including those on inputs and outputs, and a re‐look at impediments to competitive exports by the mining industry. Well crafted change in these areas could well put the industry in an even better shape than it is currently even if the DFR were to be withdrawn.

Given the existing tax and policy milieu, industry witnesses clearly stated that they would prefer government to raise taxes out of profits rather than to cut assistance measures, which affect costs. The Australian Democrats will therefore support a reduction in the total budget allocation for the DFR as proposed by the government, but we do believe that the proposed legislation needs amendment in terms of fairness and rationality within that broad budget constraint, and we have circulated amendments to that effect.

Any further reduction in the DFR we believe should be laid out in advance by government on a phased and graduated basis so that the industries affected can proceed with sound financial planning. In terms of the arguments I outlined earlier, we accept that that should be done within the purview of an overall look at the tax system and competitive export assistance.

There are four ways in which the DFR could be applied by government to the mining industry—firstly, as a general rebate to the mining industry. This, we recognise, as does government, would result in a growing and open-ended budget cost. Both the present and the previous governments rejected this route, selectively restricting eligibility.

The second way in which it could be applied by government to the mining industry is as a rebate selectively applied to favoured constituent parts of the mining industry. This system is currently in place. This restricts the total potential cost but it is still open-ended for those so favoured. In an attempt to hold down the budget cost, this bill increases the discrimination between those mining activities which attract the DFR and those which do not on a basis which does appear to us rather arbitrary and rather capricious.

The third way in which the DFR could be applied by government to the mining industry is as a capped amount. For this to work the rebate would have to be altered from a specified amount per litre of diesel used to a pro rata application of funds to all those eligible on the basis of funds available. This, in our view, is the best way of reducing the DFR on a known cost basis but of then being able to extend the scheme to all industry participants on a fair and non-discriminatory basis.

Fourthly, the DFR could be applied by government to the mining industry as a targeted and specified industry assistance measure designed as a mechanism to grow mining, fishing or farming sectors or subsectors, or organisations which warranted special interventionist attention on sound economic and social grounds.

When the Senate report came down, the majority report correctly summarised the discriminatory, arbitrary, complex and capricious way in which the DFR is being applied in the mining industry—and it was the same case, incidentally, with the previous government as well as with this bill. Changed definitions to mining operations and beneficiation have resulted in very considerable concern. The industry witnesses produced a telling list of mining processes and minerals which are illogically excluded from the present and proposed scheme. Land mining operations are favourably treated in comparison with sea mining operations. There appears to be no rational process for the inclusion of certain minerals in the scheme and the exclusion of others. Salt, mined limestone, petroleum, rutile and kaolin rank amongst the losers; copper, gold, uranium and alumina are amongst the winners. Natural gas is at a disadvantage compared with coal. In electricity generation, with regard to CO2 omissions natural gas plants are far preferable to coal fired plants, and we believe that natural gas should be supported.

BREAK.PARA: These DFR changes will cut eligibility for a number of claimants who have been eligible for many years. We need to be cognisant of the possibility that these DFR changes could tip some operations into a loss making situation. Such operations may need a little time to get their affairs in order. It would seem desirable, Minister, that any person or organisation which formerly operated at a profit and which will now operate at a loss solely because of the DFR changes should be able to appeal to you for special dispensation to claim for at least one further financial year.

The majority report well summarises the evidence that the revised administrative arrangements will be too onerous. Witnesses advised that the proposed amendments would result in excessive compliance costs. In evidence, an AMEC witness read out a list of the day‐to‐day DFR administrative problems consequent to the amendments. That submission would have been very funny if it was not so damning. For a government committed to reducing business compliance costs, this bill does not appear to do much for their cause.

The exclusion of some and the inclusion of others in the proposed amended DFR scheme is unfair and, in the opinion of many in the industry and its experts, is not determined on sound and defensible grounds. The government has quite properly determined to reduce the cost of the scheme and the levels of expenditure on it. Unfairness can only be eliminated by either capping the scheme and paying pro rata, as discussed above, or by limiting the payment very considerably to a few narrowly defined activities or by deliberately picking sectoral winners in the industry.

It seems to me that the government, in its negotiations and intended resolution of this issue, has achieved an outcome which is unsatisfactory to many key industry constituents and it has to some extent lost their trust as a result. Industry witnesses spoke strongly to the economics committee concerning a breach of faith and a failure to honour agreements or a deal that they believed had been reached.

I want to turn to prospectors, a small business group within the mining industry. The Australian Democrats believe that prospectors undertake an essential, high risk and difficult task for the mining industry. It is also a major small business and entrepreneurial sector in the mining industry. The coalition government has already ended a tax exemption concession—paragraph 23(pa) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936—which did apply to prospectors. The government's decision in this bill to end the DFR for light vehicles under 3.5 tonnes gross weight is another hit at this small business sector. Light vehicles are the main off‐road item used in prospecting. It is our intention to move an amendment to correct this.

I now want to move to probably the only area which really affects farmers in our discussions and our amendments, and that is taking away the right to silence and the rights to appeal. The Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee in Alert Digest 1/97 identified a problem of civil liberties and natural justice. Item 25 of schedule 1 and item 10 of schedule 2 of this bill would insert proposed subsection 164AC(15) into the Customs Act 1901 and proposed subsection 78AD(15) into the Excise Act 1901. The committee said:

These sections refer to the powers of the Chief Executive Officer of Customs . . . to obtain information for the purposes of auditing a particular diesel fuel rebate application . . . These subsections, if enacted, would take away the right of a person to remain silent . . . that may result in the person incriminating himself or herself, thus exposing the person to prosecution for, and perhaps conviction of, a criminal offence. Taking away this right undoubtedly trespasses on personal rights and liberties. Whether it trespasses unduly on personal rights and liberties will depend on the context in which it is done. The issue is whether the advantage to the common good outweighs the loss to the individual of taking away the right to silence . . . The adverse effect of taking away the right to silence is partially mitigated by the protection included in the proposed subsections . . . The protection, however, is quite inadequate because it does not grant immunity from prosecution under paragraphs 234(1)(c) or (d) of the Customs Act 1901 or 120(1)(vc) or (vi) of the Excise Act 1901 in relation to the diesel fuel rebate.

I and the Democrats are opposed in principle to the erosion of such rights. Citizens and organisations need safeguards against the power of the state. Many government entities, including Customs, have historically had to be reprimanded and constrained by the courts. The other problem is a lack of rights to appeal some Customs and chief executive officer decisions. Customs is an organisation with considerable powers, sometimes exceeding those of the police. I do not accept that there should be situations where Customs can be accuser, judge and executioner. I propose to introduce appropriate amendments for rights of appeal where they do not exist.

Judging by the experience of the cement industry, as outlined in the hearings, one would be wise to be cautious of expecting Customs to always operate consistently and fairly. In the case of the cement industry, DFR claims are accepted at three sites and rejected at eight. I understand they are now going to be reviewed for the three that they were accepted at.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have been.

—It has happened. The basis for differentiation appears to be Customs' refusal to grant the DFR unless forced to by the courts or the AAT. That is an unnecessarily costly course for eligible claimants to have to follow and is unsatisfactory.

BREAK.PARA: The economics committee did not hear from persons or organisations opposed to the DFR on policy grounds, which is a regret I have. I have made clear the Australian Democrats' position. Also not addressed in the committee inquiry was the issue of rail versus road and the effect of diesel on taxes and charges that affect the relative usage of either. A review or change of these could affect diesel costs.

Another matter has not been addressed by the committee. In October 1996 the Democrats raised in the Senate the problem of a major leakage and loss of diesel fuel at a mining site which may have been subsequently claimed for DFR. The minister's answer to the question, read in part, states:

I am advised that it is not possible to determine whether all or part of the diesel lost was, or was not, subject to rebate claim without an extensive search of both Customs and GEMCO's records, even then, a conclusive outcome may not result . . . Under the existing legislation, payment of rebate is based on intended use for eligible activities.

It seems profoundly odd to me that a claim can be made for intended and not actual use. So, Minister, it is a curate's egg from us. We will be supporting your bill, but we will be moving amendments to correct those areas which we regard as unfair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I make it clear that the Greens oppose the diesel fuel excise rebate which goes to the mining industries in Australia. There is a move in this legislation to tighten the criteria for eligibility for that rebate but, when we look at the figures, we see that the mining industry will receive $1,437 million and, together with the rural industries, we will then see that figure go to $1.708 billion three years down the line.
—Wrong.

—The minister opposite says, `Wrong,' but I do not know what he is talking about—they are his figures. However, what he will know is that the lion's share of the $1 billion or so per annum for the next four years does go to the mining industry.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, in the current year the big Australian, BHP, will be handed a cheque for over $100 million as its gift from this government, which, at the same time, is cutting overseas aid by $16 million, has a $5 million cutback to SBS, is cutting the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission budget by 40 per cent, is going to eliminate Aboriginal Austudy assistance over the next four years—that is a $39 million cut—is going to cut the Aboriginal reconciliation budget by five per cent, is going to raise immigration application fees—that is $18 million there from people who might not have as much money in their pockets as BHP—and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —You people don't want migration anyway. You want zero net migration.

—Senator O'Chee can get up and misrepresent who he likes in his own good time but I suggest to you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that he should not misrepresent through interjection. Of course, I will be a little better than him by trying to ignore his unruly and out of order interjections as best I can, particularly when they come from such profound ignorance as he is so readily able to display.

BREAK.PARA: The Australian Greens will be supporting the move by Senator Margetts to eliminate this $1 billion per annum hand‐out to the big mining corporations, some of which, by the way, bounces back in terms of hundreds of thousands of dollars going to the major parties through electoral donations year after year. I am sure that they will say that has—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are making that up.

—I am reading the documents which are released each year. Senator Parer, who says that that is being made up, might care to look at those figures himself and cavil with the mining corporations—they think it is a good investment. No doubt, one of the things they think it is a good investment in protecting is this $800 million this year, moving to more than $1 billion, hand‐out which they are getting courtesy of his government's very biased policy as far as the mining companies on one hand and the poor immigrant Australians on the other hand are concerned.

BREAK.PARA: Having looked at the negative side of the diesel fuel rebate, which has been so ably protected by this government when they are cutting ordinary Australians to the bone in their other budget policies, I want to be positive and to challenge the positive side of the government in doing so. What we Greens propose is a sun fund. The amendments which I will be moving in the committee stages will set the basis for this revenue‐neutral option to the diesel fuel rebate for farmers in particular, for people in the bush. What it means is that people will be able to cash in their diesel fuel rebate and use the money instead to subsidise the capital cost of installing solar panels, wind or solar thermal systems.

TALK.START.PARA: —For their trucks?

—The senators opposite do not understand the difference between diesel fuel rebate coming from their trucks, as Senator Parer says and Senator O'Chee screams in laughter in backing up, and the fact that many farmers—thousands of them—are getting the fuel rebate for their diesel generators producing electricity.
—What about their tractors?

—Senator O'Chee can come up with a scheme for their tractors. I am sure he is short of the wit and wisdom to do anything positive on his own, but I am putting forward a positive initiative here and, in his own good time, he can respond positively to that.

BREAK.PARA: What I am talking about is the component of the diesel fuel rebate which produces electricity for people on the land. This will test Senator O'Chee. It means that people will be able to cash in the equivalent of their diesel fuel rebate over the next 10 years and, in return from the government, have that rebate over 10 years put into up‐front capital investment in solar alternatives for the production of electricity, particularly domestic electricity which they will be dependent on. This means that they will be producing clean, green energy instead of using one of the most environmentally destructive forms of fossil fuel energy production. So it is a win‐win situation for people on the land. The problem for many people on the land is that they are having hard times at the moment and capital is very hard to come by. Senator O'Chee laughs at that, but it is a serious matter, Madam Acting Deputy President.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am laughing still at your suggestion.
—I take it seriously even though he thinks it is a joke.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. My point of order is not Senator Brown's deliberate misrepresentation. My point of order is that Senator Brown is deceitfully trying to impute to me a quite erroneous motive for my laughter. That is not why I am laughing; I am laughing because of his absurd proposal to have solar powered tractors. To impute any other motive is quite unparliamentary, and I ask that the imputation be withdrawn.
—Senator O'Chee, there is no point of order. If you feel that you have been misrepresented, you can, at a later time, seek leave to make a personal explanation.

—That is absolutely correct. I do not withdraw what I said. I stand by it absolutely, because it was correct. As I said, Senator O'Chee might find room for laughter here, but I take it seriously. We are putting a serious alternative to the people in the bush who do not have the cash in hand to move towards an alternative like this, even though many of them may aspire to it.

BREAK.PARA: It is a win‐win situation. It is based on similar schemes elsewhere in the world. For example, for many years the electricity authority in New Zealand made an interest‐free capital grant available to householders to insulate their homes. In return, the householders had diminished electricity bills which allowed them to pay off that capital loan quite rapidly. The electricity authority had spare electricity which it could sell on to new buyers. That was a win‐win situation.

In the United States, private corporations have gone further than that. In a move which is simple to understand, one private electricity utility has been handing out the new energy efficient light bulbs free to householders. These bulbs, which are eight times as efficient as the old bulbs, have allowed energy to be freed up and passed on to new buyers. That is energy efficiency. It takes a bit of lateral thinking, but it is a very wise way to be moving.

I put this idea of a sun fund for the bush very seriously: people can take up this option which, besides helping with the capital investment up front, will mean that over the coming years—ad infinitum—they will not be paying any diesel fuel bills for electricity production. It is a very exciting and positive alternative. It fits in very much with the world's aspiration to reduce greenhouse gases. It also fits in very much with the stimulation of sunrise industries which this country should be at the forefront in assisting.

This is not small pickles. If we look at the rural sector which this fund is aimed at, if all those farms were to convert their electricity production from the current diesel generation to solar alternatives, the energy displacement would be equivalent to 600 megawatts. Six hundred megawatts is equivalent to half the total potential output of Tasmania's hydro‐electric system—the 39 dams in Tasmania. It is a big domestic market. So the third component of the good news about this option is that it would be a tremendous stimulus to those Australian businesses—not least small businesses, which are labour intensive businesses—which are at the forefront of technological innovation for energy production.

So the government wins, the farmers win and the sunrise energy production industries win as well. I hope the government will consider very seriously the amendments which I will be putting forward, because there is a great opportunity to have something very positive and green come out of this legislation. The government likes to say that the Greens oppose the proposals it brings forward and that they have a negative viewpoint. While I disagree with that, here is a great opportunity for the government to be positive, to follow its own line of thinking and to take up an alternative which has everybody in the community winning and which will do a great deal to enhance the government's own image both with environmentalists and with people in the bush.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Children from their Families

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the report of the National Inquiry into the Separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Children From Their Families, entitled Bringing them home . I propose to the Senate that any debate on this report be delayed until later this week, when it is expected that the government will make a statement in relation to this report.

TITLE.XREF: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1996 (No. 2)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran, Sen Julian

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are discussing the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996 (No. 2). The bill gives effect to the 1996‐97 budget announcement of the government, and its intention is to amend the diesel fuel rebate legislation. The fact that we have the government's first budget legislation now overlapping with the government's second budget is a fair indication of the sort of log jam this Senate is facing and of the obstructionism this government is facing in the Senate. The guilty party is sitting across the other side on the Greens benches.

SPEECH.PARA: The best example of their obstructionism was only about a fortnight ago when we had the delay to the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia Bill. You would have thought that that bill—which was doing no more than setting up a billion dollar trust for the good of the environment—would have been rushed through this chamber with the support of all the parties in the Senate. But the Green senators vexatiously and frivolously delayed it, simply on the grounds of politics. They were very fearful that, with this government on the front foot on the environment, it would put their party out of business.

In discussing this bill, I cannot help but mention the previous three speakers. I was amused by Senator Murphy's detailed and studied contribution. He went in to bat to defend the very industries he has spent a career—particularly under his union hat, let alone his senatorial position at the moment—pulling down: the mining and forestry industry, to say nothing of the farmers. In his contribution he even said something in the defence of the farmers. Of course, his party, when in government, spent 13 years—each budget—ratcheting up petrol taxes.

He was followed by the Democrat Senator Murray. I tried to understand the scheme that he put forward; I really made an effort. He himself admitted that it was complex, and he is dead right about that. It seemed to be a scheme that brought in more restriction, yet also broadened the scheme, to use his words. It broadened and restricted. Isn't that typical of the Democrats? There is something for all. I suggest that the mining industry or any of the industries that at present have the advantage of the diesel fuel rebate study Senator Murray's scheme and not fall for it, because, as usual, it has not only the gloss of the Democrat fairness on it but also the complexity and the uselessness that the Democrats bring to this particular debate.

I think we all had a good laugh at Senator Brown from the Greens party when he seriously suggested that we have sun‐powered tractors. This is very relevant to the debate, isn't it! This legislation contains a billion dollar‐plus scheme to tighten up eligibility and that wacky Senator Brown walks in here and suggests that the farmers would do well to have sun‐powered tractors. I have never heard of the scheme before—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I ask you to remove the word `wacky' from your assessment of your colleague.
—I withdraw the word.
—Unbelievable.

—To be replaced by `unbelievable'. Thank you, Senator O'Chee. I have never heard of such a scheme before. I do not think it is even on the drawing board. I think it has just come from Senator Brown. Sun‐powered tractors! As if the farmers haven't enough problems without taking up that absurd suggestion. But we all had a good laugh and we did not take it at all seriously, Senator Brown, if you thought for one fleeting moment that we did.

SPEECH.PARA: Getting to the essence of the scheme before us, which escaped the speakers before me, the scheme does provide rebates of excise or customs duty on diesel fuel purchased for specific off‐road users mainly in the mining, agricultural, fishing and forestry operations. The figures from 1994‐95 show that there were some 213,000 claims involving some $1.25 billion.

BREAK.PARA: The scheme is pretty clear. There is no mystery to it, as defined by the Australian National Audit Office. The bill gives effect to the government's intention to achieve savings in the scheme by tightening eligibility and containing growth in the outlays. This particular intention is endorsed by the audit office, which recommended that the purpose and objectives of the scheme be somewhat clarified, and that a range of measures be introduced to improve accountability.

According to the government's explanatory memorandum, the amendments fall into three broad categories. The first excludes from mining operations the eligibility for rebate in respect of nearly all light vehicles and certain off‐road activities. Further amendments restricting eligibility relate to sea transport, off‐site rail, sea and public road use and quarrying.

The second broad amendment has the effect of counteracting the effect of certain AAT and Federal Court decisions, specifically the Dampier Salt decision. In his second reading speech, the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser), said:

The particular amendments will ensure the continuation of rebate for diesel fuel used in carrying out mining activities but will preclude from eligibility certain activities, best described as undertaken for economic/marketing reasons, rather than the physical extraction of minerals, and activities which essentially involve the transport of inputs/materials for mining or beneficiation.

As the audit office requested, that certainly does clearly define the purpose of the diesel fuel rebate, if there is indeed any doubt at all. In relation to the Dampier Salt case, the concern of the government was that the interpretation had the potential to substantially widen the eligibility under the scheme. On this matter, the minister said:

The full Federal Court's judgment is considered to be the most far reaching ever delivered in relation to the diesel fuel rebate scheme. It represents a fundamental shift from a scheme based on the concept of an activity (in this case mining) being regarded as a physical act (that is the extraction of a product from the ground) to a concept of the activity being an economic one.
The third broad based amendment relates to accountability and administration. In his second reading speech, the minister said:
A range of amendments are proposed which will improve accountability requirements, assist in enabling a clamp down on misuse of the scheme and improve its administration.

I will not go into too much detail on the third amendments. Given the strict time which we government members are under, I would like to jump to the main point, which relates to the defence of the diesel fuel rebate. It is so often under attack from those on the other side of the house and from many out in the community. We know from those on the other side of the house that, if they could have abolished the scheme in their time in government, they would have. We know they tried—but failed—in their last budget to place a one per cent levy on the administration cost, which would have raised around $12 million, which is about the cost of the administration of this scheme.

This government has no plans to introduce such a levy or to fundamentally change the diesel fuel rebate. We know just how much the major export industries—the mining industry and the rural sector—depend on this scheme and how important it is to their competitiveness to reduce input costs. Why should these two major export schemes not have the advantage of the diesel fuel rebate? The mining industry exports $33 billion a year and claims only some $750 million a year—a very low percentage in regard to the diesel fuel rebate. The rural industry exports $21 billion a year and claims around the $400 million mark, which is a very small price for the government coffers in respect of supporting, giving incentives to and lowering input costs for these major export industries.

The National Farmers Federation, a staunch defender of the diesel fuel rebate—as are the National Party in government; and Senator Crane, from Western Australia, who knows only too well the importance of the diesel fuel rebate to his state—submitted a very extensive report on the importance of the diesel fuel rebate to the farming sector. Part of that report says:
Over the two decade period, consumption has grown on average by about 2.4% per annum. This would, in part, be due to substitution of diesel for petrol—
with—
the wider availability of diesel powered vehicles and equipment—
such as four‐wheel drives and grain harvesters.
Over the same period, the area sown to grain has risen by about 3 million ha, about 25% in total, an average annual growth of 1.1% in the area sown to grain.

The relationship of that to the diesel fuel rebate scheme is that it is an important factor in supplying, and giving incentive to, the expansion of the rural sector. In the mining sector, we need only to look at two industries. The Minerals Council has submitted a paper in regard to the importance of this scheme.

I will pick out two major export industries. The first is the major export industry—the coal industry. The paper says that, should the scheme be abolished, it would have an effect on the coal industry. It says:
. . . cancellation in the Rebate will:
(a) increase input costs by about $1 a tonne for coal with no ability to pass the cost increase on to customers.
For the coal industry, which is the most competitive industry, particularly with exports to Japan, any increase in cost almost means death.
The second industry that would be most affected is the gold industry. The paper says that the abolition of the diesel fuel rebate would:
significantly increase the input costs of Australia's gold industry—

particularly in remote areas where diesel is a major fuel source with virtually no likelihood of alternative fuel sources such as electricity or gas due to the remoteness of mines from the national grids. This has the potential to impact on low grade mining operations. For example, for the remote mine of Telfer in Western Australia, abolition of the Rebate would require the mine head grade to improve by over 70% to maintain mining income.

That is fairly significant in respect of the importance of the scheme. In conclusion, the amendments that the government is bringing to this scheme to tighten its eligibility are necessary and creditable while maintaining our commitment to the scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill, currently the subject of debate, seeks the reduction of Commonwealth expenditure to the tune of some $160 million. This will be achieved by saving about $35 million by restricting eligibility in the mining operations category; saving about $100 million by containing the effect of a series of allegedly expansionary court decisions which impose significant cost obligations on the Commonwealth; and saving some $25 million through amendments to accountability.

SPEECH.PARA: In this debate I wish to briefly address the following issues arising out of the bill: firstly, the impact on the goldmining and exploration activities in Western Australia through the removal of the DFR for light vehicles less than 3.5 tonnes; secondly, the adequacy of the financial impact statements; thirdly, the somewhat confused and apparently contradictory position of industry participants in this debate; and fourthly, particular industries that are affected by this bill and recent amendments circulated by the government. I refer here to the salt industry and concerns of major organisations like the Minerals Council, AMEC and APPEA.

I turn firstly to the impact on the goldmining and exploration activities through the removal of the diesel fuel rebate for light vehicles. It is critical to understand at the outset how the mining exploration industry and its people work. It is a quintessential, risk driven industry. It comprises individuals, small groups and small companies. A feature of this industry is high risk at the outset and continuing high risk, often over many years. It requires initial raising of capital. This capital funds exploration and continuing exploration. That exploration is carried out in both brown field and green field sites.

Brown field sites are existing geological formations, and exploration tends to follow trends of possible or potential mineral deposits. Green field sites are pure exploration. It is increasingly done by radio beams from satellites which identify particular mineral formations under the ground. In either green field or brown field sites, actual physical follow‐up is required. This involves soil sampling, pit exploration, geological surveying, site marking and site identification.

BREAK.PARA: These activities all require four-wheel drive vehicles to carry out physical work. The cost of the diesel fuel is critical to that exploration process. The removal of the rebate is thus a high cost impost to the early exploration and identification work conducted by individuals and small end mining companies.

The process of exploration, initial capital raising and physical checking is high risk and very expensive. As the process continues and potential sites are identified, the value of that site increases. This outcome is used as the incentive to raise further additional capital through placement of additional shares. This then funds further exploration, building up the further value in potential sites.
In Western Australia in the goldmining areas, the gold ratio is higher than for other minerals. Hence, the removal of the rebate is an attack on the gold exploration industry.

One asks the obvious question: what are the attributes of individual geologists and prospectors involved in this industry? They are highly educated, small business people or often battlers, entrepreneurial in outlook and risk takers by nature. The removal of this rebate is thus an attack on the backbone of this industry.

So, in summary on this aspect of the debate, I would submit that this industry employs many people from this battler sector and many people who are generally entrepreneurial in their outlook; it is a high risk industry with any return many years in the future; the process of capital raising is critical to fund exploration, which is the heart of the industry; the only government concession is the diesel fuel rebate; the removal of this rebate for light vehicles less than 3½ tonnes directly attacks the cash flow of all in this industry; the prospectors' main tool of trade is their four‐wheel drive vehicle used extensively in remote off-road situations in the search for minerals; any extra cost associated with the use of four‐wheel drive vehicles will impact upon exploration activities; and the consequences of the removal of the DFR will be to limit exploration, make capital raising more difficult and restrict the comparative advan tage of the Western Australian goldmining industry.

I now turn to the financial impact statements. As is customary in the EM, there is a financial impact statement. The form of the FIS in this EM is no different from that prepared for other bills. At best, it is a most cursory document. On page 7, paragraph (a) simply identifies savings of around $35 million in the mining operations category. Paragraph (b) says:

The amendments are designed to contain expansion in the Scheme and not designed to achieve savings. Failure to introduce these changes however could result in additional outlays of up to $100m per annum.
Paragraph (c) refers to :
. . . amendments to improve accountability under the Scheme and its administration.
It says:
Savings of around $25m per annum are estimated from these measures.

So the assertions of savings of millions of dollars are made. The government chooses to provide no supporting evidence of how these figures were determined, the method of calculation, the detail of any cost‐benefit analysis that may have been carried out, whether any cost‐benefit analysis was carried out and which department or agency did this job, and whether any figures were the subject of review by either Treasury or the Department of Finance. My suspicion is that the figure grossly underestimates the amount of savings, particularly with reference to paragraphs (a) and (b) on page 7 of the financial impact statement.

Indeed, in the budget the government announced that, whilst the DFR scheme would be tightened, it would remain. The budget figure costed savings to outlays of $441 million over four years. This can be contrasted with the EM, which proposed a financial impact of $60 million per year, or $240 million over four years, plus $100 million per annum in savings. If these two savings in the explanatory memorandum are added, the saving is really $406 million over the four‐year period. So two different documents show alternatively a saving of $441 million or $640 million over four years. At best, it is fair to conclude that the government is confused.

This issue of exactness of financial figures was raised in the additional estimates. It was raised in the Economics Legislation Committee's consideration of the current bill. Indeed, Senator Cook specifically asked the government a series of questions. A particular question was:

Has the government conducted any cost benefit analysis or is it aware of any cost benefit analysis conducted by a reputable non‐government agency or private sector consultancy into the impact of federal government taxes and charges in the mining sector?

The government on 6 May responded to these questions with the simple response of `No'. So in arriving at its costings and savings, the government did not carry out any cost‐benefit analysis and is still not aware of any such analysis being conducted by any private sector agency.

So at the end of the day the Senate is requested to add an impost on industry or make a savings to forward outlays of between $441 million and $640 million over a four‐year period. At best, these two parameter figures are dubious and more likely to be a back‐of‐the‐envelope consideration.

In addition, the government refuses to provide any of the relevant financial information to the Senate. This is a matter for concern because it goes to the question of financial responsibility, accountability and transparency. These are all matters addressed by the government in its charter of budget honesty and it is about time they were put into practice in bills presented to the Senate.

I now wish to turn to the apparently confused position of industry and government in this debate. The minority report outlines the apparent position reached between government and industry on this bill. The minority report makes the following points. Firstly, the basis of the bill is an agreement struck between a high‐level group and a government negotiating committee. Secondly, that government committee comprised the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs, Mr Prosser, and on occasions Senator Parer. Thirdly, that agreement was the result of a negotiation exercise carried out by the high‐ level group, broadly representative of the mining industry and the Commonwealth. Fourthly, that agreement attempted to resolve from the Commonwealth's perspective the issues of growth and budget costs of rebate due to unintended claims, and from the high‐level group's position the industry objectives of certainty.

This agreement of course is most critical. There are different views on the nature of the agreement and different final documents from the high‐level group and the government. Notwithstanding these differences, the following is clear: the high‐level group, on behalf of industry, intended to concede areas that may have been held to be areas of legitimate claim, thus confining the scope of the rebate quite tightly in exchange for an agreement from the government not to put a cap on claims in the remaining legitimate areas of the act.

Industry associations testified that the bill explicitly dishonours the agreement reached. These disagreements go to: the inclusion of the salt industry; the definition of beneficiation where it is involved; and the involvement of the cement industry without its apparent knowledge or support. Details of that confused position are outlined at paragraph 13 of the minority report. This is indeed a most unsatisfactory conclusion, the result of an industry process.

The opposition does not wish to be particularly difficult on this aspect of the debate. Normally industry‐government agreements are to be applauded and are a powerful indicator to the legislature. Normally it should and would be supported by the opposition. However, subject to any comments to be made later by Senator Parer, it is not proper at this stage to offer any further comment than to simply point out the apparent inconsistencies.

Turning fourthly to particular industries, I refer specifically to the salt industry in Western Australia. It is the opposition's view that this matter needs to be resolved with the industry. The amount of their savings identified in figures provided to the Economics References Committee and in the EM is of the order of $600,000 per annum. The issue of that saving arises from the use of a dry stockpile in the mining of that particular product. My understanding is that the concern of the government is for flow into other areas, presumably the iron ore industry and other large extraction type industries in Western Australia.

The inclusion of Dampier Salt from Western Australia and the limitation of their existing right to claim the rebate has a wholly unsatisfactory and unsavoury flavour. The high‐level group never claimed to have authority to negotiate and conclude a bargain on their behalf. The likely saving to the Commonwealth of $600,000 per annum is a fairly heavy impost on a commodity extraction and export oriented export firm and industry. It is really a tax on the productive inputs of the salt industry. To the extent that it affects the price received for the end product, it is quite inefficient. It is also, by definition, an unworthy slug on a Western Australian based mining industry.

The solution, if the government is of a mind, is fairly simple and straightforward. It is simply to circulate an amendment to the effect that nothing contained in the bill shall affect the current entitlement of Dampier Salt Pty Ltd in respect of their location in a particular site in Western Australia. Indeed, the real criticism of the proposed amendment to the definition of beneficiation is that it unfairly discriminates against salt producers relative to other mining operators.

I now turn to recent amendments of the Commonwealth. During the Senate inquiry Senator Parer announced further amendments to the bill. They are now tabled in the Senate. The Minerals Council of Australia has advised of a number of concerns. In its correspondence of 19 March it says:

The Minerals Council's support for the amendments is qualified by the statement that any suggestion of the introduction of a cap on expenditure in the diesel fuel rebate scheme or any increase in diesel fuel excise would be seen as a breach of faith of the industry/government High Level Group agreement and opposed by the industry.

In particular, the Minerals Council goes on to point out the discriminatory treatment meted out to Dampier Salt in Western Australia by singling out particular company activities unfairly. The Minerals Council is correct to point out that the amendments could have unintended consequences for the future.

Obviously, a technically satisfactory way of drying and cleaning the salt exists. The passage of the bill may force the company to consider a more inefficient way of stockpiling to retain the rebate of $600,000 per annum. Similarly, AMEC is correct to point out that the structure of the legislation is flawed. As it identifies, the bill does not provide for complete coverage for all activities in a mining operation. Thus, it is to be regretted because, again, it has the capacity to introduce inefficiencies in planning, layout and production processes.

In cost terms, an inefficient or technically backward method of production or value adding may be referred to a mining company because of a rebate entitlement, whilst the more advanced, efficient or technically competent process may be jettisoned. This flawed approach really penalises those companies committed to innovation, product development and process improvement and has the real capacity to retard the ongoing introduction of state‐of‐the‐art technology. It is a regrettable example of public policy restraining the potential growth of leading edge and world-class firms.

In summary, it would be useful for the mining industry to have had some certainty for the future. There seems little rationale for the bill except cost savings. The process entered by the high‐level group and the Commonwealth seems to have had a worthwhile objective, if not a confused outcome. The DFR does appear to be the subject of a somewhat complex and cumbersome application. Capricious interference through the customs department seems to be accepted as a norm. One can only shudder at how this impacts upon industry planning. As Senator Murray outlined in his minority report at page 39:

There appears to be no rational process for the inclusion of certain minerals in the scheme and the exclusion of others. Salt, mined limestone, petroleum, rutile and kaolin rank amongst the losers. Copper, gold, uranium and alumina are winners.

In conclusion, I would recommend that both the Commonwealth and the high‐level group reactivate the negotiation process and that process concentrate on what they have identified as their core interests. In that way the diesel fuel rebate may survive as a legitimate business input cost and not be the subject of errant classification as business assistance or business subsidies by minority parties like the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996 (No. 2) deals with the diesel rebate for mining. It should be noted that there are effectively three diesel rebate schemes: the rebate for mining, that for farmers and pastoralists—in fact, all non-primary producers, including fishing and forestry—and the one for residential power use in remote areas, including some remote communities. This bill only relates to the mining rebate. I would like to make it clear that the Greens (WA) have quite different attitudes towards the various types of rebate. The amendments here really relate to what kinds of mining attract a rebate and which do not.

SPEECH.PARA: In the inevitable lobbying whenever we deal with the diesel rebate scheme, various interests have pushed for extensions of the mining rebate. While the Greens support the agri‐pastoral rebates, we do not support the rebate for mining. We will be putting forward amendments to phase that out. In line with that attitude, the Greens (WA) generally resisted extensions of the mining rebate.

Our approach has been to adjudge what is just and fair. For example, we opposed a retrospective extinction of the rebate a few years ago, although we were quite happy to support a prospective extinction of them and told the mining lobby so. In this debate, however, some miners have complained of injustice on the basis of various principles of what mining is. In our opinion, there are no real principles in operation about what is included and excluded in this bill. It is based on arbitrary decisions, regardless of what people indicate in speeches or statements.

BREAK.PARA: A certain amount of effort is being put in to try to define mineral as based on the need for extraction of something called a mineral from something else, which might be called an ore. Whilst this has a certain logic, it is not what this act says. `Mining for minerals' as a phrase does not imply this any more than `prospecting for minerals' or `exploration for minerals' does. The phrase `mining for minerals' occurs precisely where it is meant that mining, exploration and prospecting are all included in the definition of a mining activity.

It is the definition of mineral that is critical, but not usefully provided. The definition that does appear simply says that it could be a mineral as solid, liquid or gas and then excludes sand, water, clay, soil, gravel and other elements, which implies that they would have been included without this exclusion. By example, we have been approached on the basis that mining involves extraction of a mineral and that extraction of a mineral is, or should be, therefore, mining; that where such an extraction occurs it is not just to exclude an extractive industry.

But this is not the principle in law. Coal is not extracted from an ore. It is just dug up and used in that form. It is quarried under the stated principle. It is not a mineral in the sense that it is not constant or homogeneous. It varies with the pattern of vegetative decay in its formation, yet it is covered. Salt is not extracted from an ore. It is covered, although obviously we have some issues there. Limestone quarrying is not covered. Yet it is covered, but only where the limestone goes to farmers. This is not a principled system. It is an arbitrary one. Things are specified as either in or out.

In this regard, we do not feel that we are obliged to extend the rebate to cement producers. We do not feel obliged to extend the rebate to tenders for offshore rigs. The government and the Senate can or not as they like. There are no principles under which groups are being treated unjustly. They are simply excluded. Others are simply included. We might argue about whether we wish to include or exclude them, but no-one is in by right. The principle here seems to be that these are generally extractive industries involved in extracting non-renewable resources.

Why should we subsidise depletion of non-renewable resources? What is so special about them that we want to pay to have resources taken away? In many cases—bauxite, mineral sands, iron ore, gold—we have large portions of the world's economically recoverable deposits. Why do we need to provide special assistance for others to use it? Surely it is madness to build our economy on extraction of non-renewable resources? Surely it is counterproductive to fail to maximise our return for something the world wants, which is present in limited quantities. I say this without raising the question of what these limited resources are used for and what planetary impacts occur as a result of subsidising consumption and waste of our physical resource heritage.

If we decide to use subsidies to promote the economy and jobs, why subsidise this industry? What goals is the government seeking to achieve? If it is employment, this is certainly a low employment industry per unit of investment. How is government or taxpayer largess distributed and on what basis? Manufacturers do not get a diesel subsidy for transporting their goods or running a generator or whatever. Why is that? What is the justice of that? Which employers are subsidised and why?

There seems to be little rationale and little justice here. It is simply a decision that the previous government made and the coalition went along with it—or sort of. Where is the debate and the rationale about what kinds of industries we want and what industries are best able to meet communities' wants and needs? These are social and economic decisions, the kinds of decisions many people still expect a responsible government to consider. They are political decisions, and ones that look beyond how governments can assist big corporations to maximise profits. This kind of debate has largely disappeared in Australia.

We should be sharing in a community vision of a more socially and ecologically sustainable future. But, instead, we have a great policy abyss, which is the result of a blind belief by government of the international free market ideology. The Greens (WA) disagree with the emphasis that puts international competitiveness above all other values. There are other choices, such as increased regional self-reliance, less dependence on low-value exports, more import replacement, more industries involved in value adding—all within a context of sustaining the ecology, finding solutions to global problems, improving social amenity, more efficient use of energy and resources and, particularly, more reliance on renewable energy, reduced use of non-renewable resources and reduced use of renewable resources, especially where they are being used close to, or beyond, their rate of renewal.

The human impact on this planet is increasing logarithmically. For most of human history, natural forces dwarfed or overrode human activity. But from the point where we learned to use tools and precipitated Pleistocene overkill, a large number of the large species present at that time were wiped out. Human agricultural and logging activity in other areas resulted in significant desertification in northern Africa, the Tigris-Euphrates, and the south‐western deserts of the United States—all occurring over 2,000 years ago. Scientific literature has pointed out that only in the recent past can human activity really be considered equivalent to a geological force in terms of its shifting of material, mainly minerals, and its impact on global atmosphere and aquatic systems.

In 1800, that is less than 200 years ago, the global human population is estimated to have been under one billion. It has been only about 100 years since the internal combustion engine, the use of petroleum, the car, and the electric generator became significant. It has been 100 years since the use of radio, telephones and the first sound recording devices. In 1890, the population of the planet was about 1½ billion. For most people in the world—the peoples of Africa, Asia, South and Central America—these technological innovations and their associated products were not widely in use until the last few decades. For well over half the world's population, they are still not being used.

It has been in only the last 50 years that we have seen really wide scale and effective exploitation of the fish populations of the oceans. It has been in the last 25 years that we have seen a dramatic collapse of several pelagic fish species. It has been about 50 years since the first major transnational corporations began to shift mineral resources for processing in a truly global way.

It has been only about 50 years since the wide scale use of chemicals in agriculture, pharmaceuticals, food, and production has become common. It has been only 50 years since they entered the ecosystem, our food chains, our atmosphere and our oceans to any large extent. We have seen dramatic change in climate, change in incident solar radiation, changes affecting the formation of birds' eggs, and changes in the growth of plants, the survival of fish and aquatic plants, and the respiration of algae. We have seen DDT, PCBs, and CFCs, photochemical smog, cyclodienes, acid rain and global warming. All these are extremely recent on the scale of human existence or ecological time in terms of global impacts.

Humans have seen increases in cancers; we have seen growing problems with chemical sensitivities, immune system faults and major increases in technology‐related diseases. In 1950, there were still only about 2¼ billion people on the planet; around four‐fifths of these people remained users of pre‐industrial technologies. The impact of modern technology was the impact experienced from its use by about 300,000 people.

It has been about 50 years since television began to be common anywhere and there have been 50 years of radar and 40 years of UHF broadcasting. It has been about 25 years since the advent of personal computers and photocopy machines, and under 10 years since the advent of mobile and cordless phones. In the last 50 years, we have been in a period of wildly accelerated environmental exposure to chemicals and electromagnetic fields.

The population of the planet is now nearly six billion. An increasing number of people are not only using modern technology but are dependent upon it. Worldwatch Institute believes that soon it will be impossible to feed the population without general, almost universal, use of modern chemical or mechanical agriculture. It warns that this is not sustainable nor is future population growth sustainable for long in terms of available food. Our food resources—a renewable resource—are being used faster than is sustainable.

We are mining our soil; it is dependent on petroleum‐fuelled agriculture. Major global petroleum experts estimate that global oil production is peaking and will soon decline and become markedly more expensive. This is a major threat to providing the food to sustain a population where millions of people each year already die from a lack of food. In part, this translates to the lack of ability to afford food and the lack of resources to produce their own food in sufficient quantities. We already see famine creating a class of environmental refugees and interacting with conflict within and between nations.

It has been about 35 years since Rachel Carson wrote Silent Spring, Von Forster published his population article and, generally, environmental issues attained prominence. Green thinking has really developed from that point. It is 25 years since the Tasmanian Greens became the world's first green party. Since then, we have seen green parties with the same core values arise in many nations around the world and at all levels of political activity.

Contrary to those who claim that the greens want people to starve in the cold and dark, it is clear to anyone examining green thought that most greens are not Luddites or misanthropes. The basic premise of green thinking is that we must look open‐eyed at the future and adapt ourselves, create limits for ourselves and develop technological and social structures that will allow all people—and their children, grandchildren and great‐great‐grandchildren—to live in relative harmony with each other and nature; to have what they need to form rich lives; and to foster a peaceful, tolerant and more equitable society, one in which all members of the community take an active part in determining the social frameworks for our future. This is the meaning of the four pillars of green politics; that is, ecological sustainability, social equity, peace and participatory democracy.

For decades now green thinkers have proposed solutions and pointed to the technologies that would enable us to retain a developed way of life without destroying the life systems, biodiversity and beauty of the world around us. Often these were ways that would require a major re‐orientation and commitment—including capital commitment—but which would result in transformations that would see us better off, with more options and lower ultimate maintenance costs. It is difficult to re‐orient the direction of sociotechnical development. The greens have been cognisant of that and have stressed the need to act early, phase in and make the transition as easy as possible. We have stressed the need for urgent action, in part to reduce the costs of transition. We have said again and again that if we wait until we are forced by events to address these problems, the costs will be horrendous.

We now see the outcome in relation to greenhouse emissions. After years and years of Australian governments ignoring the calls to create a viable policy, after years of pursuing policies to attract energy intensive industries without addressing the need to come up with cleaner energy sources, the current government is now trying to undermine the global response to greenhouse and, in case that fails, it is trying to claim exemption on the basis that we should be pitied because we use too much energy, and it would cost us money to do our part, so we shouldn't need to.

In this regard, we will put an amendment to end the subsidy of energy use to fuel the cheap use of non‐renewable resources. We have options in this country other than digging it up, cutting it down or killing it and shipping it all away and seeing the profits shipped away with it by the transnationals that own these mainly low‐labour, low‐employment industries.

If we want to provide public subsidies to industry, I would like to see us move towards creating a sustainable energy industry here. We could vastly improve our impacts on the planet in the process. But, guess what? In the budget a substantial chunk was cut from the Energy Research and Development Corporation funding, and the national energy efficiency program is being wound up—tiny amounts compared with the massive handouts to some of our largest energy consumers.

There is a future for sustainable energy, for devices that make use of sun, wind, tide and co‐generation. There is a major global market for this, particularly if the international community manages to put hard targets on greenhouse emissions. We used to be world leaders in these areas.

There is another entire market for making goods that allow energy to be conserved and used efficiently. These industries are in manufacturing, design, contracting and areas with high value‐added components and potentially high levels of employment. If we went so far as to challenge the road‐ freight and private car structure, we could reduce the ultimate imports of oil we will soon have to have. We would have another system with associated manufacturing technologies to sell in places like Bangkok, Bombay and Beijing.

There are implicit agendas; there may be principles we make decisions on, whether or not we recognise them. In this place, we are actively creating the future, particularly where we support one industry or activity over another. The Greens have opposed spending roughly a billion dollars a year subsidising energy use and digging up our resources to sell them cheaply. We do not believe that the Australian community is helped by promoting extractive industries over manufacturing and we do not believe that taxpayers are getting any fair return on the billion dollars they are giving to the mining industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to speak in this debate on the issue of cement in particular because of the interest in Queensland in the mining of limestone. Limestone, of course, is used predominantly in the cement manufacturing, flux and smelting of lead and copper. The industry is not an insignificant contributor to the Australian economy: it employs some 2,600 people, has fixed assets of over a billion dollars and a tax on profit last year, I believe, of in excess of $62 million. The industry mines limestone for the sole purpose of recovering the mineral calcite, or calcium, from what is a naturally occurring raw material.

SPEECH.PARA: The industry enjoyed the diesel fuel rebate, as we have heard already in this debate, prior to legislation in July 1995. However, arising out of legislation in that year there was confusion as to the application of the DFR to certain industries. That was later clarified by the then Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction in a letter dated 9 August 1995. The letter, in part, says:

. . . rebate is no longer payable on diesel fuel purchased on or after 1 July 1995 for use in the extraction of limestone per se, as the law now clearly excludes limestone, amongst other things, from the definition of `minerals'. However, the law continues to allow rebate to be paid where an activity can be said to be `mining for minerals' and does not simply constitute the extraction of the now excluded materials.
It went on—and this is the crux of the letter:

Therefore, the legal test is whether the activities of a claimant are carried out with a view to recovering from the limestone ore, a mineral or minerals such as calcium carbonate (or calcite). If this is the case, then the rebate is payable.

Whilst there was some comfort gained from that, with the change of government there was a further item of correspondence, which was referred to in the debate earlier this evening, dated 16 October from the current Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs, Mr Prosser. It is most confusing because it says that:
