Most quarrying materials previously eligible for diesel fuel rebate became ineligible on 1 July 1995. The only materials presently eligible are limestone for use in de‐acidification of soil in agriculture and materials from which the mineral content is extracted, such as rutile.

Therein lies the dilemma—just in that letter itself. Really, the cement miners maintain that there is an extraction process anyway from the limestone and it should therefore attract and retain the diesel fuel rebate. The minister's letter went on:

While the government is presently considering further changes in eligibility, particularly in the mining sector, these are directed at containing eligibility. Budget circumstances preclude consideration of proposals to widen eligibility or re‐instate activities which may have received the rebate previously.

What we have is a debate about whether or not limestone used in cement should attract the DFR and, if so, whether it is proper that these people should receive the DFR. I believe this has been subject to court action and the courts are currently trying to deal with it. Whilst the courts are still trying to deal with this issue we now have legislation before the Senate which seeks to exclude these people from any further chance of accessing the DFR.

It is interesting to look at the inquiry conducted by the Economics Legislation Committee into this particular legislation. It clearly establishes there the confusion that reigns. In the minority report my colleagues have clearly outlined the position and, for posterity, it is worth going through some of those key points. Point No. 6 in the minority report says:
This Inquiry has revealed that the actual basis for this Bill is an Agreement struck between a High Level Group (HLG) and a Government negotiating committee . . .
So that was the basis, we are led to believe from this report, of the legislation that is before us. As you read down in the minority report, at point No. 9 one sees that:
All of the Industry Associations testified that the Bill explicitly dishonoured the agreement reached.

Here we have a breakdown between the industry group and the government. As my colleague, Senator Bishop, said before, this is a most unfortunate aspect of what has taken place in this particular case. The report goes on to talk about the areas in dispute:

. . . there remain areas of continuing dispute. For example, the Government contends that the Industry agreed in the HLG that the Salt Industry would not be included in the rebate. Industry strongly reject this. They claim that their position has always been that the Salt Industry is entitled to remain eligible.
Further down it talks about government involvement:
. . . the Minister for Customs unilaterally and without consultation, with the industry varied the Agreement . . .
No wonder there is dissatisfaction. No wonder there are problems with this piece of legisla tion that the government has brought here on this occasion. Point No. 12 in the minority report says:
While the HLG appears to have been broadly representative of mining interests, it did not represent, nor did it purport to represent the Cement Industry.
That point further says:
. . . the concern of the Cement Industry to continue to be eligible to claim the rebate has been set aside by the Government.
That sets the framework in which this legislation has appeared in this chamber. It is interesting to note that the conclusion drawn in the minority report says:
It is clear that the Cement Industry mine limestone in order to break down that raw material and obtain Calcinite as a key ingredient in the manufacture of cement.
It goes on:

It is also clear that this industry has previously had an entitlement to receive the rebate. That entitlement is on hold at the present time because of legal action to reassert it in the face of the withdrawal of the rebate by Customs from some, not all, Cement operations.
They go on to say:
I note that Customs, on learning that some cement operations received the rebate, indicated to the Committee that it would withdraw the entitlement from all Cement companies.

That is like saying: `We are now going to take our bat and ball and stumps and go off, and that is your bad luck; you will have to play on the field without any equipment.' The minority report says at point 7:

It would appear that the Customs decision with respect to the Cement Industry has been spurred by the obligation placed on it by the Government to make savings in the scheme rather than the Cement Industry's right to eligibility.

That is the real nub of this debate. It seems to be about a disagreement between the government and the industry. It seems that the cement industry are finding themselves out on a limb. In the face of real challenges to their industry, they are seeking to claw back something which makes their industry viable. This is supported in their submission to the Senate Economics Legislation Committee. It is worthwhile noting, looking at the degree of expenditure over a 10-year period in my state alone, that some $26 million has been invest ed by Queensland Cement Ltd in Gladstone in the processing and manufacture of cement. The Cement Industry Federation's submission says:

The potential for surplus capacity in the South East Asian region over the coming years will expose the Australian Cement Industry to the threat of placement of larger quantities of imported cement. Existing anti-dumping legislation in Australia will not serve to protect the domestic industry in the event that Asian economies can produce cement at a lower cost.

Any additional imposts make the task all the more difficult. The potential loss of the diesel fuel rebate further increases the load and widens the competitive gap between Australia and our South East Asian competitors.

Clearly, this is about the viability of a major industry in my state. I did at the outset outline that there are $1 billion of assets in this industry, which employs more than 2,600 people Australia-wide. So we are not talking about a small employer or a small industry. If there were a competitive edge that gave this industry a degree of viability, it was access to the diesel fuel rebate. They seem to have been excluded in the debate to a substantial extent by the HLG itself and also by the government.

So these people have, in my view, a real gripe and a real axe to grind with the government on this legislation. The government has not thought this out well. It is patchy at best. It is about time the government took a close look at the impact of this legislation, stopped trying to pick winners in this game—whether it be the mining industry or the farming industry—and looked at doing something positive for the maintenance of the competitiveness of the cement industry.
It is interesting to look further at the views as outlined in the letter by the Association of Mining and Exploration Companies to members of the Senate, which piece of correspondence says:
AMEC believes however that the legislation still does not go far enough.

Of course, this is after there has been a supposed consultation between the HLG and the government and those people who may well have been disaffected by the govern ment's decision. The letter then goes on to say:

AMEC seeks your assistance in this matter so as to ensure that the reduction in the mining industry's eligibility to access the DFRS is limited only to those items listed in the agreement reached in the high level negotiations last year. Until that time it is our view that the CELA Bill (No. 2) 1996 is a breach of the agreement and will have a significant negative impact on the international competitiveness of the Australian mining industry.
Surely the government is going to take note of that sort of plea coming out of industry. They go on to say:
Government has indeed not kept faith with the mining industry in that, following the agreement, it sought to attain its objectives by stealth.
Nothing can be more damning than those words coming out of AMEC, which obviously has a great interest in seeing that the DFR is applied equitably throughout the mining industry.

So in summary, I believe that what I have put to the chamber here this evening warrants the government not pursuing its current legislation. In Senator McGauran's contribution to the debate he talked about how important the mining industry was. He talked about any increase in costs being the death knell of the industry. I can only echo and support those words because I think in that respect he is quite correct. Justice has to be done for the cement industry. The DFR has to be reinstated so that the cement industry can remain competitive in the Australian marketplace and can continue to operate as a major contributor to the Australian economy and, in particular, to the Queensland economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in this second reading debate on the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996, which I suppose euphemistically could be described as the diesel fuel rebate scheme debate. I rise to speak not at any length. It is not my area of shadow ministry responsibility, but I could not help but become involved by saying a few words in this debate as a former customs minister in the previous government who dealt with this scheme and made recom mendations in I think the 1995 budget about changes to the diesel fuel rebate scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: When I proposed certain changes, which were very modest compared with what this government is putting up today as far as the effect on expenditure is concerned—it was a few hundred thousand dollars in some cases or a few million dollars in other cases—I do not think that in any particular area did I propose changes that were to rake in tens of millions of dollars or hundreds of millions of dollars in expenditure in relation to the diesel fuel rebate scheme.

There was one particular aspect for which I sought support from the Senate: the need for some retrospective legislation to stop an appeal by three major construction companies in Australia—CRA, Boral and Pioneer—who were claiming between them, as a result of an AAT determination, up to about $80 million going back to 1986 or 1987. This was a real try-on. I asked the Senate to support legislation so that these companies would not be able to claim that. They had already spent the money in running the projects. They had already paid for the diesel. This was a try-on by some consultants who said to them, `If we win this case, give us our percentage cut,' which I imagine would have been quite sizeable.

When I proposed that in this Senate, I was roundly attacked by National and Liberal Party members for doing something outrageous in relation to retrospectivity. In the end, I could not convince a majority of the Senate in relation to that and the retrospectivity was lost. My last recollection is that the AAT decision was overturned in the Federal Court, but I suspect a challenge is before the High Court at the moment because of the amount of money at stake. I certainly support the customs department fighting that case all the way through.

I was roundly attacked as doing something really evil about retrospectivity in this area. Then we looked at ways to tighten up some definitions which were very much based on previous Auditor-General's reports and general comments around the place about the looseness of the administration, which is not Customs' fault. This scheme is almost impossible to administer accurately and in a way that guarantees that the policy intent of government and parliament is carried out and that all claims, totalling I think between $1,200 million and $1,300 million, if not $1,400 million, can accurately be said to have been claimed for the legitimate purpose for which the scheme was established.

When I made recommendations in those areas—the debate went on, I think, for several days—I was roundly condemned that this was an attack on the mining industry, on farmers and on the productive capacity of Australia. The senators who led the charge in this place were the late Senator John Panizza, Senator Crane, Senator McGauran, other National Party senators and Senator Ferguson. They were the most vociferous about this being an evil and terrible thing I was doing on behalf of the government to tighten up eligibility that may save the taxpayers of Australia a few million dollars and no more.

I look forward to hearing Senator Crane and other Liberal Party senators and National Party senators who were so vociferous in their remarks only two years ago justify these changes to this scheme that are going to save, under one estimation I have seen, $660 million over four years, with a minimum of $110 million plus per annum.

When I read the second reading speech provided by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator Campbell), I find that all the reasons given for justifying this are the same ones I gave to save $10 million or $15 million. The Auditor-General's reports—I think there have been four or five over a decade or more—were dismissed by Senator Crane, Senator Ferguson and the late Senator John Panizza as irrelevant in this administration. Now this government comes in here and quotes pages of Auditor-General reports to justify their saving $110 million plus per annum in the diesel fuel rebate scheme.

When I had the temerity to point out in Senate estimates hearings as well as in this chamber to the taxpayers of Australia that this scheme was growing at a rate of hundreds of millions of dollars per annum and that people ought to understand that this is a major expenditure item for the Australian taxpayer, I was again accused by those senators opposite of trying to undermine the scheme and undermine the mining and rural industries of Australia.

Senators from our side have spoken most eloquently about the way in which the industry is being dudded in the negotiations as the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) have driven a program to make savings from this scheme. I suggest that, if we had tried two years ago to make a minimum saving of $110 million a year from the diesel fuel rebate scheme by doing a number of the things that are being suggested in this bill, Senator Crane, Senator Ferguson and Senator Panizza would have physically taken action against us. They would have screamed the roof off in this place and gone around Australia even further than they had, saying what a dreadful government this was. Now we find dead silence, utter silence, from those senators opposite who shouted and screamed in an hysterical way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the dinner break I was pointing out the hypocrisy of a number of members of the government who, when in opposition in 1995, were making very strong, bitter and hysterical attacks, in my view, on a proposal I had as minister for customs to change some administrative matters that would have saved revenue of only a few million dollars at the most. As I pointed out before the dinner break, this was attacked as though this was a wholesale attack by the government on the viability of the mining industry and, in particular, farming in Australia. They were hysterical attacks, but they were used with considerable political effect and a number of my amendments were defeated—although a number were carried, despite the bitter opposition from some senators opposite.

SPEECH.PARA: As I pointed out before dinner, we now have a bill before us in which, in various estimates—whether you look in the second reading speech, the explanatory memorandum or the government's own budget documents—you could calculate there are savings to the government over the next four years of over $600 million, which is certainly over $150 million per annum. Another estimation is that it could be just over $100 million. Whichever way you look at it, they are significant and substantial changes to this scheme.

I look forward to the justification from senators like Senator Crane, Senator Ferguson and National Party senators who were so vociferous in their opposition when only a few changes were made. As I pointed out, the justification in the second reading speech by the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser) was to quote the Auditor-General's report. When I quoted that, it was ignored at the time as not being relevant. All the arguments I used for a few million dollars worth of savings have now been used by the government to reduce expenditure on diesel fuel rebate by some $600 million over four years.

There is no doubt, and I accept the fact, that, in any fiscal planning, when you have a program that has grown in 1983-84 from under $200 million to now $1,400 million or $1,500 million and it may reach $2 billion by the year 2000 in revenue forgone, no government is going to be able to ignore the consequences of such expenditure. I only wish the members opposite had the good grace to at least apologise for what they said in 1995, compared with what they are now putting to the parliament.

The opposition will be moving a second reading amendment at the vote on the second reading. I look forward to participating in some aspects of the committee stage of this bill when we start dealing with definitions, where, as they say, the devil is in the detail on these matters. I will look forward, in particular, to listening to Senator Crane and Senator Ferguson use the same words as they did two years ago in attacking my legislation to now defend the government, which is taking a much larger sum out of the program and is doing so in a way that clearly, by all the evidence I have seen, has even dudded the industry groups who were involved in discussions through 1996 and into early 1997.

This bill really proves that, even if you are in opposition for a long time, you should try to maintain some consistency about how you argue fiscal and expenditure matters. If you do not, it will always come back to haunt you when you become the government. That is the main reason why I wanted to speak in this second reading debate. It is with some ironic amusement that I look at members opposite in the government now justifying a much bigger change to diesel fuel rebate than they were ever willing to support when in opposition.
Debate (on motion by Senator Ellison) adjourned.

BREAK.XREF: HEARING SERVICES AND AGHS REFORM BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 March, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation before the Senate is the Hearing Services Administration Bill and the Hearing Services and AGHS Reform Bill 1997. The position of the opposition is that we are opposed to this legislation. We are opposed to this legislation for very good reasons. In particular, it is our view that what the government has in mind here—namely, to make changes to the operations of Australian Hearing Services to exclude certain clients from being able to access those services—is simply unnecessary. Secondly, the proposal to corporatise Australian Hearing Services is one which we believe is not necessary and indeed is contrary to the public interest.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand from the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services (Senator Ellison) who is at the table that the government will be moving certain amendments later which relate to the original proposal to reduce the qualifying age from 21 years to 18 years. That would have had the effect of excluding, as clients able to access the services available under the scheme, persons between the ages of 18 and 21 years.

I understand that on review, and no doubt due to the persuasive arguments put by the opposition senators on the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee, and due to the opposition from people involved in the provision of assistance to those who have impaired hearing, the government has revised their position and will no longer proceed with that proposal. That is a very welcome move by the government, we would say. It demonstrates that, as we said at the outset, this legislation was ill‐conceived, it was rushed, it was not properly thought through and it would have harsh consequences for certain groups within the community, one of those groups being students, school leavers and others between the ages of 18 and 21 years. There are still aspects of this legislation which the opposi tion believes make it contrary to the public interest and should, therefore, be opposed.

I indicated a moment ago that this legislation was rushed. As was pointed out in the other place by the shadow minister, Mr Lee, on 26 February, this legislation was put on the Notice Paper and introduced the same day—on 5 February—with the intention that it would operate from 1 March this year. That was a totally unreasonable proposition for the government to put forward and one which clearly would not have allowed sufficient time for the public, particularly those involved in the health sector and, indeed, the parliament, to give it adequate scrutiny. So from the outset the legislation had the major and fundamental flaw that it was clearly rushed legislation.

The major impacts of the legislation go to four specific areas which can be looked at as essentially two major proposals. The four key impacts of the legislation were, firstly, as I have said, to remove access for 18‐ to 21‐year‐olds. That will apparently be addressed by an amendment to delete that proposed change from the bill. The second major area of impact, and therefore public concern, was that the legislation proposed that persons currently eligible under the scheme because they hold senior health care cards would no longer be eligible.

BREAK.PARA: The third major impact of the proposed legislation was the introduction of a voucher system whereby the minister, through the department, would oversee a system of clients being issued with vouchers with which they could then seek to have services provided from either Australian Hearing Services or some other private sector provider. Fourthly, the proposed legislation seeks to corporatise Australian Hearing Services leading, we would suggest, to its ultimate privatisation in the future.

They are the four key areas of the proposed bills but, as I said, they fall into two broad categories: firstly, those proposed changes which remove entitlements from certain groups within the community, namely young people between 18 and 21 years of age and persons holding senior health care cards; and, secondly, the issue of corporatisation and ultimate privatisation of AHS. The legislation was appropriately referred to the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee which considered the bill and handed down its report in March of this year. I would urge all honourable senators to read that report and particularly to take note of the minority or dissenting report of the opposition, and also, in certain aspects, the Australian Democrats.

The report clearly acknowledges the impacts that these proposals were going to have upon client groups in the community and also upon the continued operation of Australian Hearing Services. I do not need to go through all the arguments advanced during the committee's deliberations. Other speakers who will follow me who were members of the committee when the legislation was looked at will no doubt address them.

What I want to say—and to reiterate—is that once practitioners, affected parties and senators had a chance to look at the impact of the legislation as it affected young people, it became clear that it was a pretty stupid proposal in the first place. The government had said that this legislation was going to improve cost‐effectiveness and efficiency. Yet it also said that the overall impact would be cost neutral.

Clearly, now that the government has recognised the error of its way in proposing to exclude 18‐ to 21‐year‐old young people, now that it has recognised that that proposal was wrong and will now withdraw it, it has acknowledged that the original cost saving for that proposal was only of the order of half a million dollars. A very small amount was going to be saved by that measure, notwithstanding the fact that many young people were likely to be affected as a result of it. While I applaud the government for having come to its senses on that proposal, I have to say that it is something that should never have been there in the first place.

The other issue is the one that I have highlighted, namely, the proposal to corporatise Australian Hearing Services. It is noted that, overall, there are no net savings to Commonwealth expenditure from this measure or, indeed, from the legislation in total. As the opposition senators said in the minority report, we do not oppose corporatisation for the sake of it. Indeed, when we were in government, we were on occasion criticised for some of the decisions that we made with respect to the corporatisation—or the eventual privatisation—of government instrumentalities. I understand that, and accept it.

But there comes a time where, rather than jumping in holus‐bolus—as this government would—on an agenda of corporatisation and/or privatisation, you have to look at the service itself and its effectiveness and determine whether or not it is doing what it is supposed to do. This government has caught the corporatisation‐privatisation disease and is—as in this legislation—proposing to divest itself of its involvement in these entities without giving any consideration to their effectiveness.
I would like to conclude on this point by referring to the committee's report—pages 13 and 14, in particular—where the Labor senators put the position most appropriately. The report states:

The second aspect of this bill is the administrative changes and corporatisation of the AHS. The first step is to split the two functions of the AHS being regulator and service provider. The regulatory functions will be transferred to a new body and the service provision will be retained by the AHS. We are not in principle opposed to this division but the benefits of corporatisation appear questionable when the additional costs of restructuring and duplication of administration are provided by the cutting of benefits to the deaf and hearing impaired.
Further on the report states:

The Australian Hearing Service points out that the cost efficiency and effectiveness of the AHS has been independently audited and verified by the Australian national Audit Office and the Centre for National Economics. "To date the cost to the taxpayer of AHS direct services has been significantly less than that of comparable private sector services."

The Deafness Forum of Australia said in its submission that the AHS has been instrumental in setting and improving the quality and standards of services provided by audiometrists in Australia, and has worked to improve training in audiometry and to have better hearing technology developed and manufactured in Australia. The Deafness Forum wants to see existing services maintained, and this will not necessarily be achieved by the private sector.

Because of its buying power, its ability to buy in large quantities, the AHS is able to provide batteries at a 33 per cent and hearing aids at a 50 per cent discount on what people would pay privately. AHS hearing aids are provided to people at a price that is $400 lower on average than private sector providers. This represents a massive saving to most people.

The Centre for International Economics said that not only were the AHS' costs per new adult client lower than the fee paid for private sector services, but the AHS kept its prices well below the OECD average.

The AHS' joint venture with Australian Hearing Aids Pty Ltd means the AHS is not having to import hearing aids and is creating highly skilled jobs and foreign investment, sales and exports in high quality hearing aids and devices worth $200 million.

Corporatisation of services is certainly beneficial where greater efficiencies can be achieved. In this instance, the Australian Hearing Services is providing an efficient, cost effective and high quality service to Australian taxpayers, the deaf and hearing impaired and the Government. It is also helping generate skilled employment and Australian export and development in hearing technology. There is no evidence that this change to the structure of AHS will increase the efficiency or quality of the service.

I have not heard from the government that they challenge the fact that AHS is cost effective and that they challenge that summary of what AHS contributes, firstly, to improving the hearing ability of those people unfortunate enough to be hearing impaired but, secondly, does so in a way which is cost effective for the taxpayer and for the government.

One has to ask why it is that the government would want to corporatise, to privatise such a service. Why would they want to introduce a system which clearly, firstly, will be disadvantageous to certain client groups, particularly those on seniors health care cards but, secondly, brings with it the clear prospect of a less efficient, less uniform, less beneficial system for those people in need of these services. The opposition does not support this legislation and it will be opposing it in due course.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The two bills that we are considering today, the Hearing Services Administration Bill 1997 and the Hearing Services and AGHS Reform Bill 1997, will bring about very significant changes to the provision of hearing services within this country.

SPEECH.PARA: These bills facilitate several of the measures which were outlined in the 1996‐97 budget, including the introduction of a voucher system for the delivery of government funded hearing services; the introduction of managed competition between the government and the private sectors in relation to the provision of hearing services; the introduction of full commercial practices to the Australian Hearing Services; and the corporatisation of the Australian Government Health Service.

The Hearing Services and AGHS Reform Bill also removes the eligibility of seniors health cardholders for government funded hearing services and it lowers the eligibility age limit for young people from 21 to 18 years of age—although, as I understand it, the government will be moving an amendment tonight which will restore the full range of hearing services to young people between 18 and 21. The Democrats were pleased to see that the report of Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee was taken on board to some degree by the government and that it has decided to reverse its previous decision to remove the eligibility of young people in that age group. It is refreshing to see that, at least on this measure, commonsense, it appears, will prevail.

BREAK.PARA: We think this is an important win for young hearing impaired people because it means that the government seems to be acknowledging the many additional obstacles that these young people face during their formative and educational years. These additional obstacles mean that most young people who are hearing impaired are far more likely to complete their formal education at a later age than their non‐hearing impaired counterparts. This also means that young people who are deaf are much more likely to enter the work force and begin to earn their own income at an older age as well.

For these reasons, the Democrats will be happy to support the government's amendments to this section of the bill. We are, however, disappointed to see that the government does not intend to move an amendment to restore the eligibility of seniors health cardholders to government funded hearing services. Removing eligibility for seniors health cardholders flies in the face of the coalition's pre‐budget social security policy which was `to maintain all current Commonwealth concessions'. It is very difficult to understand why the government would want to break one of these election promises when the full extent of the savings to be derived from this measure, by the government's own figures is, as I understand it, zero dollars. So with the saving of zero dollars, the Democrats do not see how this little measure can be justified and we will be supporting the ALP's amendments to fully restore the eligibility of seniors health cardholders to hearing services.

While the Democrats view the move to corporatise hearing services in Australia with some degree of caution, we are not surprised at all by the course that this government is taking. It is very much in line with stated policy goals and the policies we have seen introduced in other areas. However, we urge the government to closely monitor and to evaluate the effects of these reforms once they are put in place and to ensure that all community service obligations continue to be met by the Australian Hearing Services.

The Democrats will not be opposing Part 2 of the Hearing Services and AGHS Reform Bill, which sets up transitional provisions for the corporatisation of the Australian Government Health Service. However, I do want to make a few comments about the corporatisation of the AGHS. We have supported the corporatisation of statutory authorities when we have felt a real benefit will result from the process. While I could not say the arguments in support of the corporatisation of the AGHS are compelling, it is a fact that this organisation has been operating as a business unit—on a full cost recovery basis—within the Department of Family Services and Health for some years. As such, there seems also to be no especially compelling reason for not corporatising it.

Of course, we all know that the process commenced under this bill—that of establishing a government business enterprise—is usually the precursor to full privatisation. I think the minister should be a bit more forthright about the government's intentions in this regard because what is happening here is that an element of uncertainty is being introduced into this area. Whilst I would not be so concerned about the privatisation of some aspects of the AGHS, I would be very concerned about the loss to the public sector of some of the expertise, for instance, which has accumulated within the AGHS.

We are currently seeing the effects of the winding back of public health inspectors and health inspection functions around this country. The health consequences could be equally disastrous if the AGHS was privatised and the government completely gave away its capacity to conduct health and medical assessments. For example, as I understand it the AGHS currently carries out asbestos screening for former and civilian members of the armed forces and, as of fairly recently, for World War II merchant mariners. That seems to me to be an important function which could not necessarily be provided at a reasonable cost in a private sector environment to those who need it most.

The flip side of that, of course, is that a corporatised AGHS may very well be able to market this particular kind of assessment as being something in which it has expertise and for which it may develop a clientele. I do not think it is any secret that the AGHS has not always enjoyed the greatest of reputations. Many people, particularly in the disability sector, have long been critical of the AGHS's processes, medical staff and standards of service. I know that a number of people in the disability services sector are not unhappy about the AGHS being corporatised and the idea of federal and state departments having a greater choice in who, or what services, provides their health assessments.

So, in short, while the Democrats express some reservations about where the AGHS corporatisation may end up, we will not be opposing these transitional amendments. However, I do want to make the point that the Democrats have been very unhappy with the loss of accountability which usually accompanies corporatisation. What we often end up with is a body which is still wholly owned by the taxpayers of Australia but for which the federal government is no longer accountable and for which the minister no longer accepts any responsibility.

The corporatised body often no longer has any requirement placed upon it to act in the public interest and has no or few service obligations to low income or disadvantaged clients. It often ends up being a rather secretive and shadowy agency for which, at the end of the day, nobody takes much responsibility. You can look no further than the AIDC or the ADI for examples.

We all know that the people most likely to benefit from corporatisations are senior managers who transfer from fully public bodies to the corporatised body and then on to the private body, usually presiding over reductions in services along the way and a hike in fees as well.

So the Democrats have not supported, and do not support, corporatisations where such a loss of accountability and transparency occurs. I place this government on notice that we will not support those outcomes when later legislation relating to this corporatisation comes to the Senate.

There are a couple of matters which have come to my attention just today. The first is the implications of this bill for health and, in particular, the use of hearing aid technicians and the additional costs of providing such paramedical staff with adequate supervision. The second is the impact this legislation will have on our local and very successful hearing aid manufacturing business. Neither of these issues was canvassed during the inquiry into this legislation a couple of months ago. But they have emerged. These are two matters I put on notice to the government that I will ask quite a few questions about once we move into the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibbs, Sen Brenda

TALK.START.PARA: —The Hearing Services Administration Bill proposes significant changes to the way in which hearing services are delivered in the future. It will ensure that those people who need and who can afford hearing aids will be fine, but those who are on low incomes will end up on long waiting lists and others, like students, will miss out altogether. We now know that the government has reviewed their position, but it is important to put on the record what this legislation would have meant.

SPEECH.PARA: How many students can afford $3,000 to $5,000 to pay for two hearing aids and then pay $100 to $150 per year for batteries as well as hundreds of dollars whenever repairs are needed? I do not know too many students or young people who can afford those sorts of costs.

The Deafness Forum of Australia has received a great deal of reaction to the prospect of 18‐, 19‐ and 20-year-olds having to bear these costs themselves. The Deafness Forum has said that the community is very worried about this aspect of the legislation in particular. According to the 1996 budget, the saving on making 18‐ to 21-year-olds ineligible for government hearing services is just half a million dollars. This very small saving for the government is surely not worth the angst it will cause in the community and the difficulties for dependent students who already have to overcome their hearing disability to complete their high school or tertiary studies.

Tertiary students already have HECS fees which will have to be paid in the future because most students cannot afford to pay the fees up front. Now they will have an extra fee which they will not be able to defer, even though they may not be able to afford it. According to the Deafness Forum—the government should be aware of this as these figures were part of a submission to the hearing services bills inquiry by the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee—there are currently around 2,500 to 3,000 clients of the government's hearing services program who are in the age group of 18 to 21. About 800 of these are provided with services in any one year. The cost of servicing these 800 clients is about $250,000 per year or less. Not everyone needs full cost services each year, and many merely need maintenance.

What this government is doing is putting at risk the ability of these students to complete their education—an education, if the government can create enough jobs, which will lead to jobs for these students that will make them self-sufficient members of society. We have here a group of people with disabilities who have an excellent chance of leading productive lives, and this government plans to put impediments in their way. Where is the logic in this? It seems as if no government minister thought to ask Treasury that question when this ridiculous slash was made in the budget process.

Would the government prefer to see these people forced to give up their education and become reliant on the government for assistance? How many of these 18- to 21-year‐old students are still completing their secondary education because their disability has hampered the progress of their education? Because of this factor, these students deserve extra consideration.

One of the first witnesses at the Senate inquiry on the Hearing Services Administration Bill 1997 and the Hearing Services and AGHS Reform Bill 1997 was a 22-year‐old woman who was completely reliant on her hearing aid or her lip reading abilities. Her name was Amanda Moir. With the assistance of her hearing aid, she has been able to complete her HSC, is in her third year of an associate diploma of child care and works in a centre for hearing impaired children from three to five years of age. She has done extremely well and is obviously making a very positive contribution to the community in general and to those with a disability like hers. She does, however, have very serious reservations about the threat to cut assistance to 18‐ to 21‐year‐olds with a hearing disability.

Since the age of four, her mother has brought Amanda and her brother up on her own. As Amanda pointed out, it would have been extremely difficult for her to afford a hearing aid and also complete her education. The very short times that her hearing aid was in for repairs were almost impossible for her. She felt isolated socially and struggled with communication and her studies.

Thanks to the service that was in place and supported by the previous Labor government, this young woman has been able to educate herself and has found positive employment. Most importantly, she has a very positive self-concept and had enough confidence to appear in front of a Senate inquiry. This government's alternative is to shatter the aspirations of young people like Amanda, make them reliant on government benefits and leave them with a much lower feeling of self-worth.

The holders of Commonwealth seniors health cards have already lost the Commonwealth dental health program. Now they will also have to find the $3,000 to $5,000 cost for new hearing aids. To qualify for these seniors health cards, a person must have an income of less than $20,841.60. The cost of two new hearing aids would come close to a quarter of that income. Indeed, 16.4 per cent of people between 65 and 69 years of age have a hearing impairment, and 22.6 per cent of 70‐ to 74‐year‐olds and 31.8 per cent of those over 75 also have hearing impairments. These figures show that there will be many people in the community affected by these changes in eligibility. This government does not have any compassion or mercy for these people. `Let the old and the young who have a low income suffer,' seems to be the message the government is strongly sending out.

It must be obvious to everybody in the community that this government has no concept of social justice. People who are retired have contributed to this country in many ways and have paid their taxes for many years. They are now going to have to pay the full amount for hearing aids. They are going to be punished by this government because their hearing has failed them. Effectively, this government is making them pay doubly for their disability.

On the government's figures, it expects to save about $1.5 million over four years through these cuts to the under 21 year olds and does not expect to save on the cuts to the Commonwealth seniors health card holders. But the figures do not add up.

The report of the hearing services review noted that Australian Hearing Services was able to supply hearing aids to consumers for a much lower price than private sector suppliers, mainly because it purchased enormous quantities under a long-term contract. In fact, the report stated that the AHS purchasing arrangements appeared to save the government at least $8 million per year over a five-year period.

The AHS will lose business under the proposed voucher system. Therefore, their ability to secure lower prices will be lost and so will their $8 million savings. I do not believe that the private sector, which will not have the tax exemptions which the AHS have and will not have the monopoly of the AHS, will be able to provide the hearing aids for a lower cost.

So how is the government going to save the money they claim? Clearly, there are two alternatives if the government is determined to keep to their budget slashing targets. One alternative is that the voucher system will only give people vouchers which will pay for part of a hearing aid. As time goes by, the voucher will pay for a steadily declining percentage of a hearing aid. In reality, vouchers will merely give people a discount on hearing aids. Everyone will have to top up their voucher to a greater extent every year. This top up factor for the voucher system is already being openly discussed by potential recipients out in the community.

The only other obvious alternative will be to create waiting lists. If the budget for vouchers runs out, people will simply have to wait goodness knows how long to obtain a hearing aid. This is not just my fear. People out there in the community are also quite fearful of this prospect.

This of course is a perfect way for the government to divert attention away from hospital waiting lists. The answer is to create waiting lists in other areas so Australians will become accustomed to waiting for all manner of services. The cost of such budget cuts and waiting lists will be borne by the innocent who already have to cope with a disability.

1 The consequences of people being without hearing aids for weeks, months or longer will be enormous. Many will lose the ability to communicate, others will lose self‐confidence and their quality of life and others may even lose their jobs or their place in an educational institution. This is a disgraceful and shameful action being perpetrated by this government. It is a disgraceful and shameful action for abolishing the Commonwealth's dental health scheme, for the increased charges for home and community care, for introducing entry fees for nursing homes and forcing many elderly to sell the family home, for increasing the cost of pharmaceuticals, for not increasing the pension to take into account all of those cost increases and for denying many the assistance of acquiring hearing aids. Is this not the government who, in the run-up to the last election, assured Australians that it was working for all of us? What rubbish!

The other half of this legislation is even more puzzling. The Australian Government Health Service is going to be corporatised. Why? According to the government, it is being corporatised so that it can provide mainly health assessment services for Commonwealth clients. But the AGHS is already doing this quite efficiently. The AGHS carries out medical assessments on people who apply for positions in the Commonwealth Public Service, migrant applications and others who are required to be assessed by the Commonwealth. Why does the AGHS need to be corporatised to compete with the private sector if this is the service it so adequately provides? Quite obviously, it is being prepared for privatisation.

BREAK.PARA: This government has already made it easy for companies like Woolworths to sell petrol, even if it will send many small retail petrol outlets to the wall. It is also going to make it easy for supermarket chains like Woolworths and others to sell pharmaceutical products. Surely it is not going to suggest that a company like Woolworths will be allowed to do medical assessments for the Commonwealth. Maybe that is a little far-fetched, even for this government.

However, if this is opened up to private medical practices, the applicant who is applying for a Commonwealth job or a migration application and who is, after all, paying the doctor for the service, will be able to shop around for the most lenient doctor who will give the most glowing medical report. Most doctors, of course, would be too professional to be influenced. However, there are always those who could be easily persuaded. This is another example of a government making ill-thought‐out decisions based on political philosophy rather than commonsense. We will lose the expertise of a government body that is good at speedily assessing Commonwealth clients because this government is hell-bent on privatising large sections of the Public Service.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Denman, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Hearing Services Administration Bill 1997 and the Hearing Services and AGHS Reform Bill 1997. This legislation, if it passes, would mark the start of an era of uncertainty for those who are deaf or hearing impaired. With regard to particular groups of hearing impaired, it will cause hardship that is needless and pointless.

SPEECH.PARA: With the introduction of these bills, promises made at election time have been breached. As we have said on this side of the chamber on many occasions, those who have been singled out in the first 12 months of this government have been those in need of an element of assistance to help them get started—to get them on an equal footing. So it is with the deaf and hearing impaired. By and large, that is the position.

There has been no better exemplification of how this government will attack those in need than the measures contained in these bills. That came out clearly in the committee hearings into these bills. I was heartened to hear though that the government will make amends to the 18‐ to 21‐year‐olds. This particular group would have been severely disadvantaged, as will other groups, but it is heartening to see that there will be amendments made to the legislation for that particular age group.

On the north-west coast of Tasmania, where I live, for example, there are currently approximately 50 young people who are in the age group that would have been affected by the changes. Many of these people in the 18 to 21 age group would, I suspect, either be continuing their studies or be in the unfortunate position of being unemployed. Not only have many of these young people had troubles recently—for example, with their Austudy entitlements or with the withdrawal of the benefits they have received from the Department of Social Security—but they were not going to be able to have access to the Burnie Hearing Centre. Their access would have been—I hope it is not going to be—severely curtailed. This would have been at a period in their lives when they need to have their confidence and their self-assuredness boosted and not shattered. Again, I make the point that I am delighted that amendments will be moved.

The fact that these bills would have jeopardised the ability for young people to communicate as effectively and properly as they have in the past with a model public service provider as Australian Hearing Services is a true travesty. As I said earlier, many of the 18‐ to 21‐year‐old deaf students are still at school. Having this service removed would, as ACROD stated, `Significantly impact upon these students and their access to higher education'.

The services provided by the Australian Hearing Service for the 18‐ to 21‐year‐olds does not just include the fitting of hearing aids, but also other assistance devices which can be very expensive. For parents of students, the financial impost in purchasing a normal hearing device so that there is adequate access to lectures and tutorials would have caused much unnecessary hardship. I also wonder whether, for those young people on the north-west coast and throughout Tasmania who suffer hearing loss, placing a model public service provider such as the Australian Hearing Service in a competitive environment will lead to an improvement.

It must not be forgotten that Australian Hearing Services currently provides hearing aids to its clients at an average price which is $400 lower than the private sector providers and can, for example, due to buying powers, achieve discounts of more than 33 per cent on batteries. Australian Hearing Services also, through a joint venture, produces hearing aids, creating highly skilled jobs and $200 million in foreign investment with the resultant sales and exports of high quality hearing aids and devices.

Unfortunately, it is more likely that the Burnie Hearing Centre, which has provided so professionally services to the hearing impaired in the region, will, with the proposed reforms, see the loss of jobs and a related falling away of service. At the moment, there are private enterprises providing visiting services to the region. But I doubt whether such services will set up a regional based service equivalent to that currently provided, employing locals and spending money locally. This type of situation, I suspect, will be replicated all over regional Australia.

I would hope that, within the next decade, one would be able to look back and observe a change for the better. I believe prima facie these bills do not augur well for the future level of service in Tasmania. I concede that competition may lead to benefits in the larger metropolitan areas, but I cannot see those benefits flowing at the same level to the deaf and hearing impaired community in Tasmania.

From a consumer perspective, there has not been any real problem or disadvantage with waiting times in Tasmania. I guess smallness has an advantage. Anyway, the argument is put that waiting lists reflect a system where there is no client choice. It may also likewise be argued that they reflect the comprehensive level of ongoing after‐care services that are provided by the Australian Hearing Services. There is, on my understanding, an expectation that a smaller number of private providers will visit the north-west coast of Tasmania and other parts of the state. But how that will provide a service other than offering devices, as opposed to a whole rehabilitation approach, is anybody's guess.

Tasmania needs a public service provider like the Australian Hearing Services, as it does not possess the mass of people to drive a competitive environment. What I fear is that over the next decade we will end up with an inferior hearing service because, like many industries and professions in Tasmania, the gains to be made from adopting the Hilmer competition reforms are unknown at this stage in my home state.

We hear a lot about the fact that those in the affected age group who will lose eligibility for full services will be able to take advantage of the extension of the hearing aid maintenance service support package for a period of up to five years. For a young hearing impaired person, there will not be much solace gained from knowing that he or she may be eligible for maintenance when the body of a hearing aid falls on the floor and breaks or where electronic components fail. There will be no regular supply of batteries and this would impose a cost of upwards of $150 per annum. There will also be a cut‐off of the Commonwealth seniors health card holders from access to Australian Hearing Services.

I understand that there are presently 15 clients of the Australian Hearing Services on the north-west coast of Tasmania who are Commonwealth seniors health card holders. Obviously there are many more in the rest of Tasmania. There is no doubt that the number will increase with the ageing of the population.

As stated in the Labor members' dissenting committee report on this measure, the government is also being mean spirited when those to be affected will largely be self-funded retirees who may be asset rich but are income poor. I thought this government was going to look after self-funded retirees but, alas, it would appear that if you have a hearing problem you will have to pay in future or go without. Realistically, most will not be able to afford the cost.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel that it is important to rise to speak on the Hearing Services Administration Bill. Although I no longer have the conduct of this area, I certainly feel that it is a matter of sufficient importance that some time should be spent on speaking on it this evening.

SPEECH.PARA: When the changes were first put forward in relation to the Commonwealth dental health services I thought I had seen some of the most callous budget cutting that I had ever seen and probably would ever see. But I have to say that, during the hearing of the Senate community affairs committee, the budget cuts disclosed in these particular pieces of legislation surpassed even the callous indifference of those cuts to the Commonwealth dental health program—and that is really saying something.

I am pleased to see that there has been an amendment proposed by the government in relation to the eligibility for hearing aids for those young Australians between the ages of 18 and 21. I have to say very strongly that it was not an amendment that was won with great ease, for it was a debate that went on at length within the Senate community affairs committee. In fact, the major focus of the dissenting report of both the opposition and the Democrats was the particular callousness of taking away the entitlement for that particular age group. I suppose I should be grateful that the government has seen sense and has agreed to reinstate that entitlement. But in my view it does not entirely correct the measures that are contained in these bills. I would like to spend a little time in talking about those issues.

Just before I do that, I would like to go back to the fundamental issue before us and whether this government is really, honestly putting forward its program as it promised in the election. I might remind you of something that John Howard, the Prime Minister, said in his third headland speech to the Australian Council of Social Service. He promised to `maintain all current Commonwealth concessions'. In my view, to take away the entitlement to hearing aids of those senior health cardholders is in complete contradiction to and shows complete disregard for this promise.

I know that we have had a lot of debate about core promises and non‐core promises, but I think it is very difficult to say that this particular promise of maintaining current Commonwealth concessions would have been seen by the vast majority of Australians—and, in particular, the vast majority of Australians who had the benefit of those Commonwealth concessions—as anything but a core promise. I think there are many members of the community who would see it as a betrayal; that now that this government has control of policy and control of our budget it sneaks around behind people's backs and takes away an entitlement that people rely on to maintain a reasonable lifestyle.

Returning just quickly to the 18‐ to 21‐year‐olds, one of the matters that I think is worth focusing on, in particular, is to look at the budget impact of the change proposed by the government and to examine the amount of money that was at stake in relation to 18‐ to 21‐year‐olds. I really think it is quite shocking. In order to save the huge sum of $500,000, this government were prepared to throw away the lives of those deaf and hearing impaired young people between the ages of 18 and 21. I think that is really quite horrifying. If you were looking at maybe a much larger sum I suppose you could understand why the government might be tempted, but when you are looking at what I might describe as piddling sums for which they are prepared to wreak damage on people, whose lives are extraordinarily difficult already, for that sort of money it really makes me feel ill. That is the truth of it and I think the people who gave evidence to us in the Senate Community Affairs Committee felt pretty much the same way. I am certain that even though you have reversed your decision, the betrayal that was contained in this bill will not be easily forgotten.

We have remedied the situation. The government have seen fit to withdraw from their proposition for the affected young people in Australia but they have not felt that they should extend this generosity to those people who are at the senior end of the spectrum, those people who have a seniors health card and who are entitled to the benefit of a hearing aid. They have not reinstated this one. They have shown a little bit of humanity towards the young people but they have not seen fit to show that same humanity to the older people in our community.

A lot of older people in the community do have a difficult time. They have, in large part, provided substantial amounts of taxation money to the community during their working lives. Now they have retired with maybe a little bit of money set aside and they have been told that a benefit that they have relied on for some time—that is, a hearing aid—will no longer be available to them because of a decision of this government. The trouble with elderly people is that many of them when they first left the work force may not have had difficulties with their hearing but, as we all know, as time marches on, more and more people are affected by lack of hearing or their hearing becomes impaired.

It is this particular group of people that this budget change so seriously affects because they will not be provided with assistance in the future. It is not a very small group of people, either. In fact, the total number of people that have been assisted by the Australian Hearing Services is 180,000. What proportion of that are seniors cardholders? It is almost impossible to estimate. The department made some attempt to but, in giving evidence to the committee, they admitted quite freely that it was not possible to exactly say. We do know that for a lot of people it will have an effect on their lifestyle and it will mean that they will not enjoy the sort of life that they expected when they retired.

The interesting thing about the 33,000 Commonwealth seniors health cardholders who are not obtaining this benefit is that this cut, according to the budget documentation, shows no savings whatsoever. That is a fairly remarkable statement that this government, in the case of seniors, are prepared to go even further than they did for young people. For young people they were prepared, for the princely sum of $500,000, to take away the quality of their lives. For the 33,000 Commonwealth seniors cardholders, they are prepared to do that for nil savings. That is really quite an astonishing proposition.

Essentially, this government should be rethinking their entire approach in relation to this bill. They should be stepping back from this callous approach. They should be stepping back from this niggardly penny‐pinching which, in the end, will affect only those who are the most vulnerable in our society and the most likely to be adversely affected. The government should start to have a little bit more of a generous heart and a little bit more regard for the promises they made when they wanted to get into power and should not so quickly disregard the people who are relying on them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I would like to thank the senators from the opposition for their contribution and Senator Allison from the Democrats for her contribution. I can confirm that the government will be moving the amendment mentioned previously, which will reinstate hearing services in the 18‐ to 21‐year‐old group. I can also confirm that the government will be opposing the amendment which, I understand, will be moved by Senator Forshaw. I will advance the reasons for that during the committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: The government is not being mean‐spirited, as Senator Neal has stated. Senator Neal fails to mention that, in this recent budget, the government announced extra funding of $2 million for cochlear implants for profoundly deaf children. That was not something we went to the election with; that was something we saw a need for in the community. There are just under 400 young Australians who could lead a normal life with such an implant and funding was provided for that. Senator Neal also does not mention the mess that we found the finances of this country in when we took power or that we had to take steps to make sure that the deficit, which had blown out to $10 billion, was addressed.

BREAK.PARA: Let me deal specifically with the matters that were raised by the opposition. Senator Forshaw made the statement that the government was not supporting AHS as being cost effective. The government believes that AHS has done a good job in improving standards throughout the hearing services industry. But that does not mean that things should just stay forever there. There are better ways and the government is pursuing this.

The government will retain the same level of monitoring in standards as in the present system. It will remove the conflict of interest between the AHS providing a regulatory service whilst also being a service provider itself. What the government proposes is that there will be an office of hearing services, which will oversee the voucher system. The AHS will be free to compete with the private sector on an equal footing in relation to the provision of health services. This competition will improve the system and will allow consumers that all important free choice between service providers. That can only mean a benefit for the people of Australia. There will be no diminution at all in the provision of hearing services. There will not be the harsh consequences for those people under 21 that were mentioned because, as I said, the government will be moving that amendment.

It is not just the opposition who can say that they thought this amendment was important because I notice that the Democrats alluded to that very amendment themselves, as did the chair of the committee, Senator Knowles, from the government. It was recognised universally by the members of the committee, by people who gave evidence and also as a result of consultation carried out by the government that the amendment was necessary.

I acknowledge the frankness with which Senator Forshaw admitted that the previous government was no stranger to corporatisation or privatisation in any way. I refer to the federal airports, Australian Defence Industries, the Commonwealth Bank, Qantas and Telstra. There was a definite corporatisation spirit in the opposition when it was in government. Therefore, I fail to see how it can say that corporatisation here is such an evil thing, especially when it will provide consumers with a choice. That entirely destroys the argument of the opposition.

The two bills that we have before us deal not only with the Australian Hearing Service but also with the Australian Government Health Service. Senator Allison mentioned that the AGHS had been given the job of screening for asbestosis in marine seamen who were involved in the last war. The AGHS won that on a full cost recovery, competitive basis and there is no reason at all to assume that, under the new system, the AGHS will not be able to fulfil that function in the future. It will, of course, continue with that screening.

These measures are innovative. They will provide competition in both the health and hearing services. They will give the people of Australia a choice of provider. The AHS will retain its charter to service children, those people who fall into special categories and, in particular, those people living in rural and remote areas such as Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. So there will be a safety net there.
Perhaps the other aspects which are more detailed can be dealt with during the committee stage. I would commend this bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: HEARING SERVICES ADMINISTRATION BILL 1997
The bill.
Motion (by Senator Ellison) proposed:
Clause 5, page 4 (line 7), omit "18", substitute "21".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that I have that running sheet in front of me but, as I understand it, this relates to the decision by the government not to proceed with the original proposal to reduce the age to 18.
—That's right.

—Thank you. As I outlined in the second reading debate, the opposition's position is that we are pleased the government has done a backflip on its original proposal and has recognised the error of its ways on this matter, so we will not be opposing this amendment or indeed the amendments as they relate to this issue of age. Of course, as I have made it clear, when we come to it later in the committee stage, we will be opposing that aspect of the bill which relates to the removal of eligibility for seniors health care cardholders and the legislation as a whole.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
HEARING SERVICES AND AGHS REFORM BILL 1997
The bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition opposes schedule 1, item 3.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That Schedule 1, item 3 stand as printed.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 1, item 5 negatived.
Amendments (by Senator Ellison)—by leave—agreed to:
(2) Schedule 1, item 24, page 20 (line 28), omit "Australian children", substitute "young Australians".
(3) Schedule 1, item 29, page 21 (line 22), omit "Australian children", substitute "young Australians".
(4) Schedule 1, item 29, page 21 (line 23), omit "Australian children", substitute "young Australians".
(5) Schedule 1, item 29, page 22 (lines 29 to 31), omit the definition of Australian children .
(6) Schedule 1, item 29, page 23 (after line 12), after the definition of referred Commonwealth employee , insert:
young Australians means:
(a) Australian citizens under 21 years of age; or
(b) Australian permanent residents under 21 years of age.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I wanted to raise a couple of questions concerning this legislation. I wonder if this is an appropriate time for me to do that.
—If you do not raise them now, you will not get the chance, Senator.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of audiologists and audiology organisations have raised some questions with me. One relates to hearing aid technicians who are known as audiometrists. The effect of the Hearing Services and AGHS Reform Bill is, as I understand it, to increase the number of opportunities for audiometrists to practise and that the Office of Hearing Services would supervise the work by medical practitioners in private industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The concern which was raised with me was that more of these hearing aid technicians would be operating. A correspondent who says that a number of errors can be made in the licensing of audiologists has given me a case history showing the implications of this. It concerns a woman—I will read it out to the Senate because it is interesting—who:

. . . attended a non-audiologist tester in a rural community, who performed a hearing assessment without the use of a soundproof facility. The tester reported the presence of a unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, and subsequently recommended the fitting of a hearing aid in her right ear. The tester did not suggest nor indicate the necessity of medical and audiological follow up at the time of the assessment.

Some months later, the woman consulted an audiologist and attended the Audiology department of a metropolitan hospital. The results of the audiologist's assessment showed a unilateral sensorineural hearing loss. On the basis of the results, a subsequent urgent otological follow up was initiated. The woman was found to have an acoustic neuroma on her right auditory nerve. This was removed in a neurosurgical procedure in a major metropolitan neurosurgery unit. However, due to the size of the tumour on the acoustic nerve, the patient had a resultant complete loss of hearing on the right side, and slight facial weakness on the right side.

She subsequently contacted the original non-audiologist tester, seeking a refund for her hearing aid which was now useless to her. The tester refused to make a refund for the hearing aid fitted to the right ear. The tester also refused to provide details of their assessment, despite the signed request of the patient.

The person who wrote to me on this subject says that there is a real health danger here to people being tested by such non-professionals, or at least hardly trained technicians, and that this is likely to be exacerbated by the passing of this bill. I gather that this correspondence has also been sent to the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) for his opinion.

BREAK.PARA: I just wondered whether perhaps Senator Ellison could give us the government's response to this, because I am actually quite concerned about this matter. If it is a matter for this bill, and perhaps an amendment which ought to have been put forward, then perhaps we need some time to think about what that amendment should be and whether it should be put tonight or whether there should be a suspension of consideration of this bill until there is a time to consider it more thoroughly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —There will be no lessening of services by the passing of this bill. AHS and the private sector use audiologists. In fact audiometrists do work in the private sector and organisations which are contracted by the AHS. I am not aware of the particular case you mentioned. Certainly I can undertake to pursue that. But that case would indicate more a problem with the current system rather than the one proposed by the passing of this bill.

SPEECH.PARA: It has to be remembered that, with the passing of this bill, there will be an Office of Hearing Services, which will carry out the regulatory role and will not have the conflict of interest the AHS currently has. The AHS currently is both a provider and a regulator at the same time. That would not happen in the situation were this bill to be passed, because you will have the OHS overseeing this. There will be no lessening at all of any of the services that are being provided for. In fact I believe that, by having the OHS, there will be greater control. As for the particular case you mentioned, I can undertake to follow that up and get back to you.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think one of the other issues associated with that is the extra cost which would be associated with this supervisory role of OHS. I recall during the hearing raising the questions of whether the OHS would be appropriately resourced in order to provide this service and, given that hearing aid technicians are more likely to be the testers in these cases, whether or not there were adequate safeguards both in terms of accreditation and in terms of resources within OHS to deal with this issue.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —This will be budget neutral, in effect. The current regulatory role that AHS carries out will be taken over by the Office of Hearing Services, OHS. So there will be no added cost. The OHS will simply take up that area which the AHS will be abandoning. There will be the same maintenance of standards. There will be no alteration in accreditation.

—Can you assure us that there will be not more audiomet rists who will test people seeking hearing aids? Can you just advise us what the changes are in this sense? What is the likelihood that there will be more of these technicians—rather than audiologists—performing this work than previously? Is it a risk or is it not?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be the same as the current system provides. Audiometrists would be able to test just as they can at the moment. There will be no difference. It will be the same as the current system.

—In taking evidence on the Australian Hearing Services, we received evidence that about 180,000 people are serviced by them. Of these, about 75 per cent are fitted with hearing aids. From my rough calculations, that is about 135,000 people. One of the major advantages of the Australian Hearing Services is that they are able to provide these hearing services extraordinarily cheaply. I suppose we see the positive side of having a government monopoly in that sense. It appears that the cost of a hearing unit is, in some cases, $400 a unit less than comparable private providers. How can we be assured or will you assure us that in fact those people who are eligible for a concessional hearing unit will not have to pay more? What steps will be taken to monitor the cost? If there is a rise in cost, will some sort of compensation be provided for those people?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —Private sector providers have told the government that they want a level playing field. They want to compete with the AHS on the same level. They say that they are happy to compete with the Australian Hearing Services as long as they are paid what the Australian Hearing Services gets paid—that is, they will compete at current price levels. So I think that answers your question. There will not be any increase in costs, because the competition will be on the same price levels as at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: I noticed that in the earlier debate Senator Gibbs, I think, said that people would have to top up. The government has given an absolute assurance that consumers will continue to receive the same standard of service as they do now at no charge. They can go beyond what is clinically needed. If they wanted to get some optional extras, they can pay for that; but, otherwise, there will be no extra charge at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —I might not have made myself completely clear. At the moment the Australian Hearing Services is able to get a very low unit cost for their hearing aids. They purchase about 135,000 a year so they can go to a manufacturer and get that very low cost. That means that, obviously, they are applying pressure against anybody else. My concern is, if Australian Hearing Services is no longer providing 135,000 hearing aids, they will not be able to buy them as cheaply.
