I am asking: could the parliamentary secretary provide an assurance that this corporatisation will not mean we will be paying more for our hearing aids? Are you prepared to give that assurance?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can give an assurance to Senator Neal that individual customers will not have to pay more.

—But will you also give the assurance that the government, in purchasing those hearing aids, will not, in fact, be paying more for each individual item? The whole process of corporatisation is based on the assumption that the provision of services will be more efficient. That assumes, on a per item basis for providing the service of the hearing aid—whoever it is who pays, whether it be the individual or the government—that the individual item cost will be lower. It appears to me, if you are producing fewer items and have to pay more per item, that eventually someone, whether it be the government or the individual, will be paying more which would indicate a loss of efficiency rather than an increased efficiency as a result of the corporatisation, the contracting out. Do you agree with that proposition or are you prepared to give the committee an assurance that there will be no increase in cost either to the government or to the individual on a per item basis?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —The tendering process is yet to be finalised and I cannot answer that question until that tendering process has been answered.

—Parliamentary secretary, if you are unable to assure us that, in fact, the unit cost will be lower, which translates that the provision of the hearing aids would be more efficient, what is the purpose of the second half of the bill which corporatises the Australian Hearing Services, splits off the regulatory body and commences contracting out? Is it merely an ideological pursuit, not really a pursuit of more efficient practice at all and clearly not a benefit to individuals who are affected, the community at large or the government in a budgetary sense?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —The tendering process will naturally force down the price that the government will have to pay. The competition will force that price down, there is no question about that. I just cannot give you the exact figure. It will be in the same ballpark figure as what is paid at present. The tendering process will do that, but that process has not been finalised and we cannot give you a final figure.

—With respect, parliamentary secretary, the lowest cost provider at the moment is the Australian Hearing Services. They are able to provide that low cost per item because they provide about 135,000 a year. At the moment, if the private sector wants to compete, they have to match the cost of the Australian Hearing Services. If you reduce the capacity of the Australian Hearing Services to provide an item at that lower cost, then competition will not provide you that low level because the cost per item for the Australian Hearing Services will go up and what the private sector has to match to compete will also go up. The end result, as I said, will be a higher cost per item. Will you assure us that the cost per item will not go up and if you are not prepared to assure us of this, what is the point of the second part of this legislation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —The AHS will be competing with the private sector. That is the whole idea of this. If the AHS provides the best price, it gets the business. It is as simple as that. The private sector is going to have to compete. That will not force prices up. If they are not competitive, they do not get the business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to refer to the inquiry and to the comments that were made on this subject by Mr Cochran from the Department of Health and Family Services. There was quite a lot of discussion about how this tendering process would work. As I under stand it, Mr Cochran was asked about the tendering process and what that would mean in terms of achieving a level playing field. I asked the question, `Was it the aim to bring the tenders down to the same level as the Australian Hearing Services pays for their services?' As Senator Neal rightly points out, they have the advantage of economies of scale and their unit price is much lower than the private sector can manage.

SPEECH.PARA: The answer that Mr Cockran gave was that there will be extra cost involved for AHS in putting it on that level playing field in that they will pay a dividend to the government that reflects the cost of taxes, and so forth, that would be incurred in the private sector. In other words, when the tenders are completed—that is a government based tender process, as I understand it, to which the private sector tenderers can access hearing aids at a unit price—if that unit price is higher than that which is achievable by the government, then the government services, AHS, is required to refund the government by the difference.

So what we are doing here is creating a level playing field but not without some cost both in terms of the hearing aid units and, presumably, in terms of the cost to taxpayers. I remind the government of the remarks that were made at that inquiry. Perhaps the parliamentary secretary would like to reconsider those remarks.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said earlier, these measures are budget neutral. The AHS will be relieved of the regulatory role that it otherwise had. That is a benefit it is getting. There will not be any added cost to the AHS so that there will be cost increases. This is budget neutral.

—What are the anticipated returns to the government? Has that been factored into this question, given that the AHS is required to pay the government, in the event that the tenders are higher than its current unit price—which seems very likely. What happens to that money? Does it go into general revenue or does it go to pay for the OHS? And how much would it be? What is the government's expectation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot speculate on what difference—if any—there will be in these prices, because the tendering process is yet to be finalised. That cannot be answered at this stage. Suffice to say, if AHS provides the cheapest service, it gets the business.

—Parliamentary Secretary, you made a statement in your closing remarks in the second reading debate—and it is also contained in the explanatory memorandum—that Australian Hearing Services will continue to operate as the provider for children and certain other groups. You mentioned, for instance, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. I would like to ask you what the rationale behind that decision is, given all the other arguments you have put forward about the need to open up the provision of hearing aids to competition from the private sector? How is it that, on the one hand, you can argue that in respect of some groups who would at the moment be clients of AHS but, on the other hand, you still recognise a continuing role for AHS in these areas?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is fair to say that the private sector is not yet at the stage where it could accommodate the special and complex needs of children and of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people—especially the latter group, as they are in remote areas. Therefore, it was recognised that the Australian Hearing Services could provide a competent service for this sector of the community and it would be unwise to rush headlong into totally freeing up the provision of services to the whole spectrum of the community. It was thought wise to retain this safety net and to monitor how things go. I notice that the Democrats mentioned in their part of the Senate committee report that they wanted some monitoring to take place, and the government will be monitoring the operation of this system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a question about the new tendering process and the way in which this is designed to bring other players into the service and about the current hearing aid manufacturers, in particular. I think Crystal Aid is the name of the organisation, and there is another associated company which deals with the marketing of this product overseas—quite successfully, I understand.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 9.50 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Job Losses in Canberra ACT Brumbies

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again I find myself rising in the chamber to talk about the situation the people of Canberra find themselves in. As a result of the last budget, more job losses are expected in the ACT. These will not be just public sector job losses. There will be flow‐on job losses in the private sector.

SPEECH.PARA: There is another city in Australia that has been subjected to a decision resulting in about 2,000 job losses. That decision was made not by a government but by a large private corporation. It decided, basically, to wind up a significant proportion of its operations. This event has captured the heart of the nation. There is a sense of abhorrence that a company can shut up shop, move out and leave a community devastated. As a result of this, there has been a political response—and quite rightly too.

The political response to commit $10 million in an assistance package to the people of Newcastle is well founded. It probably will not be enough to secure their futures, but it will go a long way in assisting the community in the struggles that they face. The total package now for Newcastle is $12.25 million, thanks to an extra $2.25 million for employment programs in the Hunter region. Senator Vanstone concluded that 2,000 job losses in Newcastle required $2.25 million for employment programs. My point this evening is that, with respect to Canberra, we are anticipating 7,000 job losses and, if you apply Senator Vanstone's own calculations, that would mean that we could have at least $5 million here for employment programs to help us through the difficult employment transition.

The similarities between Newcastle and Canberra are there. They are both Labor areas; they are both one‐industry towns. Unfortunately, or perhaps fortunately—it depends on your perspective—Canberra's one industry or dominant industry is the Public Service. It does not attract quite the response in the Australian community that the blue‐collar steel industry does. That is not only a shame for the people of Canberra but also a reflection on the job that this government has done on the role that the public sector plays in the Australian community.

There is no doubt that, under the Howard Liberal government, we have seen continued attacks against the public sector—and not just in a dry drive for economic efficiencies and cost cutting and savings; we have seen an attack on a philosophical basis. We have seen a move to a market economy where the private sector takes over the service provision role formerly held by government.

It is a bitter pill to swallow that we cannot blame a big private company that is motivated by profit maximisation. We are actually being abandoned by the government itself, the government that we all pay our taxes to. They are the ones pulling out of town; they are the ones cutting the jobs. And there is no hint of a package to help the Canberra economy through this transition. In fact, there was not even an offer to the government of the ACT to waive some of the contribution to the deficit reduction program in an effort to offset the damage that is being done through the cuts to the public sector.

BREAK.PARA: I know the cuts to the public sector affect many regional communities in Australia, and Canberra is not the only one, but I draw these comparisons on the basis of the magnitude and the concentration of the cuts here. I am of the view that this needs to be seen in the same context as any other regional community. I congratulate the respective governments for acknowledging the situation in Newcastle and for taking some remedial action to limit the damage, but I ask that the same courtesies, the same acknowledgment be applied to Canberra.

One of the groups that is particularly affected by this is the private sector; it is not just the public sector. The people of Canberra are sick of hearing the simplistic mantra by both the federal Liberal government and the ACT Liberal government that states there is a transition of jobs from the public to the private sector as a result of the changes that they are implementing. That is not the case. It has been shown that the private sector suffers inordinately whenever there is a cut in public sector jobs and that outsourcing or a transfer of those jobs from the public to the private sector is not the solution it has been painted as being by the Liberal governments.
Ms Wendy Hamilton, the Chairwoman of the Canberra Business Council outsourcing task force, in an article in today's Canberra Times, is reported as saying:
Outsourcing is not a be‐all, or end‐all, for Canberra business.
She is then reported as saying:

There will be a big surge initially of outsourcing for basic services [corporate service and public relations] then there will be a long period of navel‐gazing by companies as they strive to become more efficient and they might just choose to down‐size rather than outsource.

So there is no certainty for small business in any respect. The article reports Ms Hamilton as saying that it was a `matter of concern' to see federal government departments now contemplating `piggybacking' on some of the few contracts that have actually been let out. So the promise that local companies, local private sector businesses would actually have the opportunity to expand and grow under this plan is a fallacy. Piggybacking contracts cut out local businesses. We have seen by experi ence that the opportunity that these businesses will have to quote and tender as part of these major contracts is limited and it is not being addressed by the government.

I would like to finish on a more positive note. The Canberra community had a rare opportunity to collectively smile last weekend, and I am referring, of course, to the magnificent win by the Brumbies, the ACT Rugby Union team—

TALK.START.PARA: —You shameless parochialists.

—Absolutely. The ACT Brumbies' contribution to the Super 12 Series is something that you, I am sure, would appreciate, had you seen them play. The achievements of this team have really captured the imagination of Canberra and the surrounding region, leading with a sensational style of rugby that has not been seen for a while. They are off to face Auckland next Saturday.

BREAK.PARA: On behalf of everybody here, I want to wish them luck. It is likely to be a very tough game. Regardless of the outcome, I want to thank the Brumbies for giving us a lift. Congratulations on your achievements. All those who made the season possible—the fans, the conditioning coaches, the ACT board, partners, the officials and the lot—deserve recognition for something that has made us all feel pretty good at a pretty low moment in our lives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shameless parochialism! Maybe Minister Vanstone and I should mention that the Crows—three in a row—are doing quite well. I rise tonight to discuss—
—I'm a Port Power person myself.

—Hey, Minister, I am the first to acknowledge the win over the Crows by Port Power. I tipped 15 points, and it was 12 points—pretty close. But that does not have a lot to do with privacy laws, which is the reason I am speaking tonight.

BREAK.PARA: Privacy protection needs to extend to the collection, storage, security, access, correction, use, destruction and disclosure of all personal information. I believe that the present legislative scheme that is outlined in the Privacy Act 1988 addresses the collection, storage, use and disclosure of personal information held by the government. This scheme also extends to credit reporting and some telecommunications suppliers and operators. This scheme does not, however, extend to the private sector.

A discussion paper was released by the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) on 12 September last year which set out a scheme based on the existing information privacy principles in the Privacy Act 1988 and added to this codes of practice and a range of additional provisions which addressed the particular concerns of the private sector. In essence, this was a proposal for industry codes of practice supervised by the Privacy Commissioner and subject to statutory backing—a co‐regulatory approach. This scheme is consistent with the schemes adopted by New Zealand, Hong Kong and, of course, the European Union.
However, on 21 March this year, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) announced that the Privacy Act 1988 would not extend to the private sector. The Prime Minister said:
The Commonwealth opposes such proposals which will further increase compliance costs for all Australian businesses, large and small.
That was it—the end of Australia's international best practice privacy scheme, and, I should add, another election promise broken.

The Prime Minister's decision was yet another example of the Attorney‐General being rolled, and it reinforces the belief that legal milestones are not important enough to this government when measured against the special interests of a few. The reasons for this decision, and the relevant information the Prime Minister relied on in making this decision, must be made available. I call on the government to do so. A decision of this importance cannot be passed off without some explanation.

I would like to set out some of my concerns which I believe require a response from the government and which really go to the core of the Prime Minister's decision. His only expressed reason, so far as I am aware, is compliance costs. There is a considerable number of other issues that he should have addressed.

Recently a Price Waterhouse survey of 120 large businesses found that two-thirds favour the introduction of a comprehensive system of national privacy laws. Obviously these businesses did not think compliance costs were a particular problem. If compliance costs are a problem for some businesses, we need to see the data or cost projections the Prime Minister considered in order to make an assessment as to whether these compliance costs are relevant.

The cost of compliance may be an issue for some business, but it also may be a cost associated with good business. The cost of compliance may also be offset against the improved management of personal information. What the Prime Minister must consider is that, in these changing times, personal information now has a value the extent of which I do not believe it has ever had before.
For example, in today's Financial Review a story entitled `Banks tapping into heavy number‐crunching' states:

In the retail trade . . . computers have matched things like age, sex and credit card spending habits and discovered that on Friday nights, an extraordinary number of 30-year-old men develop an apparently compelling desire for two oddly juxtaposed items. They stop into the supermarket on the way home from work and pick up nappies and beer. That's led to rapid rearrangement of shelves.

This story shows the way in which personal information in the form of age, sex and credit card spending habits have been applied for commercial purposes. This is personal information, and this personal information has some commercial value. Consumers should be able to know that their personal information is in fact adequately protected. I do not think this is an unreasonable trade-off for compliance costs, and I do not think it should be overlooked by government.

The European Union privacy directive, which comes into force on 1 July 1998, will prevent trade with Australia—and any other country, for that matter—if there are not adequate privacy laws to protect personal information. The absence of privacy laws is unlikely to satisfy this trade requirement.

Last week the Attorney-General actually suggested that the European Union did not require identical protection or equivalent protection. That is true. As I have said, no protection at all is unlikely to be an adequate level of protection. This issue is further highlighted by legislation like the Trans‐Tasman Mutual Recognition Bill 1996, presently before the Senate. This legislation includes specific provisions about privacy. If the Attorney-General's conclusions are correct, why are these sorts of provisions neces sary in legislation? Surely commercial incentive, as he suggests, would be sufficient. But clearly this is not correct, and the government must address this important issue of trade.

If the Commonwealth does not introduce such laws, New South Wales has indicated that it will introduce a scheme. Victoria, Tasmania, Queensland, the ACT, South Australia and the Northern Territory are also presently examining privacy legislation options. If state and territory governments do introduce privacy schemes, businesses will be required to comply with those requirements, which may end up being different for each state and territory, therefore increasing overall compliance costs significantly.

So the reassurances of the Prime Minister and the Attorney‐General are hollow in light of the state and territory responses and highlight the need for a national and consistent privacy scheme. This issue also suggests that the compliance costs argument may not have been fully considered.

I think it is a fundamental principle that a person has a right to know what personal information is held about them and, if the information is lawfully held, that the information is correct. Article 17 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights provides that no-one shall be subject to arbitrary and unlawful interference with his or her privacy. Privacy is a human rights issue, and the government should deal with this issue appropriately by introducing suitable legislative schemes to comply with Australia's international obligations.

Last week, the Attorney-General said that businesses had a commercial incentive to protect privacy. In fact, in response to a question from me in this place, Minister Vanstone said the week before that some businesses have already taken steps to introduce good privacy practices.

Self-regulation has many beneficial aspects, but it should not be relied upon as the only means of regulation. Certainly, the Australian Democrats support a strong and enforceable privacy scheme which helps to assure consumers that their personal information is being adequately protected. Self-regulation falls down because it does not have the supporting mechanisms for investigation and enforcement.

It should be noted that developing a scheme to address the diverse requirements of protecting privacy is complex and will require extensive consultation and consideration. I have set out a few of these matters here and place on the record my particular concern, as well as that of my party, that a range of other matters need to be addressed.

The government's backflip from its election commitment—because it did make a promise that it would extend privacy laws to the private sector—is an unfortunate decision. I would encourage the government to take steps to reconsider its decision and consult a little more widely so that it does not rely on the interests of a few to the exclusion of an international best practice privacy scheme and the potential to develop and lead the information businesses of the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to talk on the issue of the by-election which occurred in the state seat of Kurwongbah on Saturday last. The by-election was necessitated by the resignation of Margaret Woodgate. Margaret was a former minister in the Labor government and had served the electorate extremely well over a long period of time but had to resign due to ill health. Then followed a preselection process within the Labor Party whereby we, through the rank and file, selected the candidate, Linda Lavarch.
—Was anyone charged over that like they were in Townsville?

—No, those sorts of things do not happen. Anyway, you are getting off the point of my rising this evening. Linda was selected on her own merits. Linda was a person who had a long experience in the community. She had lived there for the last 20 years. Linda had been heavily involved in community groups. Linda acted as a volunteer solicitor at the Petrie Community Legal Centre. Linda's children went to local schools.

SPEECH.PARA: Linda herself has achieved admission as a solicitor and is also currently completing a Bachelor of Social Science degree majoring in psychology. Linda was also the President of the Australian Community Safety and Research Organisation, a group which formulates community responses for crime prevention. So in her own right, she was well and truly credentialled to stand as the candidate for the seat of Kurwongbah and, moreover, to be elected successfully last Saturday as the new representative for that state seat.

The unfortunate aspect of Linda's election to the state parliament is that the media have portrayed her as being the wife of the former Attorney-General. This, through no fault of Linda or her husband, has been designed to take away from the personal ability, capability and integrity of Linda herself. It has also been designed to sell more newspapers and to provide a bit of a beef up as far as the media are concerned.

So I rise to acknowledge the credentials of Linda Lavarch in her own right as the successful candidate who achieved a five per cent swing in that by-election and the successful candidate who did not campaign as the wife of the former A‐G but who has been portrayed by certain sections of the media in that way. I think that has done a great disservice to those people who reported in that particular way on such a fine person.

Undoubtedly though, there are other lessons in that particular by-election which people should take note of. Whilst I will not go into these in any depth this evening, I will just make a passing reference to one of the headlines in today's Courier‐Mail which warned `Blitz signals poll warning'. That refers to the advances that were made by an Independent candidate who, to all intents and purposes, looked like a candidate from the One Nation Party but was not endorsed by that party. What we saw emerging in this particular by-election was the Hanson effect for probably the first major time in any poll.

This of itself is concerning, particularly when one considers that the coalition received one out of four first preference votes and the Labor Party received one out of two. So there is undoubtedly a lesson there for the coalition—they failed to quell the march of Ms Hanson early in the piece and she is going to be a force to be reckoned with in the future.

But the coalition in Queensland took no notice of the result on Saturday, and I think they did so at their own peril. The Age of today in Melbourne carried a headline `Borbidge unfazed by swing in poll'. However, no-one can shy away from the fact that there was at least a five per cent primary vote swing to the Labor Party and something in the order of an eight per cent swing two‐party preferred. This was achieved by an excellent candidate who ran an excellent campaign and did so on her own merits, not on the merits of her husband.

That is the significant thing about Linda Lavarch. She is her own person—a capable person—and will prove to be a very competent member for the state seat of Kurwongbah in Queensland. I suppose it is worthwhile pointing out that she has a very good husband, whose name is Michael. I think I should leave the state seat of Kurwongbah there.

The other thing I would like to briefly mention, seeing that it is sporting night tonight, is that the Brisbane Strikers won the national soccer league before a record crowd in Brisbane yesterday over Sydney United. To them I extend my congratulations. It was interesting—Senator Woodley might note this—that the southern media wanted to downplay the fine achievement by the Brisbane Strikers over the weekend.

TALK.START.PARA: —They're always knocking Queensland.
—That is quite correct. To them I extend my congratulations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak tonight on a matter which has dogged my state and been before this Senate for some years. It concerns the shredding of the Heiner inquiry documents ordered by the Goss government to stop their use in litigation after the Crown had been put on notice of impending court proceedings in which those records were critically relevant and also after the Crown knew that the documents were being sought by a legally enforceable access statute.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter first came under scrutiny in 1995 by the Senate Select Committee on Public Interest Whistleblowing, chaired by Senator Shayne Murphy and of which I was also a member. There now appears to be further evidence referred to the Senate by the Queensland parliamentary Criminal Justice Committee alleging that the CJC misled our deliberations in 1995. I understand that the CJC's handling of what is also known as `the Lindeberg allegations' is to come under scrutiny in Queensland again by the Connolly‐Ryan judicial review into the effectiveness of the CJC in the near future. Another announcement which is long awaited and rather overdue is an announcement by the Borbidge government concerning the establishment of a separate commission of inquiry to investigate this very serious affair in accordance with the recommendation of the Morris‐Howard report.

My reason for speaking tonight is to inform the Senate of another important development which is of relevance to the federal parliament because of the international attention that the shredding is now attracting. I wish to inform the Senate that the shredding has now come to the attention of the International Council on Archives in Paris. It may be debated at an inaugural meeting of a subcommittee on electronic and other current records to be held at The Hague in the Netherlands on 18 to 20 June 1997. However, that is yet to be resolved within the ICA.

The International Council on Archives is a non-governmental organisation, acting internationally, which is concerned with archives and their role in the conduct of public and private activities, the protection of individual rights and the advancement of human knowledge and culture. Founded in 1948 at a meeting convened by UNESCO, the ICA was formally established at its first international congress held in Paris two years later in 1950. Its headquarters are in Paris. The ICA is a non-governmental organisation admitted in the category of consultative and associate relations with UNESCO, category A. It cooperates with other international organisations in implementing projects of common interest.

The management of our public records in Australia is a measure of the how open and accountable our governments are. It is a measure of our commitment to democratic principles and the rule of law and it is a yardstick by which we can be judged internationally.

During the course of our select committee deliberations, the role of the state and federal archivists, as represented by the CJC, was put on the public record. It was a position which Mr Lindeberg, the man at the centre of the affair, objected to quite vigorously at the time. The CJC's 1995 declaration has been subsequently roundly condemned by former chief Victorian archivist and former Australian ICA representative Mr Chris Hurley. He did a detailed analysis in March 1996. He now works at the national archives in New Zealand. Regrettably, our Senate select committee did not have the benefit of his expertise in 1995.

The issue at stake is essentially a simple one, but one of great importance. If the Crown or the state, through its statutory keeper of public records, cannot be relied on to impartially and independently protect public records from destruction when those records are known to be required for foreshadowed court proceedings or when it is known that they are the subject of a legally enforceable access statute, the due administration of justice is gravely imperilled. That is essentially what the Lindeberg declaration states in a document I wish to table later.

As a Democrat, I find it hard to think of anything more serious than the Crown or state deliberately shredding public records to thwart justice. One of Australia's leading Queen's Counsel, Mr Ian Callinan, described it as an unthinkable act. It is made much worse, however, when executive government uses and abuses the independent and impartial good office of a state or federal archivist to achieve that objective. Archivists should be protecting records in the public interest, not destroying them for any desired outcome of executive government or its agencies at the expense of individual lawful rights. It is fundamentally undemocratic and may breach criminal and administrative law in the process.

Archivists must be able to lawfully withstand pressure from any executive government and its agencies when incidents like this occur in the future. Former Queensland Police Commissioner Noel Newnham, now a lecturer at Charles Sturt University in Sydney, described this case as `monumentally serious'. He courageously, and quite properly, I believe, criticised the CJC's handling of the Lindeberg complaint and the cavalier manner in which that body treated him.

Let me conclude by saying this: it is totally unacceptable for any Australian government to send to the international community a signal that shredding public records to stop their use in court proceedings or to stop lawful access to them is acceptable conduct in our public and legal administration or in any aspect of public life at all. It brings our reputation as a nation governed by the rule of law into unacceptable disrepute.

The Queensland archivist, or any archivist, cannot operate above our courts and cannot be oblivious to the rights of individuals. While it is accepted that the Queensland archivist may have been misled by the Goss cabinet and others about the true legal status of the material she approved to be shredded, she certainly became aware shortly after the shredding, and did little to protect the public interest.

This is a serious matter. The current Queensland government appears incapable of properly resolving this matter. It is no wonder that the ICA is taking an interest in this case. I seek leave to table the Lindeberg declaration submission, dated 7 May 1997, so that honourable senators interested in this matter may read in greater detail why it has captured the attention of archivists throughout the world. I have given copies to the whips and there may be some problem. The government said they were happy with that.
Leave granted.

The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 24 April 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the names of the organisations to which the Minister has appointed consumer representatives.
(2) What are the names and backgrounds of the consumer representatives.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As at 24 April 1997, I have appointed consumer representative to the:

ROW.ENTRY: Complaints Resolution Scheme of the Financial Planning Association of Australia Ltd—Council

ANSWER.PARA: I have also confirmed the appointment of consumer representatives to the:

ROW.ENTRY: Australasian Furnishing Research and Development Institute Ltd—Exclusive Board
Insurance Brokers Dispute Facility—Insurance Brokers Compliance Council

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The names and backgrounds of the consumer representatives who have been appointed are:

ROW.ENTRY: Consumer/community policy officer with a community welfare sector organisation, now working for the NSW government
Lawyer with an independent legal/policy centre
Lawyer with a financial counselling service
Coordinator/principal solicitor for a community legal service

ANSWER.PARA: The names and backgrounds of the consumer representatives whose appointments have been confirmed are:

ROW.ENTRY: Research/policy manager with a non government organisation directed at reducing injury children

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Energy Research and Development Corporation Grants

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 24 April 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to each Energy Research and Development Corporation grant made in the 1993-94, 1994-95, 1995-96 and 1996-97 financial years, can the following information be provided:
(1) Project name and brief description, in particular whether it relates to renewable energy, energy efficiency or non-conventional energy sources.
(3) Date of approval and date on which contracts were signed.
(4) Duration of project and starting and finishing dates.
(5) Total grant and allocation for each year of the project.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is attached and has been provided by the Energy Research and Development Corporation (ERDC) on a project-by-project basis for 1993-94, 1994-95, 1995-96 and 1996-97 financial years. The projects have been classified by project keyword according to whether they related to renewable energy (REN), energy efficiency (EFF) or non-conventional energy sources (NCE).

ANSWER.PARA: The ERDC has advised that its database currently does not contain information on date approved and date contract signed for a number of projects, and a manual search of files to capture the data was not possible within the time and resource constraints.

ROW.ENTRY: Possible Participation in IEA Task 20—Solar Energy Retrofit
Funding for an Australian expert to evaluate benefit to Australia of joining the IEA Solar Heating and Cooling Task.
Demonstration of an Energy-Efficient New Commercial Building—Stage One
This project explored the use and promotion of advanced energy efficent design principles in a potential small ofice redevelopment in Canberra.
This study researched possible concepts for sourcing a premium for electricity generated from renewable sources.
The EcoDesign program was aimed at protecting the environment through design. This project developed and refined a kettle which saves energy through eliminating unnecessary reboils.
Sponsorship of annual Australian and New Zealand Solar Energy Society Conference
Development Facility for an In-Situ Measurement of Thermal Insulating Materials

The project aimed to develop a testing facility in Sydney for the resting of insulation products so that different types of insulation could be tested and rated against each other. Given to dispute between contractor and subcontractor, this project was terminated early by the contractor.
Evacuated glazing has the potential to reduce energy consumption in buildings by around 30%. This is a new technology and this project aimed to understand the heat transport aspect of the window.

This project builds on the RMIT Centre for Design's EcoReDesign( Program and assist Kambrook to identify and take through to commercialisation two products suitable for redesign in an energy-efficient and environmentally suitable way. This project was terminated early due to a change in corporate policy at Kambrook.
Fundamental Study of the Behaviour of Fine Particles in a Packed Bed (David Pinson)
Angular Selective Window Coatings Based on Metal/Insular Composites
Energy Efficiency Improvements to Electric Railway Locomotives using Retro-fit PWM Rectifier Technology (Frank Flinders)
Algorithms for Battery Storage Plants when Connected to a Utility Grid in Power and Industrial Networks (Gunilla Burrowes)
Design, Development & Testing of a Novelly Driven High Pressure Micro-compressor for Direct Injection Gas Engines (Frank Bruno)
Development of New Algorithms for Economic Dispatch and Generation Scheduling Problems in Power Systems (Suzannah, Yin Wa Wong)
This project discusses the technical issues and economic benefits of parabolic trough concentrator photovoltaic systems. It also discusses the potential market for this technology.
Study aims to identify where future reliable photovoltaic markets may develop and to suggest practical ways to penetrate any barriers to those markets.
An assessment of Australia's hot dry rock (HDR) geothermal energy resource, and the technical and economic factors involved in HDR energy development.
ERDC sponsorship of an International Workshop on Daylighting in Buildings.
High Efficiency Solar Water Pumping Systems—Product Range
This project confirmed the attractiveness of the coupling of very high efficiency, brushless DC motors to standard pump elements for use in solar water pumping systems.
Development of Commercial Energy Efficient Export Hay Production Systems

Project aimed to develop a commercial-sized energy efficient, hay production system that uses at least 30 per solar contribution to its energy needs. This project was terminated and funds were recommitted. A new project was subsequently established with another party.
Gas heat pump and absorption chiller/heater commercialisation
Gas and Fuel Corporation of Victoria
The overall objective is the commercialisation of gas fired heat pump and absorption chiller/heater systems in Australia.
The development of a new wireline traction device designed to help reduce operating costs and increase the efficiency of oil and gas well production in Australia.
Australian Participation in IEA Solar Power and Chemical Energy Systems Program

Program allows the sharing of technical and policy information and representation at various international fora. It also provides a coordination mechanism for solar thermal research activities in Australia.

This project evaluates the potential to increase the uptake of carbon dioxide by enhanced photosynthetic activity in our oceans. It also presents a review of the literature and results from an engineering demonstration of the feasible techniques.

This report discusses the production of a natural fibre insulation possessing those attributes. It focusses on loosefill wool insulation and a commercial insulation product which is fire and insect resistant, and has signficant export potential.
Sponsorship of Titanium Dioxide Solar Cell Workshop, with visiting academic Professor Michael Graetzel, the inventor of the Titanium Dioxide Solar Cell
Motor Vehicle Fuel Consumption In-service Versus Australian Standard Test Data
Department of Primary Industries and Energy

A study in which in-service fuel consumption data was obtained from fleet management information systems of large commercial fleet operators to enable a comparison to be made with Australian Standard test data.
Development of the Econodrive inverter—a speed control mechanism for motors which provide substantial savings in energy consumption.
This project investigated the technical viability of a thermochemical concept to store and transfer solar energy, using a reversible chemical reaction such as ammonia dissociation and recombination.
The Development of LNG as a Heavy Duty Vehicle Fuel
This project follows from the previous Appin LNG Project which demonstrate the use of LNG as an alternative to diesel fuel in heavy duty bulk haulage service.
Intermediate Temperature Solid Oxide Fuel Cell
Research and development of intermediate temperature ceramic fuel cell technology.
This program supports research to ensure that the most cost efficient and appropriate interconnections are built and maintained between existing distribution networks
Program directs research into technologies that are not yet available in the market place but which offer the potential for quantum leaps in efficiency in the electricity supply industry
Projects in the program are designed to address these and other issues associated with the continued use of plant and equipment as it approaches the end of its orginal design life.
Research and Demonstration: Optimised Hybrid Energy System
The development of an efficient hybrid energy variable speed system, a combination of renewable energy, diesel and battery power.
Explored methodology used in demonstrating energy conservation in commercial buildings. The project investigates an ecodesign approach to new buildings and those in retrofit.
Study on a Reversable Window Tinting System
The project evaluated the technology of a reversible window system and the strategies required to take the product from its current state, through to commercialisation.
The project aimed to bring together appropriate participants to prepare Australia's involvement in this new Solar Heating and Cooling Task and explore the benefits for Australia of being involved.
Development of a low cost Aluminium Metal Matrix Composite
This project is developing an optimal Aluminium Metal Matrix Composite utilising flyash for the world markets, particularly Automotive applications, assisting with their weight reduction targets.
Study on Daintree Tourist Resort Energy Management
Australian Participation in IEA Demand Side Management Program
Program involves the sharing of an international database on DSM programs and assesses the best options for research, development and demonstration of DSM technologies.
Study on Energy Efficient Renovation of Commercial Buildings

Project provides a sound understanding of the Australian commercial building market and its renovation process. It also identifies the potential to incorporate energy efficient considerations in that process, recommending mechanisms that could promote change
Development of a Ground Source Heat Pump System with Phase Change Thermal Storage
The Advanced Engineering Centre for Manufacturing

Developing an innovative energy storage system using phase change materials, which stores energy at one predetermined temperature, and slowly releases the energy. Applications include large buildings and glass houses.
Energy/Environmental Notes for Architects (and Other Building Designers)
An energy and environment reference source for architects and building designers, the Guide provides information on the greenhouse gas effect, biodiversity, life cycle analysis, and legislation.
Development of a Gas Feed Back and Gasifier/Engine Control System for Biomass Fuelled Entrained Flow Gasifier
Biomass Energy Services and Technology Pty Ltd
The development and testing of a 100kWe entrained flow biomass gasifier, engine, and clean-up and control system over a two-year period.
Queensland Department of Mines and Energy

To demonstrate and evaluate a new generic electric hybrid bus technology in Brisbane as a cost effective alternative transport technology to both diesel powered buses and existing electric bus designs.
Development of Standards and Test Protocols for Ethanol Fuel Blends
Explores interim standards and test protocols for ethanol use as a base transport fuel and for blends of ethanol with petrol and diesel
Extended Field Trials of Ethanol Fuel Blends in Vehicles
One of four studies undertaken to accelerate the market penetration of ethanol fuels in Australia.
Technical Improvements in Ethanol Fuel Blend mixtures
Reviews the status of ethanol fuel mixture technology. It examines trends in Australian ethanol and automotive industries.
Technical Improvements in the derivation of Ethanol from Lignocellulosic Feedstocks
Reviews past and present developments on the derivation of ethanol from lignocellulose based feedstocks.
Viability Assessment of Vanadium Redox Battery Manfacturing in Australia
A study to assess the viability of establishing a Vanadium Redox Battery Manufacturing industry in Australia.

It is estimated that at least one quarter of Australia's greenhouse gas emissions emanate from urban areas, mostly from the space heating, cooling and lighting of buildings, and from urban transport. The Urban Villages project identified sites in Melbourne that would be suitable for redevelopment. It assessed the potential of these sites for accommodating Melbourne's future housing demand and employment growth, while reducing energy use and greenhouse gas emissions.
Establishment of an IEA Photovoltaic Power Systems Consortium

Australia is considered a world leader in developing photovoltaic (PV) cells and systems, with a local industry manufacturing and supplying a range of products, from cells to PV integrated systems. Australia has joined this implementing agreement to learn from other countries active in this field, so that we can build on the sound basis we have for developing our PV industry; and to share knowledge with the international community.

This project explored the need to increase the efficiencies of steam raising in order to conserve fuel and help reduce greenhouse gasses. The executive summary describes the use of radiant tubes or candles as a way of burning natural gas with increased radiant efficiency. The project demonstrated that up to 49 per cent of radiant efficiencies could be achieved in sub-surface burners. Further work on the reliability of the burners now needs to be undertaken to offer boiler manufacturers an Australian gas fired alternative to present systems.
Development of Aquagas Marine Outboard Engine Conversions

The aim of this project was to develop and commercialise a conversion kit for marine oil-injected outboard petrol engines to operate on liquid petroleum gas (LPG). A successful outcome would result in reduced fuel operating costs and adverse environmental impact. A secondary objective of the project was to establish effective and safe working standards, qualifications and material selection for use in marine LPG installations. This project was terminated early due to difficulties experienced by the contractor.
Development of Analytical Models for Evaluating Embodied Energy in Construction
CSIRO Division of Building, Construction and Engineering

Buildings have a significant impact on the environment due to the energy embodied in construction materials. Currently, building professionals such as artchitects, engineers and quantity surveyors have very little guidance or quantitative information on the embodied energy impacts of individual materials or the total of the building. This report discusses the development of a prototype software package to quantify the energy embodied in the construction of a building.
Enhanced Methane Production from Low Permeability Coals by Permeability Development and/or Gas Flooding
Fly wheel energy storage, Phase 1: Due diligence and planning

Project established to report on the nature and size of likely early markets for flywheel energy storage systems in stationary applications. Project also to confirm the validity and completeness of the assessments made in the Flywheel Energy Storage report regarding the five enabling technologies, which are: fibre composite rotor systems; high-efficiency motor/generators; power-conditioning systems; magnetic bearings; and housing and containment systems. The project also aims to report on the state of development, in Australia and overseas, of the five enabling technologies.
High-Speed High-Efficiency Twin-Turbine Compressor for R134a Refrigerant

Multistack International is a chiller manufacturer. This project is developing a new, high speed high efficiency, twin turbine compressor that could be used in air conditioning and refrigeration systems, increasing their efficiency and reducing running costs. The compressor is 50 per cent more efficient that current compressors and 20 per cent of their size.

A prototype of the Anjay Spinning System was developed to improve current yarn spinning methods, particularly where the desired end product is fine yarn. This project addressed the economic advantages, the quality, and production rate capacity of the Anjay system, with particular emphasis on improving energy efficiency.
Evaluation of Australian Bituminous Coals: Slagging Characteristics of Intergrated Gasification Combined Cycles
CSIRO Division of Coal and Energy Technology

Project established to support the development of the clean use of new and existing black coal deposits in Australia, in advanced IGCC power plants by determination of their slag fluxing requirements during gasification.

This project addressed the development of an inexpensive and energy efficient low voltage lamp adapter for downlight fittings. Previously, retrofitting existing GLS and incandescent reflector lamp fittings has been limited to installing energy saving lamps—or replacing the entire lighting system.The convertalite is a simple non-hard wired retro-fit system which converts incadescent lamped 240 volt downlights to a more efficient 12 volt light source.The convertalite is designed to achieve energy reductions of up to 80 per cent and overcomes the problem that other lamps have of generating a lot of heat.
Gas in Coal—Coalbed Methane Working Party

CBM is a huge potential energy resource for Australia. However, it is currently vented to the atmosphere either naturally or through a mining pre-drainage process, making CBM a contributor to greenhouse gas emissions.

n 1995, ERDC established the Coalbed Methane Working Party to address ways of encouraging industry to work together, and to develop strategies for understanding the Australian conditions to accessing gas in coal. This has resulted in the planning, consultation and liaison activities for the development of The Commercial Significance to Australia of Gas in Coal Market Study were conducted during 1995‐96.
Research into the Bioremediation of Oil Spills in Tropical Australia

Much of tropical Australia is not only environmentally sensitive to oil spills but vast and remote. The use of mechanical or physical clean up techniques in mangrove and saltmarsh habitats can cause extensive damage to these foreshores and is extremely difficult and expensive to undertake. Bioremediation, or the accelerated and improved efficiency of the natural degradation of oil by micro-organisms, has the potential to reduce the environmental impact of marine oil spills on tropical Australian foreshores. The primary objective of this project is to assess the feasibility of bioremediation to clean up oil spills in environmentally sensitive tropical foreshore environments so that the findings can be incorporated into the overall planning and response management plan for oil spills in Australia.
To Assess the Exposure of Workers in the Australian Petroleum Industry to Hazardous substances including Benzenes & other Hydrocarbons

The Australian Institute of Petroleum Health Watch program has run for a number of years. In this project, ERDC has jointly invested with the AIP to investigate the level of exposure of petroleum industry employees to benzene and other hydrocarbons. It is hoped that the results of the project will provide evidence which can then be used by regulatory authorities such as Work Australia when it considers the establishment of future occupational exposure levels for benzene and total hydrocarbons.
Operation on Alternative Fuel of Optimised NGV Engines

The primary aim of this project was to explore the feasibility of operating the optimised NGV engine developed for the ERDC/Ford gas taxi project on an alternative fuel (in this case premium unleaded petrol), and to evaluate its performance, emmissions and durability to enable assessment of its commercial viability and compliance with current ADR's.

This project will undertake a proof of concept investigation of methods for the production of hydrogen using micro-organisms. A technical and economic feasbility of the process will also be undertaken to determine the merit of proceeding to pilot scale production.
Study on Polymer Drying by Microwave Technology
Industrial Microwave Technology & Environmental Corporation Pty Ltd

There is a high level of wastage in the processes of the polymer manufacturing industry. A significant reduction in the energy requirements for plastics manufacture would lead to improved competitiveness, and more efficient use of the machinery involved in the processes. This project will be seeking savings in operating costs over a standard machine as well as reduced time for drying the polymers in the machines. There is export potential in both the more competitive plastics produced from an improved process, as well as in the newly developed technology to produce it.
Australian Computer & Electronic Systems Pty Ltd
Wellbore Stability and Drilling Fluid Design for Australian Shales

This project developing the understanding and technology which describes the interaction between drilling fluids and active shales and which provides the basis for designing optimal drilling fluids. If successful, the technology will be made available to the Australian petroleum industry through an established service company, Baroid Australia.
Australian Participation in IEA Solar Heating and Cooling Program's Task 21: Daylight in Buildings

The basic objective of IEA Task 21 is to promote daylight conscious design with the aim of realising energy savings and visual and thermal comfort. ERDC facilitated the development of the Daylight Working Group to co-ordinate daylighting research around Australia and to participate in this international Task, and disseminate information both within Australia and overseas and to maximise any possible advantage to Australia.
Establishment of Biomass-Based Energy Industry Association

This project investigated the feasibility of establishing a biomass-based energy industry association, one of the recommendations from the study, Biomass in the Energy Cycle, released by ERDC in 1994.

The aim of this project is to design and construct a photovoltaic reflecting trough (PV/trough) concentrator system which can generate electricity for less than 20 c/kWh based on normal commercial conditions, and to transfer these designs and systems to Australian companies such as Solar Research Corporation, BP Solar and PV systems companies for commercialisation.

The project is the first phase of a program to establish in Australia the commercial production of electric windows which will act as a photovoltaic module on buildings. The modules will therefore be able to contribute to meeting a building's electricity needs. This phase of the project will show that it is possible to arrive at an acceptable technical design of dye sensitised nanocrystalline titanium dioxide solar cells to construct photovoltaic cells in the laboratory.
Cape Keraudren Tidal Power—Research and Development Review

This study assessed the feasibility of developing a small scale, commercial tidal energy demonstration plant at Cape Keraudren, on the North West coastline of Western Australia. As a renewable form of electricity,the recommended demonstration plant would consume no fossil fuels, be pollution-free and would provide a reliable, long term energy source for a remote area of Australia. According to the study, a relatively small tidal power plant could enable an estimated reduction in carbon dioxide emissions by between 45,000 and 70,000 tonnes each year of operation.
Gas Fired Pulse Combustion Heat Pump/Absorption Refrigeration
CSIRO Division of Building, Construction and Engineering

Unlike electricity, the demand for gas reduces in summer. This project is supporting the introduction and commercialisation of gas heat pumps and absorption chillers and heaters into Australia. Expected outcomes include reduced electricity needs and assisting the electricity and gas supply industries to manage seasonal demands.
Accumulation of Coalseam Gases in the Bowen Basin

This project will undertake a quantitative and qualitative assessment of hydrocarbon generation retention and or migration in Bowen Basin coals. One of the outcomes will be a software package (based on the mathematical modelling) which will enable industry players to predict concentrations of gases in specific locations.
Plan for Australian Technology in High Temperature Superconducting Wires

Depending on location, up to 10% of electricity may be lost in transmission and distribution networks and devices in Australia each year. This loss is due to the resistance in conventional metallic conductors. So called "superconductors" have zero resistance to electric current under certain operation conditions. Therefore the economical exploitation of these materials to deliver electricity is attractive to energy suppliers and users. High temperature superconductors are a class of ceramic materials that operate at temperatures up to 120 degrees Kelvin (minus 150 degrees Celsius). At these temperatures—which are high compared with those at which metallic superconductors can operate—the economics for exploiting the superconducting properties of these materials in power applications become attractive. This project is aiming to build a small scale manufacturing facility that could supply a range of Australian—developed, high temperature superconducting wire. The wire is considered to be one of the key elements in future electricity distribution cables and equipment and has great potential for other applications. The ability to produce the wire in lengths of up to 1km, and of consistent quality, will be regarded as a significant milestone in the commercialisation of this technology.
Superconducting Components for the Electrical Supply Industry
This project aims to develop prototype high temperature superconducting components for use in the electricity supply industry.
Development and Demonstration of a Refrigeration Fault Diagnosis System

Faulty refrigeration systems can result in a significant loss in efficiencies. Running faults in such machines are often difficult to detect, and are only solved when systems are serviced. This project aims to demonstrate the utility value of MENTOR for one of the breweries in Australia, to monitor its performance and compare it with conventional methods of operating/maintaining the refrigeration systems.
Development of an Innovative Steam Engine with Linear Alternator
Biomass Energy Services and Technology Pty Ltd

There is an increasing market for small steam engines in developing and developed countries. This project addressed the development of a high speed, low cost engine that uses electronic valves and linear alternators. Using modern electronics, the project aimed to reduce the cost of the engine and increase its efficiency. A proof of concept linear alternator was also built and tested using an electrical motor.
Daylight and Solar Performance Characterisation of Advanced Window Systems (Rebecca Powles)
Analysis & Development of Bidirectional, Soft Switched, Resonant Link Converters (Andrew Tuckey)
The Packing of Nonspherical Particles (Ruiping Zou)

This second stage to the program development sought further refinement and development of the concepts, particularly through informal "market survey feedback obtained while working with possible commercial supporters, investigation of options for enabling corporate structures, research and marketing to a broad range of potential major corporate sponsors and the electricity supply industry (ESI).
Seminar of the Adoption & Marketing of Energy Efficient Appliances

In March 1995, ERDC hosted a seminar in conjunction with the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, and the Royal Melbourne Institute for Technology, to promote the results of a study into the adoption and marketing of energy efficient appliances.
First Commercial Scale Demonstration of Convertech Biofuel Production for Power Generation—Module 1

This project demonstrates the Convertech technology for conversion of biomass to energy. It uses a "whole of tree" approach to the use of biomass—the modular technology enabling the production of energy only or energy and other by-products which add to the economic viability of the process.

Australia generates approximately 2% of the world's published research papers and patents. Therefore, it is essential that Australian industry and research communities have access to international endeavour and knowledge. The Energy Technology Information Program (ETIP) was established in 1995 by the Energy Research and Development Corporation (ERDC) to improve the quality of and access to information available on Australian and international energy research, technology and innovation. EnergySearch is the key tool that has been developed to achieve these goals. It is a gateway to information about Australian energy innovation projects and expertise. The information will be delivered through an interactive site on the World Wide Web (WWW). EnergySearch will enable access to: information on projects in energy research and innovation and on the people and organisations involved information about the expertise of people and capabilities of organisations across the energy sector the US Department of Energy's current energy research file the International Energy Agency's Energy database (still in development) EnergySearch aims to provide an important link between the public and private research sectors and industry. It will: promote the work and investigations of individuals and organisations assist in the search for consultants and specific expertise enhance finding opportunities for collaboration and avoiding duplication support users interactively enable direct input of information and feedback from users provide networking opportunities nationally and internationally.
The Development of Energy Efficient Thermal Food Processing Systems

This project aims to develop new methods for packaging food which will result in improving the energy efficiency of the sterilisation and packing process, as well as increasing the efficiency of transporting the food.

This project is a follow on from RMIT's Green Fridge Quest. The project aimed to bring together students and industry groups to look at new ways of reducing the energy requirements and costs for domestic heating. A range of new product ideas was developed, both within industry and by students, and the results will be published in a final report for dissemination.
Development of Lithium Ion Secondary Batteries
CSIRO Division of Materials, Science and Technology

This project evaluated the potential of Lithium Ion secondary battery systems and related technologies. There is an increasing need for an additional form of portable stored energy, derived from electricity, particularly in a rechargeable form. This report explores the state-of-the-art Lithium Ion technology with a view to scale up to electric vehicle size.
Sponsorship of this international conference hosted by the University of Melbourne.

In March 1995 ERDC commissioned the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) to estimate the effects on greenhouse gas emissions in 1999-2000 and 2004-5 if a third of all ERDC investments since 1990 were successfully commercialised. ABARE found that in the short term (5-10 years) the projects focussing on energy use are potentially the big energy savers in greenhouse gas emissions. Over the same time span, the supply side options (electricity generation and distribution) show the largest relative rises in potential carbon dioxide reductions.
Intensive Field Trials of Ethanol Blends in Vehicles
Fuel Blends: Emulsions of Hydrated Ethanol in Hydrocarbon Fuels

This project involves two distinct parts: Part A—hydrated ethanol/diesel emulsions; and Part B—hydrated ethanol/petrol emulsions. The primary objective for Part A is to optimise the chemistry of the copolymers comprising the DALCO emulsifier for use by diesel fuel and ethanol fuel distributors to increase the specific activity of these polymers and reduce the cost of hydrated ethanol/diesel fuel emulsion production. The primary objective for Part B is to optimise the chemistry of the copolymers comprising the DALCO emulsifier initally for use by researchers and regulatory authorities to produce stable emulsions of hydrated ethanol in petrol in order to identify any advantageous physiochemical properties of such hydrated ethanol/petrol emulsions compared with the properties of conventional anhydrous ethanol/petrol solutions.
Ethanol Production: Development of a Thermophilic Organism for the Total Fermentation of Lignocellulose Hydrolysates to Ethanol

The primary objectives of this program of research are: To study the activities of the various enzymes required for the catabolism of hemicellulose sugar xylose by thermophilic ethanologenic bacteria. The chosen organism is T. brockii or a similar Thermoanaerobacter strain. To create cell-free fermenting extracts of thermophilic bacteria, to which have been added enzymes from other sources, to investigate the limits to rate and extent of ethanolic fermentation. To construct a transgenic thermophilic bacterium expressing the Z.mobilis pyruvate decarboxylase gene to optimise ethanol productivity.
Development of Fungal Strains Capable of Economic Conversion of Cellulose to Ethanol

The overall objective of this project is to develop an Aspergillus strain (probably Aspergillus nidulans) capable of the economic conversion of cellulose to ethanol for use in the cellulose waste processing industry in order to enhance the value of the waste products, reduce pollution and provide a useful fuel for Australian industry and transport. Secondary objectives are to investigate ethanol production and carbon repression in both industrially useful and model organisms, and in strains of filamentous fungi.
Fermentation of Hemicellulose Hydrolysates using Recombinant E.Coli and Saccharomyces Cerevisiae

The objectives of this project are to: develop strategies and technology for using recombinant E. coli and Saccharomyces cerevisiae to produce ethanol from lignocellulosics in continuous culture. develop technologies to permit fermentation of concentrated acid hydrolysates by the above organisms. study the potential of waste casein hydrolysate as a cheap, novel and apparently ideal nutrient source for commercial ethanol fermentations involving E. coli.

This project involves research into four distinct, yet interrelated, sub-topics: Direct microbial conversion of lignocellulosics to ethanol Optimisation of technology for the fermentation of hemicellulose hydrolysates Development of improved microbial strains for fermentation of hemicellulose sugars simultaneous saccharification and fermentation—development and testing of novel organisms
Sponsorship of annual conference held by the Australian and New Zealand Solar Energy Society.
A New Methodology for Tracing Oil Migration Pathways from Source to Reservoir

The overall objective is to increase the rate of discovery of oil through analysis of oil bearing fluid inclusions from unsuccessful wells to determine whether the borehole is on a migration pathway. These pathways will be mapped from source to accumulation to determine if more than one oil charge has migrated through targeted horizons. If successful, the technique will be made available to the oil industry which could result in reduced costs and damage to the environment from a decrease of the number of holes drilled during the exploration process.
Direct Fuel Injection for the Automotive Four Stroke Engine

Orbital's existing direct injection, two-stroke technology is being developed for four-stroke automotive applications to better meet the requirements of the passenger vehicle market. The focus of the project is to reduce fuel consumption of the urban test vehicle by 10 per cent whilst also achieving a reduction in nitrogen oxides, carbon monoxide and hydrocarbon emissions. Exhaust emissions performance will then be further refined to meet the forthcoming low emission vehicle target levels mandated in the United States and Europe. Successful adoption of this technology by the motor industry would result in significant reduction in greenhouse gas emissions from passenger vehicles. There would also be benefits through improved driveability, reduced local exhaust emissions and therefore less smog, and reduced energy requirements in the urban transport fleet, resulting in fuel cost savings for vehicle owners.

A site in Melbourne is demonstrating a battery load levelling system. Load levelling is the management of the peaks and troughs in electricity demand and is facilitated by storing electricity in batteries. The cost of conventional batteries prevents their use in most load levelling situations. Zinc bromine batteries have been chosen for this demonstration project because they are innovative and promise to be much cheaper than existing batteries. Therefore, the overall economics of the battery load levelling systems could become more attractive. By demonstrating a real battery system integrated into the electricity supply network, the project will showcase the potential of this Australian owned technology. Expected benefits include increased efficiency in electricity supply, and subsequent potential reductions in greenhouse gas emissions.
Performance Enhanced Flat Plate Solar Hot Water Systems

This project is designed to achieve improved cost effectiveness and market acceptance of solar water heaters by enhancing their performance. It involves developing a low cost reflector surface for use as a concentrator which can boost the winter performance of flat plate solar water heaters. The reflector technology will have the potential to increase the projected area of the solar collector in winter, without increasing collection rates in summer. To complement the reflector technology, an advanced, two-faced, flat plate solar collector will also be investigated. Improving collector performance by incorporation devices that reduce internal air flow and reflection could reduce the negative impacts of high operating temperatures. This in turn could allow increased storage temperatures, and smaller, more heavily insulated tanks could be used to store a similar amount of energy than that available in current systems.

The conversion of biomass to energy provides an ideal solution to the animal and food processing industry's waste problems. This project addressed the value of establishing commercial waste to energy facilities using a locally developed anaerobic digester technology. It assesses the viability of producing energy and a quality organic fertiliser as a by-product from processing green and putrescible organic wastes.
The project was an addendum to the Study on the Renovation of Commercial Buildings, but focussing on the knowledge within the construction and design industry of energy-efficient windows.
Compressed Natural Gas Powered Trucks for Local Government and Short Haul Use (formerly Compressed Natural Gas Powered Garbage Compactor Truck)

Diesel-powered, heavy vehicles operating in urban environments impact on levels of local air and noise pollution. In this project, Waverley Council in Sydney, NSW, is to commission two spark ignited, compressed natural gas (CNG) powered trucks—a garbage compactor and a tipper. A 12-month operational trial of the vehicles will be conducted. The demonstration of the technology is designed to facilitate the adoption of the vehicles in Australia. CNG-powered trucks have quieter engines and cleaner emissions, providing a more attractive option for vehicles in localised environments. An extensive economic and environmental assessment will be undertaken to investigate both the short term, and medium to long term benefits and the implications of the adoption of the technology. This will include an analysis of the short haul private market, together with the potential for government initiatives to encourage the use of the technology. The project is also funded by the New South Wales Department of Energy, and is supported by the South Sydney Regional Organisation of Councils (SSROC). SSROC membership covers a substantial portion of southern Sydney and its support offers significant potential for the immediate adoption of the technology, should the outcome of the pilot project prove to be favourable.
A Collaborative IEA SolarPACES Task II Project—Optical Temperature and Reflectivity Measurements on Hot Solar Reactor surfaces

A technique to optically measure the temperature, irradiance and reflectivity distributions on hot solar irradiated surfaces was developed. The technique, developed at the Paul Scherrer Institute in Switzerland, was applied to the Australian National University's solar ammonia dissocation reactor in Canberra. The project was part of a multilateral, collaborative agreement under the International Energy Agency's SolarPACES program.
Energy Metering in High Pressure Natural Gas Transmission

New methods for measuring the flow of natural gas and its behaviour at different pressures, temperatures and compositions, will be developed in this project. This information is important for improving pipeline efficiencies in the Australian gas industry and will aid its competitiveness nationally and in overseas markets. Once the measurements have been gathered, they will assist in establishing parameters for determining gas measurement and characteristics over a wide range of conditions. The information will also be validated with leading European gas research organisations to ensure that international measurement procedures are optimised for Australian conditions.
Pathways to Innovation in the ESI Study

The study complements the scoping paper, Innovation in the Australian Electricity Supply Industry, by identifying which technology development areas the energy market and the electricity business can support to offer the best environmental developments for our customers contributing to future growth and profit.
Vehicle Integrity Testing of Natural Gas Vehicle Cylinders by Acoustic Emission Techniques

This project is developing testing procedures for natural gas vehicle cylinders, using acoustic emission techniques. The tests will be designed to locate and analyse specific defects, as well as conducting total structural evaluations of metal and composite gas cylinders.
Energy Efficient Production of Synthetic Rutile
Low Cost 5kW Windmill, Induction Generator and Power Point Tracking Transformer Project
